like how the bass is all wonga wonga as the synth does its whole blanga blanga shiz until they repeat the pub chorus quite nicely again. i mean overall...i preferred the show. i know i know just because she dead does not mean she better but it just had a superior premise and was more to the point. this album is saved by absolute professionalism that seems to overshadow their creative side a lot more. gilmour is an amazing guitar player but does not seem to use this ability in his composing power and let us it falter into the trap of being a good player over a good inventor. you can make the best toast in the world but that does not make you a quality chef the prog cliches of course are in full force which kind of have a major marmite effect on whether you will loatheve this album or not. welcome to the machine is still a fanfuck of a song though and i do recommend this album as a listen to real floyd heads. it flows brilliantly and i see it being more deserving than dark side as it manages to seem much more entertaining than that without resorting to symbolism and harmonic gimmickry. it is fuller better and has more bounce. like a breast.

not a huge pink floyd fan but after revisiting wish you were here this is so obviously the bands shining diamond in their beloved storied discography. this may be the most classic most timeless effort they have made. just listen to parts 1-5 of shine on you crazy diamond. i am not a 70s expert but is there another band that sounds like this? glistening ambient music that does not bore the mind. all these production tricks that really tricks up on ya. the songwriting coming from a simple idea but exaggerated and jammed out in pink floyds repertoire. a solid ass album. it is only rated lower because of replay value but still fye.

this album while having interesting ideas i found to be a slog to get through. it feels like 40 minutes of the same damn song. i would listen to dark side of the moon or atomic heart mother over this album any day.

it is strange to think that if radiohead never released ok computer -this- of all albums would be the highest rated album on this website. i like this album alright but it is an odd thing to consider. when i was 1213 this was a favorite album of mine as i was really first exploring music then 10 years later i performatively gave this album an 0.5 on here and called it poop because i had just found out who can were or whatever  felt entitled to a being a dickhead about music stage that people on here who do not like me think i am still in. now over 10 years after that i am making an attempt to reconcile these two past positions of mine by revisiting it. musically this thing is pretty solid for commercial prog rock  the lyrics on the title track are good but damn these lyrics elsewhere are so bad - what exactly are they complaining about that the head of some record company did not actually know who they were? they were still making money hand over fist who gives a fuck. sensitive babies. the title track is a great song and the instrumental portions of all the songs are just fine. it really only stinks when you notice how much of the lyrics are just talking about nothing important.

01-02-2022 wish you were here arranca con las primeras 5 partes de shine on you crazy diamond que a mi parecer tarda algo en empezar ya que los primeros minutos me parecen muy redundantes pero cuando entran los riffs de guitarra es cuando todo se pone interesante la cancion dura 12 minutos y al igual que las demas canciones del album la duracion es algo que juega en su contra la mayoria del tiempo. welcome to the machine tiene una melodia de voz y delivery bastante raro no me gusto pero debo admitir que el puente de la cancion es interesante al igual que los sintetizadores que llegan a inundar la cancion. have a cigar debe ser la cancion mas groovy y funky del album y a decir verdad se siente como un respiro fresco dentro de los primeros 20 minutos del album donde ya se nos habia llenado de este rock progresivo lento y medio tedioso. las lineas de bajo de waters se lucen en la mayoria de los temas al igual que los solos de gilmour aunque debo admitir que no soy tan fan de su voz. wish you were here el tema mas popular de pink floyd suena muy bien junto a todo el contexto del album es una cancion muy emotiva y catchy con momentos preciosos bastante memorables se sabe que es un maldito himno. todo termina con las partes 6 a 9 de shine on you crazy diamond que a pesar de tener casi la misma duracion que las primeras partes me parecio menos pesada que su predecesora y puedo decir que me gust mas me parecio un buen cierre del album se siente nostalgico como deberia ya que el tema central del album segun dicen es syd barret y sus problemas entonces para ser algo tan delicado puedo decir que el grupo supo canalizar todo lo que sentan y entregaron un gran album. calificacion 8 canciones favoritas shine on you crazy diamond 1-5 have a cigar wish you were here shine on you crazy diamond 6-9 canciones menos favoritas welcome to the machine

at the time of writing i am the 1000th review for this album. that is why i wrote this review. i do not particularly like pink floyd i guess i have never been high enough while listening to them. this albums alright but whatever i would just listen to radiohead or something.
if you think dsotm is better than this you are fucking delusional

two great parts of shine on you crazy diamond and some unimpressive and vapid fillers in between. however this album as a whole is still more interesting than anything the man to whom it was dedicated did.

the title track sounds like a melody so they chose it right. if the stuff is really out of my grasp like rihanna its a 30 but i dont think this applies. pink floyds my defifinition of not understanding.

pink floyd are one of those bands i have a tough time approaching. as of writing this review i have heard 3 floyd albums this one animals and part of dark side. this album while good is nowhere near good enough to explain the hype for me. it is obvious why they are popular however. their sound is very distinct yet formulaic and their lyrics can relate to a large audience. but getting back onto the album itself what makes it just ok in my opinion? let us start with the first track shine on you crazy diamond. it is fine i guess. typical rock guitar structures and some admittedly hard hitting lyrics centering around syd barrett. then we get to my favorite track welcome to the machine. the sound of this song in particular really intrigues me and is probably the sole reason i would want to listen to this again. the bass synths and the echoing guitar make for one chilling track. honestly i completely forgot what the other songs sounded like. i recall have a cigar having a noticeably more bluesy sound to it and nothing else. so my verdict? eh. not great but not horribly offensive. i guess king crimson kind of corrupted my taste in prog rock because floyd just sounds too glamorous to me. if you like glam and prog rock however it will not hurt to check this out.

is it good? yeah it is good. i like it. is it the 2nd greatest piece of music ever made??? ehhhhhh. i would not even say it is the second best pink floyd album. overrated and overhyped but still amazing synths play a huge part in this and it works perfect with roger waters bass and voice. an absolute must-listen.

sonically brilliant but some of the production has not aged well. the middle 3 tracks are perfect. they are truly thrilled to listen to. wish you were here is a touching tribute that still holds its own. the opening tracks are not too long as some may complain. i just find the guitar shrieking and bending and the strange synthshorns are really meh. i do not know the vocals are amazing throughout i just cannot get behind certain parts of the sound. all that said i appreciate its significance and for all my plights its worst tracks are still leagues ahead of most songs put out today.

i am sorry. i wanted to like this more. i really did. i. . . do not actually have much to say on the matter. i can recognize this as quality music but my god it takes so long to get where it is going. again there is something hereand when you actually get to hear it it really is quite goodbut it is buried in plodding nothingness. in jazz the central concept is that of tension and releasethat is you can pretty much play anything after anything if you commit to it enough and your brain will eventually just make up the logical pathway to connect them which is why music theory is so descriptive and not prescriptive. the thing is there is not really that tension herebarely a diatonic tritone throughout the middle three songsand so that release comes at no real cost. and yes i get that that is kind of the point but that does not make it any more interesting of a listening experience. the clip of   pyotr tchaikovskys symphony no.4 had me hopeful though. i do not knowi guess this one is not for me. the dark side of the moon is still great though.

from interplanetary sunsets showering onto plugged machines wish you were here is an aerial perspective of roger waters eulogy to late band-member syd barrett. a melodramatic meltdown into synthetic servitude. for an everlasting album with only five tracks strangely enough it fills out forty-four whole minutes. though pink floyd is notorious for those dragged-dirt guitar solos and it certainly shines here. and knowing how muddle-headed the band is throughout the community you either love it or hate it. pink floyd is no stranger to dimmed-out albums that stretch an opera so far you lather in it the dark side of the moon on the flip-side this paean has definite dips. welcome to the machine and have a cigar carry-out the continued sound of shine on you crazy diamond pts. 1-5 but they seem so clashing compared to the softer compositions like the latter compilation. all parts of shine on you crazy diamond and wish you were here are the definite highlights of this golden oldie.
this whole album was dull. i could not stand a second without skipping ahead. i do not understand the reviews this album gets. wish you were here is pretty overrated dsotm is also boring.

pink floyd is just one of those bands you either completely dig them or you just do not get the exaggerated fanfare around their work. i myself belong to the latter camp. other than the short longing title track the rest of this is just...well long. too long and that is why this record for the most part gets boring fast. also welcome to the machine might be the most redundant pink floyd song ever.

this is simply one of the tritest and most vapid things i have ever heard. it is just fine. none of these musical ideas are interesting and definitely not worthy of the record-space that is given to them. do not pull the it is old card on me either because this is 1975. red by king crimson was released the previous year. i mean jesus yes had already released 3 albums that are better than this. the only reason this is not a 25 is because it is not unpleasant or anything. but i could not imagine sitting down to listen to this again. this is an album about nothing and it sounds like nothing. in one ear and out the other.

i can appreciate the talent and effort that went in this album but i am sick of hearing its better tracks from overexposure. shine on you crazy diamond and wish you were here make me cringe when i hear their choruses. i envy the future generations who will not be flogged with this album so they can properly enjoy it.
never has such an expertly-produced album also been so uninteresting to me. i wish i could understand what people hear in anything except the opener and the title track.

this album really does not do a lot for me. the whole of shine on you crazy diamonds is really solid when there is actually something going on but for its 26 minute run time more than half the album almost 15 of those minutes there is next to nothing going on. i enjoy instrumental bits when they add to the atmosphere of an album but that is not what is happening here. there is nothing i dislike more in music than wasting time and there is a lot of that between these two songs. welcome to the machine is okay but it does not justify lasting nearly eight minutes and does not do anything special. have a cigar is one of more diverse sounding songs on the record. i am not a big fan of the lyrics but it sounds cool so i will not hate on it too hard. the title track is far and away the standout of the album. none of its five minutes are wasted and it only leaves me wishing the whole album sounded like this. my rating for this album is based almost entirely in the more critical aspects the instrumentation and singing mainly. personally not an album that makes me want to relisten. the album art is cool as hell though favorite tracks wish you were here rating light to decent 7
welcome to the machine and have a cigar really drag this one down from great to just good.

this is part of a series of my reviews on the band. i have reviewed all pre-1980 non-soundtrack albums and the reviews should be read in order. part of a stretch of very overrated pink floyd albums. this one features some higher highs than the dark side of the moon though it also features lower lows. the final floyd album which i enjoy. shine on you crazy diamond 1-5 is a beautiful long track that i will not cover here. it is very good. welcome to the machine and have a cigar are bad. they both have the same themes oppression from labels within the music industry. conceptually they could be good but in my opinion neither track works well in execution. rhythmically they feel quite empty. the vocals i can only describe as annoying. wish you were here is a track of longing. the vocals and the guitar are very sweet and pair well together. shine on you crazy diamond6-9 is also great. like the earlier section i will not cover it here. listen to it. this album like i mentioned is the last pink floyd album that i enjoy. that is not to say that this is a peak by any means but rather that it is truly all down hill from here. if only it was not for the second and third track perhaps i would enjoy it more.

wish you were here 1975 by pink floyd is very similar to the original suite but made up of different instruments and settings with much different sounds including floating candles. it is also very different in its use of a tremolo and string patterns so it should not be confused with the lp recording. the suite is often misidentified as tron by film-music fans though the films plot had the main characters having become obsessed with a colorful computer game it was later revealed that the other characters were actually kind robots. the piano concerto no. 2 by mozart is often mistaken for this even though it had no actual piano accompaniment whatsoever. wish you were here 1975 by pink floyd is not a movie so much as a collection of musical scores recorded over a period of several days in a studio by jazz legends miles davis and herbie hancock arranged by warren cowan and some singers including the legendary john coltrane. it is a video essay in the classic sense centered on the two groundbreaking sessions the assembly of the pre-album work that would become the album and the introduction of audience composer peter paul  mary 1996 during the final days of the sessions. in conclusion wish you were here is the perfect record for people like me who are always interested in the politics of gender and sexuality but have never held a trans person in their real-life hands. unholy

reviewing and rating albums that played such a big part in your formative years is a strange thing. there is literally hundreds of albums that i like lots more - that mean a lot more to me - than this does but this and let us say master of puppets and a bunch of other canonical rock albums is totally ingrained in my being more than any of those other better and more important albums ever will be. i know every note of this not one moment is a surprise to me i can learn nothing more from this. but it still sounds really good to me and i cannot give it a less than good rating.

after months retracing the steps of pink floyd left before dark side of the moon i finally make it onto the other sides wake. am i better off after only having discovered one rewarding album atom heart mother? given the clear ascension in talent and substance a testament to ones artistic growth i would say yes. in many ways wish you were here picks up where dark side of the moon left off centering a concept around ones mental enigma. here it is directed at former pink floyd member syd barrett and his mental breakdown depicted quite breathtakingly on the cover. wish you were here and more precisely the bookended shine on you crazy diamond cherish those who have endured the perils of mental instability with capricious theatrics and thought-provoking lyrics performed by roger waters. given the climate of the times i am reviewing this album in 2019 the handling of mental health as an honorable affliction to experience is admirable. unfortunately waters attempted to shoehorn a secondary concept into wish you were here which on the surface aimed to provide backstory to barretts breakdown but under thinly-veiled layers mocked the music industry through the eyes of a cantankerous individual. a concept that i would not mind normally but given the concept feels unjustified and lackluster. certainly not as coherent and thorough as dark side of the moons. these moments do wear down welcome to the machine and have a cigar but only lyrically for the musical elements still adhere to pink floyds textbook mannerisms. which reach an all-time high here. i see why progressive rock fanatics foam over wish you were here. the instrumental segments are monstrous epics spoiled with rich nuance and ear-warming jazz. at times they linger a tad too long for my liking seen especially on what is essentially shine on you crazy diamonds remix pts. 6-9. normally i would not mind a reprise but only 18 minutes separates the pieces so it does not feel warranted or all that impactful. elsewhere the first minute of welcome to the machine essentially kickstarted industrial music to the masses and is easily pink floyds greatest field recording element. while the song does not reach the innovative highs set early on it still carries the ominous hopeless atmosphere to a satisfying culmination. absolutely nothing beats the title track though that is something almost everyone agrees on. like welcome to the machines cutting-edge opening wish you were here starts with a short television sample unheard of in the mid 1970s. however things take a more folk rock route here drawing similarities to the underrated middle portion of atom heart mother. the evolution of wish you were here and waters lovely vocals take the shockingly non-single to unfathomable heights though and really should have been the conclusion to wish you were here.
soundtrack to paint drying. well recorded.

got to sayi am not crazy about shine on you crazy diamond. it is fine in a pinch. the core three songs i could listen to ad infinitum  have a cigar boasting one of the most dazzling chord progressions in rock. shine on you crazy diamond fools me for jamming though i realize that it was consciously structured in the studio.

this album is a very sweet album as it serves as a tribute to syd barrett. the keyboards as well as the other instrumentals are very melancholy when the album discusses syd and his descent into madness. pink floyd reflected on why their former band mate fell off and the band is definitely more vulnerable because of this album. the first theme of the album syd barrett is done rather well but the second theme of the vices of fame and capitalism is not quite as well executed. the lyrics get lacklustre on tracks like welcome to the machine which come off as preachy but not relatable. although the album does redeem itself with the anti-music label theme on have a cigar especially with the guest vocalist which is a nice touch. the flow between tracks is there but it is not as creative as i would have hoped. the flow between themes is non-existent which is my main problem with this album. the two themes are mentioned but they do not mesh together very well. i feel this album could have emphasized the because-and-effect relationship of fame and syds madness a lot more and through that could have been a far more cohesive album. pink floyd felt pressured to make an album at this time and they felt discombobulated with their loss of syd barrett and their growing fame and demand from the music industry and it shows through this album. although this album is solid with good music and stellar production i wish it had more thematic cohesion and less vague preaching. with all that said it is a great tribute to syd barrett which made me smile and watch as pink floyd said goodbye to their former band mate and old friend.

sad that this is widely considered their best work. pf have made some absolute classics bursting with personality - from piper to meddle and dark side and animals - i do not know why anyone would listen to this album that drags its feet so much and rehashes a lot of ideas that they already did in a much more interesting way. this album seems like a prime example of a band becoming too famous and iconic to have to actually try to make interesting music anymore. soycd is a great lullaby

no doubt better than the dire dark side of the moon pink floyd return to the more thematic music of some of their earlier works echoes say. the opening of shine on you crazy diamond is quite nice. with the rock overture of part two the assembled individuals actually sound like a group. the segue into the vocals is effective. and the lyrics while not subtle at least attempt a fitting tribute to barrett. they manage to get 25 minutes out of the one song by splitting it in two. this is the very definition of milking a musical idea. what else can i say that is positive? i enjoy the vcs 3 at the start of machine setting up a nice pulse. the groove of have a cigar is serviceable and roy harper delivers the lines well. i like the way wish you were here starts with a guitar line that seems to emulate another from some lost recording. but no two of the songs seem to come from the same record. thematically this record retreads familiar ground. welcome to the machine worries over the corporatisation of.... no it is a warning against technology... no it is... let us face it any political message pink floyd might muster is incoherent. even worse is have a cigar the epitome of songs on which fantastically spoiled rock stars complain about all their money. just fuck right off.

ditch welcome to the machine and have a cigar and release the rest as a shorter lp you have got gold here. the under-cooked tracks in the middle are as bland as can be and highlight my biggest issue with pink floyd-- everyone there was very talented but their work lacked any sort of spirit. i do not feel passion in their work but i do believe they were all passionate musicians.
de enformiga och tysta partierna verkar sga mycket mer till mnga lyssnare n vad man kan hra i musiken. tyvrr hr jag bara enformighet och tystnad.
this album would be a lot better without synthesizers. a lot better.

admittedly this album is more honest and less tawdry than dark side of the moon but where it succeeds in achieving what can be seen as the bare minimum of artistry it fails as a piece in and of itself. there are certainly times when the album is listenable and enjoyable but in the same respect that dsotm sacrificed artistry for listenability wish you were here sacrifices listenability for artistry. nobody needs nearly 20 minutes of an album that sounds indistinguishable on its own. sure there are 1213 minute songs that have merit being that long but the sonic journey of shine on you crazy diamond is lost in the pretension of itself. if the piece had been condensed to its essentials it would easily improve the album while sacrificing very little of the supposed artistry it touts. ultimately it serves as a lesson for all other musicians do not make music that does nothing for the sake of making an artsy song it is long and unnecessary nobody enjoys it except for psuedo-intellectuals such as yourself.

essentially four songs that would go on to dominate airwaves the world over pink floyd stubbornly imprison themselves in the studio determined to create something fresh sonically striking and linked by a single theme to captivate the minds of curious listeners. all four songs are scatter-shot with the sexy blues bends of gilmour and thankfully only the openercloser tribute to syd directly recalls dark side particularly parrys gripping saxophone solo. the absence of clare torrys formless wailing may be the albums biggest plus. welcome to the machine is wildly original keyboards and clean guitars creating the highest high drama. no drums pulsing keyboards... moustache-era meets the space age. the funky riff and sci-fi keys of have a cigar mesh wells with roy harpers yelps and croons and wish you were here has become the ultimate wave-your-lighter campfire song seemingly more popular each year. the machine-like sucked-into-the-void interludes and other studio tricks along with the uncomplicated anti-music-business leitmotif make for one of the more intelligent rock records of the 1970s. it is my favorite floyd record and while i respect the art the pedigree of the players even the artwork - i always seem to reject it outright. i really tried to enjoy it this time adding it to my regular rotation both in the car and by the turntable. total number of plays in two months zero. just a flavor of a food that i do not enjoy and this counts for everything in how i rank an album.

let me see if i can explain this using a sandwich metaphor because that is what this album feels like a weird and not very good sandwich. let us say i am in the pink floyd restaurant. there is a new sandwich everyone is been talking about the wish you were here sandwich. i am getting sick of the dark side burger and i am feeling risky today so i order it. the plate comes to my table and the first thing i notice is the big-ass slices of bread. these are of course the shine on suites. they are a bit hard to tackle and overwhelming but at least they keep everything inside from falling out of place. it is the first thing my teeth sink into and i am hooked. they are sweet but have a bitter aftertaste. under the top slice is welcome to the machine which in this metaphor is a burned piece of lettuce. it is weird and robotic and i am wondering why it is in the sandwich. it is probably one of those new food trends that is clearly trying to be something more than it really is. i can kind of slide out the remains of the lettuce from the sandwich so i am going to ignore it and keep eating. have a cigar is... wait what is this? it is another burned piece of lettuce. this one is even more burned than the last. what the fuck? why the hell are there two burned slices of lettuce? i ask the waiter if this is right there is no way there are supposed to be two slices of lettuce. he says no that is the way the chef made it. he explains chef floyd is a little distracted by losing his sous chef barrett so i keep eating. finally we get to the meat of the sandwich. it is juicy enough to make me forget about the weird lettuce parts i have discarded onto my plate. i do not know how meat can taste sweet like this but it kind of works. clearly this is what everyone is raving about. i could probably eat this all day but i would probably get sick of it. and then i am already at the end of the sandwich. that is it? i mean the bread was great and the meat was tasty-- a little too sweet. but i mean what the fuck were those two pieces of lettuce? i will translate this back into music reviewing because i am getting tired of this metaphor. have a cigar and welcome to the machine both have the same dumb message do not trust the music industry!! not only do they not fit in with the rest of the bittersweet nature of the album but they also kind of suck. gilmour and harpers strained vocals yelling about poisoning real music or something. it is no wonder these are the tracks written solely by waters. they are preachy and not very interesting musically. the synth of welcome is cool and the ending solo of cigar is pretty cool but neither save either of these tracks from waters hit-you-over-the-head style. shine on and the title track are great but i think people forget two of pink floyds least enjoyable songs are also on this album. perfect for getting lost in the celestial shine on suite and pretending the rest of the album does not exist

wish you were here is for the most part taken up by the song shine on you crazy diamond. a 26 minute tribute to former friend and bandmate syd barrett. it is divided into nine parts and split into two halves one to begin the album one to end it. syd had taken too many drugs and went crazy so the band mourned the effective loss and expressed it in the song. the result is a near masterpiece filled with dense emotion and weaving atmospheres. it starts with a synth playing long and ambient minor chords setting a dramatic and solemn tone. with delicate synth and slide guitar soloing over it the chords underneath have a stillness and gravity that really effectively set up the magnitude of the piece. in part two those chords fade out and the famous four notes unofficially named syds theme hit. they are played in isolation a few times between tense pauses before the band joins in. this moment to me is a perfect representation for the theme of the song. the chord is ambiguous as you are not sure of its musical context. it ends on an e note which is not part of the g minor scale. this makes those four notes dramatic but also mysterious. the starkness adds a sense of importance like everyone should turn their heads toward it. it keeps playing the drums build up and the band explodes into a c chord right as that final e note plays revealing it as the major 3rd. it then gives the theme a direct and celebratory sound. this sense of clarity and unison is the band reconnecting with syd as they knew him and paying him tribute. it really opens the piece up and it is a great introduction of what is to come. the sorrow continues with the synth and guitar soloing. there is a really cool moment where the band stops and sustains and you think vocals are going to start. the lead guitar then just comes back in with heightened intensity like it just was not finished expressing its sadness. by the time the vocals finally do come it feels rather revealing. as if you just saw someone cry for twenty minutes and they actually start talking. the lyrics are about the man losing his way and his touch with reality using similes and metaphors. when the vocals erupt in the shine on you crazy diamond refrain it feels like a distraught but accepting farewell. like they are ceremonially releasing this old friend they know will never come back. syds theme then returns for part five but this time transitioning to a subdued and jazzy sax solo. i think it represents syds relatively neutral state of mind. it seems detached from the other parts in its mood with a slight night club vibe to it. it feels a little out of place but it is a nice way to lightened the load after the heaviness of the first four parts. the following song is welcome to the machine. it is about the machine that is the music industry. the pulsing synths do a good job at evoking a big and intimidating machine but overall the song is too overblown. coming after a truly harrowing tune about a beloved friend losing his mind greedy business men having too much control seems like a relatively trivial subject matter to dramatize. i do not disagree with the sentiment but the loud acoustic strums and constant strained vocals just sound melodramatic. gilmore and waters sing together and they have a constant intensity that seems almost gothic when paired with the industrial synths. the synths do sound fantastic on a technical level the whole album has top notch production and the song takes you to a unique place. it is just not a place i can care much about. the song would have probably worked better as an instrumental. the next song have a cigar has a nice groovy instrumental but i do not like the vocals. roy harper is the singer and i am not sure why he is singing other than that he was recording in the same building as pink floyd and they were friends. the singing does not elevate the music at all. the sound once again is huge and the synth riff is booming but the vocals and lyrics fall short. the words are a mocking of the typical clueless music industry guy who cares only of the bottom line. the jokey and sarcastic tone does not fit with the big commanding instrumental. there is not a coherent rhyme scheme and overall it just sounds kind of lazy. roy harpers voice sounds pretty similar to waters and gilmore further posing the question of why he is singing it. i do not know if the two band members would have made the song much better but i think waters would have more effectively conveyed the bitter attitude. the guitar solo at the end is the best part with david gilmore at his most loose just wailing over the cool rhythm. this song again would have probably worked better as an instrumental at least for me. things get back on track as the syd theme returns with wish you were here. the intro is a perfect metaphor of the meaning of the song. far in the distance you hear the main guitar line play and in front and center comes some lead guitar playing sad simple melodies over it. the sense of distance with the lead guitar being here and the accompaniment that it is playing to being far away really encompasses the title. the song itself is another tribute to syd barrett but this time the strain is gone and it is just a simple expression of sadness. like some afternoon he thought of him and had a momentary period of sorrow and introspection. the song has one of the most infectious and recognizable acoustic riffs out there and is really poignant in its simplicity. the album ends with part two of shine on you crazy diamond. this time the synth and guitar soloing parts 6 and 8 with a verse in between have a spacey and driving atmosphere. the waning and bending of the lead synth and slide guitar give a really cool sense of unease. it is still high in emotion but not the blatant sadness it was before. it all ends part 9 on a slow note with the synth playing a whimpering solo. the instrumental just trudges along giving it all an air of dejected acceptance. the major chord at the very end has a sweet optimism like it just remembered that it is making a tribute to the man not just lamenting his loss. overall this is sort of an uneven album. even though the two lesser songs only take up under a third of the record it feels like it is more. the decision to split shine on you crazy diamond in two was a controversial one within the band but because it was too long to fit on one side it had to be done. i think it would have been better had it been all together as a continuos and concise piece. 3.55

excited from reviews and it being determined by the rym charts as 2nd greatest album of all i have to say this listening was one hell of a let down. welcome to the machine and have a cigar are songs i would never willingly spend my time on again. the shine on you crazy diamond complete set could absolutely be worse but i do not see how it would be more interesting than any other masterpieces in any aspect more than any album a band has made the previous decade of its original release. wish you were here reminds me of a bob dylan song in a way and i do not like bob dylan smuch but i do like that song and it is probably the best on the album. i may have missed something about the sound only being able to stream it on spotify and not get something lossless but nothing about its pace flow or rhythm really excite me or because me to feel anything torwards it and it probably does not help that i never really grew up listening to syd barrets music at all. anyways objectively i just cannot see how this is considered one of the best albums of all time by this world. to summarize if i had a choice to get a single of careful with that axe eugene vs. this entire lp for the same price at same condition i would probably have to go with the single.

this whole album is basically a collection of well thought out slow jam sessions with different instruments. i am not particularly fond of the hookclimax of the songs it is pretty cheesy at times. i do not know how to explain why i do not like it that much. it just does not feel like there is much to talk about. it is very barebones and boring in comparison to other pink floyd albums. i do like the transition from have a cigar to wish you were here a lot it is just so classic. the criticism of the music industry topic that takes up welcome to the machine and have a cigar has been done a million times maybe this album was one of the first to do it. shrug emoji

pretty solid album. out of the pink floyd albums i have heard it definitely sounds like the saddest which makes sense i guess because it is dedicated to syd. i feel like welcome to the machine was the low point. it just felt like it dragged a little to me. the title track is great and have a cigar is also pretty good. both parts of shine of you crazy diamond are good though i feel 6-9 also starts to drag a little towards the end. overall good album though i think the dark side of the moon is a little better.

the crazy diamond tracks are p cool. the multiple sections all flow into each other to make something cohesive. fucking obviously. i am just saying that i like it. and the title track is pretty emotional and shit. i do not know. i really do not have much to say about this album. how is this 5 of all time on this website? why do people like this shit so much? why do you like it so much al huh? part of rymasters volume one i journey through alrogs top 100 albums abandoned

first one absolutely bangs. fucking pure james caan showdown in thief vibes. vocals come in late and nearly ruin the whole thing. cannot hack pink floyd lyricsvocals. takes me out of it. they will have some really ahead of their time instrumentally sound going on and then yer da comes in and ruins it chatting about stupid shite on the vocals again. second has some interesting synths going on but once again more vocals. we do not need them! this whole thing though is a lot more musically interesting than i remember. have a cigar sounds like one of the generic background rock tunes they did on the wall. it does not do all that much for me. it is not terrible by an means just kind of there. wish you were here is a classic of course. a little cringey and overplayed. it comes like that family campfire song but it is kind of nice so i will allow it. final tracks kind of like the first but not as good. has like a funky section though that almost becomes dudes rock but is ruined by that absolute dad just going shine on you crazy diamond. just shut up and make it instrumental.

wish you were here by pink floyd is the album proceeding the dark side of the moon an album which had smashed the charts. like dsotm the album flows very coherently even more perfectly than it is predecessor in fact. it is low number of longer songs aids this aspect of the album. another way in which this album is superior to the dark side of the moon is in it is greater humanity. shine on you crazy diamond and the title track wish you were here are both relieving suites of sympathy to hear after the psychedelicprog abstract exercises in the likes of dsotm and meddle. final verdict 710 will listen to on occasion 3.5 stars

i am absolutely mystified how a this could be classified as prog rock. with the endless plodding noodling it is closer to elevator music or smooth jazz. nothing progressive happens in any of the 45 minutes. how can this be in the same chart as can or even yes? b this lethargic yet surprisingly lightweight album could somehow garner so many 5-star ratings. you could argue there is greatness hiding in the details but there are hardly any details here. it is just one big fog of synths slowmotion guitars and dreary vocals. c people tell themselves that pf is somehow the greatest band in the history of popular music. if this album is part of the argument you may as well say the dire straits are the greatest apparently the majority loves soulless virtuosos. 1 star for the cover which is a classic.

i had always heard the middle three songs on this album and they never impressed me much. welcome to the machine is awful to listen to. wish you were here is boring depressing guitar strumming...perhaps i need to listen to the lyrics more to appreciate it but i really do not want to hear it again. have a cigar was the best of the three with it is funkiness but still i guess it was not enough to win me over. then one day like around 2014 i heard the first 5 parts of soycd on the radio. i did not even know what it was but i was intrigued by the ambient slow lead in. once those chiming guitar notes finally kicked in i realized i must be hearing floyd. the song resonated well with me so i bought it for that. i hesitate giving the album a 3 because i really do like those first 5 parts but i really really do not want to hear the rest. actually i have not given parts 6-9 their due. maybe i should try harder on those sometime. might bump it up to a 3.5?

regrouping after the massive success of dark side of the moon waters steered the band in the direction of a concept album about loss some of which would be explicitly about their friend and former bandmate syd barrett who eerily enough wandered into the studio during the sessions looking completely unrecognizable. i have encountered a large amount of people in my life who cite this as superior to dark side of the moon many even proclaiming it to be their favorite floyd record. for me it suffers from what i would call abbey road syndrome the production is pristine and the playing is top notch but the album fails to move or enthrall me on the whole. side one is stellar with the exquisite shine on... suite and the harrowing analog synth-fest welcome to the machine. side two becomes more ordinary for me with the funky record industry dig have a cigar sung by roy harper and the relatively mor title track probably the most mainstream song the band ever committed to tape. where is my lighter? by that point i am checked out so much that i barely notice the last four sections of shine on... which are fairly inessential. so while i appreciate the artistry of wish you were here it fails to gel for me as a whole. absolutely brilliant album cover though. owned as part of the discovery box set.

concept album - pretentious melancholic -  dreary serious - boring predictable atmospheric - reminds me of a storm cloud i suppose complex - it is complex trying to determine why people like this album meditative - really really boring satiric - parodying better artists and their earlier selves eclectic - literally the exact opposite of eclectic
gay and moody. comfortable to listen to but dull and bleak. nothing is surprising.

there was a distinct period in my life where at the discovery of any band or film or public figure that predated me i would talk about it to those older than me as if they know precisely who or what i am talking about then balk as soon as they inevitably reveal that hey they do not know what this little shit is prattling on about. in other words anything that influenced pop culture before 1992 was something i assumed all people who too existed before 1992 would have some memory or tied-affiliation with simply because the one thing they both share is to have been in a pre-vito genovese world. if you are still not following it is my fault i am rusty at this whole reviewing thing and to be honest i chose wish you were here as the album to warmup on because well it really is not terribly important. i will go on about that more once i drive my point home with an example at a cousins birthday dinner in what i assume was the middle of 2006 i had shine on you crazy diamond parts i-v on a cd that was blaring through my player and amidst the smell of fajitas and garlic-laden salsa i walked awkwardly over to my aunt and tried to be cool. remember this song? i said like the little shit i was. she took a headphone and put it gingerly to her ear a smile on her face as if trying to be amiable where in all honesty i would not have blamed her if she was counting the seconds til i walked away. i do not know it she said cheerily. who is it? i acted incredulous before returning to my seat. i have used wish you were here as less of an album but more of a tool to somehow tout how musically superior i was to the other eighth graders. this was of course after renouncing the likes of fall out boy and yellowcard in front of everybody but somehow plugging my ears at the objection that i still liked panic! at the disco. i would say no! i would say pink floyd is my favorite band! and i would don a black cap with the famed the dark side of the moon prism in its center. that was one of two albums that i actually truly loved by pink floyd at that point the other being the astounding and fan-affirming animals. but besides those two? pink floyd was my vessel for musical egotism and wish you were here was the ultimate i do not get it but i am going to pretend i do cd in my at-that-time eighty album library. i acted like everybody should know the full obnoxiously-tracked shine on you crazy diamond completely oblivious to the fact that i did not really care for it. i mean alright... once that signature guitar sounds off i sort of melt. but just how much bullshit surrounds that little beaut of a moment? too much i say. there is very little interesting going on in either of the bookending tunes and the meat in the middle is just a day shy of sour. okay so maybe that is not really true there are no bad tracks on wish you were here and everything here at least scores a three-star stamp but i will be damned if this record does not try my patience. take for example welcome to the machine a slab of progressive rock that has been bafflingly covered more than any other individual pink floyd track no discernible tune or point of accessibility to flock to and yet the masses laud it. i remember thinking it was wonderfully creepy at its time of personal inception but beyond that? i probably thought i loved it but it is not the next opus of beethoven. perhaps my favorite bit on the entire album is that strange drop in fidelity as have a cigar loses four-fifths of its decibels bleeding into the acoustic strum of the title track. wish you were here the song? a song i will say i admire greatly though my origins in admitting that have always felt more out of respect or like i had to like it because it was so iconic. i can say that my allegiance to it before has prospered into something true at least. i do not think it matters as to how i bend this wish you were here is an album that i am destined never to love by a band that i will always love and have come to know beyond their 1973 and 1977 output. if there was any act that i would boast to seeing live should such a thing ever become possible again pink floyd would be it and i would probably name the songs from this release most fervently when recounting the setlist to some jealous friend. nevertheless it is not lost on me. it is an album that could never ever be cooler than its sleeve but it is a fun and occasional spin.

more music for bank managers from everybody favourite corporate cock suckers this time with the added bonus of containing the same track twice and marginally rescued by having the jokey playful if a little ungracious have a cigar which almost amounts to a song by these guys standards although stick it on any of the truly great albums made in 74 court and spark good old boys sheet music propaganda and it would be filler at best. another insipid lazy inconsequential effort by the floyd. oh and the title track is a monumentally dull piece of songwriting.

lt1 bang in the middle wish you were here has what is possibly pink floyds best three song run in their entire career. not only is it a fantastic display of their prowess as composers with some of their most well structured material even if it might not feature such iconic riffs as on other releases but it also serves as a rough guide through all the strengths that they have accumulated over time with welcome to the machine showcasing their skill with dynamics have a cigar exhibiting their knack for neat grooves and wish you were here a very good example of pink floyds symbiotic relationship with their production job. in all these instances they are at the best of their game or close. i would not be surprised if the original intention here were to essentially celebrate what had become of pink floyds sound by this point so rather than pushing themselves forward they would have merely had to hone their skills a bit see what could be improved in their previous releases and make improved versions of the sound they are famous for. for instance have a cigar is almost like a corrected version of money in which they let ideas sink in rather than rushing into the solo and not letting the solo get out of hand once they reach it. overall this bout of recycling old ideas results in a very focused controlled and fluid but also exciting middle of the album. this is pink floyd at their best and a stepping stone towards the constant flow from song to song without losing momentum that they managed to get in the wall. sadly the two bookends do not share the same merits. for one thing they seemingly could not decide on a mood they begun by foreshadowing this grandiose beginning with a really extended fade in on pads and guitar but then when that is done we are sent right into a mellow jam session of sorts in which pf get the chance to drown everyone in vapid and inconsequential soloing. admittedly they do decide to stick to the mellower tone even on the second half of the suite but by that point the album should at least be hinting at its intention to end just sticking to the mellow vibes sounds really jarring at least on a first listen. for another thing the fact that it was decided to make a suite of several parts that is permeated with sprawling solos means that the progression of the song is fucked. by the time we reach the verse it is too late the momentum from the beginning is gone so it would be necessary to actually make some sort of buildup to the verse. and the verse itself although it works well without all the clutter that precedes it in the song itself it just sounds like pf are in a real hurry to get to the climax. once that is all done there is also a rather aggravating sax solo. and the song goes like this the whole time jumping from useless solo to useless solo wasting everyone is time and ruining what could have been a classic album or at least a classic ep.

que esperar despus de haber creado una obra definitoria?. para muchos fans wish you were here es su disco favorito de floyd y mejor que su legendario lbum previo. para muchos pero no para m. o sea de hecho que es interesante que no se hayan repetido y hayan creado un album mas centrado en atmsferas y texturas flotantes de teclado inspirado liricamente y conceptualmente por el recuerdo de syd barrett el loco diamante. pero el recordar la exuberancia de the dark side of the moon hace que en comparacin este disco me parezca muy bueno aunque menor a aquel welcome to the machine nunca me gust debo admitir. de hecho que siempre es agradable volver a oir aquella oda al fin de la inocencia que es shine on you crazy diamond y el hermoso tema que le da ttulo al album. notable.

this is probably one of the better pink floyd albums in that it does not have long stretches of pointless noodling and the dark musings actually have a purpose and story this time it is largely a lament for syd barrett. i do not think anything here does reach the heights of the dark side of the moon but it is more consistent as a whole and of course the album artwork is awesome. i do feel like side two is a bit more meandering than it needs to be but when does pink floyd not have some meandering stretches? a very good album and the one that made me understand their appeal entirely -- not to say that it necessarily turned me onto them.

this is pink floyds best album tied with the wall although i have not heard all of them so i am speaking only about the five i have heard. heard best through a giant speaker this album starts with an ambient fade-in one of musics best album opening sounds. after some slightly meanering psuedo-classical music the lyrics start at over eight minutes in. and what uplifting lyrics they are despite the knowledge that syd barret was locked up in a mental home somewhere when the album was released now dead. after some saxaphone there is a flawless cross-fade into welcome to the machine and a complete change of mood. the songs starts with the sound of an electric door and a large ceiling-fan and then the haunting guitar starts followed by david gimours scathing vocals singing of the music industry and a young teenager who thinks he is rebelling you bought a guitar to punish your ma but is actually conforming with what the music industry wants it is alright we told you what to dream. the mood of this song is quite negative but brilliant and slightly scary. side two of vynil begins with have a cigar another change in mood. it talks of the formation of the band and a music salesman talks to a young syd barret cluelessly asking which ones pink?. although the music is unremarkable it features the brilliant guest vocalist roy harper who is better than either gilmour or waters at singing and brings a slightly humrous tone to the song. after a bit of prog rock meandering not much the song is only five miniutes there is a whizz which takes us into the title track. wish you were here is one of those songs which brings a tear to the eye and is one of pink floyds most emotional songs. better than the vocals though is the lovley simple acoustic guitar more touching than any heavy metal from dream theater could ever be in it is gourgeous simplicity. it is the only time pink floyd ever embraced the principal less is more of course being progressive rockers they would not be likely to take on this principal. after some wind comes the only true disapointment of the album crazy diamond part two. the thing that made part one great was the ambient fade in the novelty and the fact it was the opening track. the mood just dosent work as a closer. of course the vocals still shine and the funerel march of part ix is good but a disapointment after four groundbreaking songs.
welcome to...machine.
overrated in extreme 75100 inmensamente sobrevalorado

i was pleasantly surprised when i had a re-listen to the dark side of the moon a week ago. i had some preconceptions about it but i loved it -- it had a great musical flow and balance between experimentation and pop and it is one of there rare pop albums that really has something to say about the conditio humana. so i was looking forward to this one -- which however turned out to be pretty much how i originally feared pink floyd would be. musically it is all nice and spacey and proggy and complexly layered stuff -- but what else is there to the music? when it is nice and beautiful it is tends to be overly long and boring and even lounge-y after a while they got it right on wish you were here though. when it starts getting interesting they kill the song with an extremely annoying 70s synth solo welcome to the machine which they never did on dsotm. if only the lyrics would have been half as great as on dark side! here you get two esoteric rants about the music industry and the rest is supposed to be about the band missing syd barrett so much. they did that one on dark side too eclipse and it feels more genuine there than filling three quarters of an album with that stuff here. especially considering that to my knowledge nobody of the band even went to visit him since he had left. i know i am a little harsh here. it is not a bad album per se and there is some good stuff to be found here. but i just cannot understand why this album has the same standing as dark side of the moon. the most interesting thing about this album is the great cover which i never realized actually is a real photograph -- and reading up on this weird story when barrett suddenly turned up in the studio during the final recording of shine on you crazy diamond with nobody recognizing him at first source in 1975 a strange reunion took place at emi studios attributable jerry shirley feels to syds uncanny sixth sense of timing. the last time i saw him was possibly the last time the guys in the floyd saw him too. they were putting the finishing touches on wish you were here. earlier that day dave gilmour had gotten married and they had to work that night so emi had this roundtable dinner in the canteen for them. across the table from me was this overweight hare krishna-looking chap. i thought maybe it was just someone who somebody knows. i looked at dave and he smiled then i realized it was syd. the guy had to weigh close to 200 pounds and had no hair on his head. it was a bit of a shock but after a minute i plucked up enough courage to say hello. i introduced my wife and i do not know i think he just laughed. i asked him what he was doing lately. oh you know not much eating sleeping. i get up eat go for a walk sleep. that night the band finished the album and were playing back the final mix of shine on you crazy diamond. when the song ended roger waters turned to syd and said well syd what do you think of that ? he said sounds a bit old. i am all with syd on that one.

general golden age pink floyd bullshit. great instrumentation great song structures great solos great song writing. everything a pink floyd album needs. but it sort of falls to the wayside when you have these things and staying power like animals and the wall. this is a great album not an amazing album.
i do not get why this is such a great album -
a bizarre collection of aimless jams interspersed with revelational moments of beauty on occasion.
easy reviewanimal
much ado for.....would not say nothing but in my opinion comes at a time of lack of ideas and is a bit confused....understandable after the dark side

wish you were here is pink floyds best album without question. as a song cycle it is their most cohesive collection of tracks. in addition they perfectly fuse their propensity for psychedelic andor progressive-rock ambiance shine on you crazy diamond with strong pop hooks have a cigar and wish you were here. while it is probably easier to read this albums lyrics as once again a cautionary tale about their fallen ex-leader syd barrett a theme also present on dark side of the moon and the wall it is more instructive to think of roger waters lyrics as examining the trappings of fame both positive and negative. once again richard wright is the secret weapon creating the shimmering atmosphere atop which david gilmours masterful leads float. with the cliched welcome to the machine as the only misstep wish you were here remains both the most consistent and best-executed of pink floyds long-players.

this album is generally moodier and more multifaceted than anything else in pink floyds catalog. wish you were here is experimental without taxing its listener with dives into lazy prog which for floyd usually means some odd audio clips played through spacey sounding guitars. i am really talking about dark side... here. anywho the title track is the highlight of the album but the whole thing feels very emotional and occasionally moving.
wish this was piper at the gates of dawn.

i listened to this to death when i was in my early teen years. so much so that i never thought i would ever want to hear it again but lately i have been getting into jazz music which has re-awakened my love for music in general. so while i am feeling like this i decided to listen to some old favorites to see if they held up over time or not. this album holds up now i do not think it is great or anything but i enjoyed the album. i think there is too much noodling around on the synthesizers but that is mainly just on shine on you crazy diamond 1-5. have a cigar and welcome to the machine both sound good after all these years. which brings us to the title track wish you were here. this is one of pink floyds best songs and it really sounds great after not hearing it for twenty-odd years. i have played it a few times and i cannot get over how great it sounds. alas it was the only song that struck me like that but i definitely think that this is a very good album and i would recommend it to all music lovers. everywhere. check it out.

i have these great memories of riding along in my friend graysons moms station wagon. we had great tapes! we had pavement and the beach boys and cat stevens ... we would drive around looking for trouble and cheap food... guided by voices and the pixies beat happening and ... what is this... can you change this? okay i will give it some more time... hey can i pick the next tape? reminds me of having to pay for the pizza every time.

this is my second attempt at writing a scathing review of this hugely overrated bloated monster. the first one mysteriously disappeared but i will be heard! the only thing i can remember about my previous review was it began like this look ma the emperors got no clothes! i am calling this album out it is useless. fifth best album of all time my rosy behind! it is a sad tedious bitter trudge through a slowed down cod-blues. i like the floyd check my other reviews but this one seems to me to carry the scars of trying to follow up dark side of the moon. they do not know what they want to do. shine on you crazy diamond is about syd of course and the lyrics are quite touching but musically it is a slow dawdle through a bunch of solos. have a cigar is waters first i-hate-the-music-biz song unless that is actually welcome to the machine and wish you were here contains the earliest reference i am aware of to the war which ultimately takes us to the final cut an album which is worse than this one but not as boring. shine on parts 6-9 actually sound better at 45 and they are over quicker. i honestly cannot see what people like about this record.

a pretty solid album but not on par with the dark side of the moon and meddle this probably contains the most classic rock favorites along with the wall. welcome to the machine have a cigar wish you were here are all played on the radio quite a bit. not my favorite floyd album and the synthesizers do get a bit annoying at times.

si trova qui la sintesi di tutto ci che non mi piace dei pink floyd brani allungati a dismisura che meriterebbero massimo 5 minuti canto lagnosissimo canzoni sinceramente ruffiane ed unatmosfera di fondo al confine tra tanti generi ma che non ne richiama nessuno. e di sicuro un capolavoro di stile e tecnica e produzione ma nella lunga suite che copre pi di met album non trovo molto di pi degli elementi che ho descritto sopra n nessuno spunto davvero degno di interesse. welcome to the machine il brano pi interessante apre una tematica che verr poi sviluppata nel successivo animals. la title track ovviamente  un brano pallido ed inconsistente. e un album francamente noioso perch rarefatto che la classe dei musicisti non riesce appieno a salvare.
it must be good because i am so sick of it i never want to hear it again. they were never as good without syd.

2.6 believe me it pains me that one of the most over rated albums of all time was made by my favorite band. i do not even want to ask people what their favorite pink floyd album is anymore for fear that this album is their answer. from the craziness of atom heart mother ummagumma and meddle. to the more refined sound of dsotm and animals thre are so many great pink floyd albums out there. yet this is the one that everybody likes. it is comparable to the division bell it is so watered-down and un-floydian.
at least it is a little bit better than dark side of the moon. mostly due to wish you were here the song if they had done more of such songs i would probably like them more.
tecnicamente brillante ma emotivamente freddo.

proof that the fanatic is the worst source of information possible. bands whose music is quietly and infrequently admitted to be good music are usually good bands and have made good music. bands with thousands of fanatics are just that - fanatic breeders. they are like opium whose popularity obliterates all order and thinking and submits one to being a fan. that is how pink floyd works. this is okay music but with very few intelligent ideas to offer. it is almost like a collage for the ability of some skilled musicians to play well in unison. it gives prog-rock a bad name.

worth owning for the title track and shine on you pt1-5. the rest is pretty standard prog fare lightened as was to become more and more the case by gilmours melodic guitar touches and some nice keys by wright. frankly i could live quite happily if i never heard welcome... and have a ever again.

i like this wish you were here more than dark side of the moon but only by about half a quark so i will give them the same score. it is basically easy listening with a bit of a bite and some pretty alright lyrics.
some good stuff but a comedown from the dark side of the moon.

all there tribute to syd barrett shine on you crazy diamond these days remains one and only my favourite song by pink floyd remember when you were young you shone like the sun. now there is a look in your eyes like black holes in the sky title song wish you were here i like pretty much too so you think you can tell heaven from hell blue skies from pain... though now these words do not seem to me as clever as they used to now they look no more than a trite truism. welcome to the machine and have a cigar sound to me now like a dump of outworn noises and the album in its entirety is a bit tedious.

so according to rym this is one of the best pink floyd albums and even more one of the best records of all time. well well well. starting a review like this usually means the writers going to crush the album for the rest of the review. well that is partially true. but only partially. i understand the whole emotion surrounding this album  the title alone is quite self-explanatory. wish you were here. you would expect sadness and nostalgia as the records main themes and minor chords all around. call me insensitive but while i absolutely feel all this on the two best tracks shine on you crazy diamond pts. 1-5 and wish you were here i think that in the other tracks they were just trying too hard and never really manage to reach that. what do you have then ? standard progressive rock that is for sure with end-of-the-world epic atmosphere loads of cheesy sounds from outer space i mean 70s outer space and pretty lame vocals too what happened here ?. not exactly my favorite music recipe. have a cigar then ? no thanks.

the only real genius i have ever found to pink floyd was their ability to so-perfectly synch the dark side of the moon up with the wizard of oz. it is really a shame they did not sequence wish you were here to work as a soundtrack for gone with the wind or some such something. would have been another feather in their collective cap as far as i am concerned. that said i can listen to this album in its entirety something i cannot dream of doing with the snooze-inducing wall. david gilmour - vocals guitar nick mason - drums richard wright - keyboards vocals roger waters - vocals bass guitar produced by pink floyd 1975 columbia records jc 33453 highs - it is not the wall lows - it is not the wizard of oz like this go for you would be much better off with porcupine tree than anything else from this bunch acquired some time at some place originally reviewed 07 august 2005 2486988 oongawad 03 december 2007 12536176

good songsshine on you crazy diamond pts.1-5 have a cigar wish you were here bad songsshine on you crazy diamond pts.6-9 welcome to the machine now my gripe with this album is thefinal song was not good at all and the packaging of the cd itself was absolute shit.

wish you were here a concept album released in 1975 explores the ideas of absence the music business and the rise and fall of original pink floyd member syd barrett. the conceptual angle was composed by roger waters so its aspects especially those involving barrett are of a deeply personal nature. unlike it is predecessor dark side of the moon wish you were here handles its critiques in a straight-forward manner. while dark side of the moon employs a more subtle over-arching approach time explores the modern perception of reality money deals with materialism for example wywh and its follow-up 1977s animals are more specific the latter even references an actual person hey you whitehouse. ha ha charade you are referring to morality crusader mary whitehouse. that being said the focus of wish you were here is primarily on the business side of the music industry and its negative effects with barrett serving as a lens into the concept. the extended and separated multi-movement piece shine on you crazy diamond is directly related to sid while welcome to the machine and have a cigar focus on the industry. the title track sees waters exploring his personal feelings regarding syd and also it appears to me his feelings toward the music business. shine on you crazy diamond i-v opens with an elegiac air as horn-like keys move throughout the constant pulse of wrights synthesizer serving as a fitting introduction to the extended piece about barrett. it is joined by gilmours shimmering almost too bluesy tone which rounds out the intro. at the 400 mark gilmours spaced-out meant physically and descriptively 4-note lick sets a haunting quality before the song launches into full-floydian force as the rest of the group joins. i love the guitar tone but gilmours playing always leaves me wanting more for every cosmic lick there is 2 out-and-out blues licks. it is as if the bluesy nature of his playing makes it sound too generic or grounded. not that his playing is generic but that blues-influenced players are more than a dime a dozen it takes away from the otherworldliness. always adding to the otherworldliness though are waterss ghostly vocals. they are slightly mad which is especially fitting as he sings of syd remember when you were young you shone like the sun. shine on you crazy diamond. now there is a look in your eyes like black holes in the sky. shine on you crazy diamond.  a now the saxophone. it is not so bad i guess the counter play with the guitar helps but i can do without it. it has nothing to do with this song in particular but it is a personal quirk of mine i just do not particularly like the sound of the saxophone in rock-oriented music and never have. in this case it is like it takes me from an outer space psych ward into a new orleans speakeasy which i guess is not such trip up for some people. welcome to the machine takes the story away from sid though he is still a part of it and brings the focus onto the greediness of the music industry. the song opens with the pulsing of machines. it is static save for intermittent buzzing and remains totally inorganic throughout--the exception being the well-placed sweetly human strums of the acoustic guitar. even gilmours vocals have a robotic orwellian quality to them as he belts out welcome my son welcome to the machine. what did you dream? it is alright we told you what to dream. you dreamed of a big star he played a mean guitar he always ate in the steak bar. he loved to drive in his jaguar. so welcome to the machine.  these lyrics are especially important because they refer to the manufacturing of the rock star image by record companies and the fabrication of rebellion glamour and whatever else comes along with stardom or listening to such and such music. waterss simple yet alien bass keeps the listener on edge unable to relax or to be soothed by the guitar and string patches. this is especially true in the welcome to the machine refrain. the song does not do much overall which fits with it is mechanized nature but clocking in at 7 minutes it can get boring depending on my mood. welcome to the machine ends with a closing door and what sounds like and unlike a car speeding. this is followed by the sounds of a party signifying fakephony people which fades out thus ending side 1. the second side opens with have a cigar the ever-present pink floyd rocker that seems to find its way at least once on every record since meddle. in this case it almost serves as this albums answer to money. this tune featuring guest vocals from roy harper points to the phoniness of industry players and of people in general as these lyrics exhibit well i have always had a deep respect and i mean that most sincerely. the band is just fantastic that is really what i think. oh by the way which ones pink? and did we tell you the name of the game boy we call it riding the gravy train.  despite it is money-like bluesboogie elements i find this song to fit better than the aforementioned does on dark side of the moon. like money the bluesy swagger of have a cigar is used to enhance the concept. i understand the role of money but damn i do not like that song. i do not necessarily like this track either but i do not dislike it i appreciate it is role as a part of the whole. the raunchy decadence of have a cigar its personal nature and wrights thick layers of keyboards probably make it less distracting. it is also a lot more scathing lyrically and musically while i find money to be too happy-go-lucky. the song ends as gilmours solo cuts out to a distant radio sound as it flows into the title track. wish you were here begins with the changing of the dial in a car radio before the song itself begins still in the distance. the loudly plucked acoustic lead jars this subdued atmosphere and i would have to say that is the songs most interesting part. it is a relatively straight-forward composition overall in which nothing really of interest happens until the blowing wind at the end. this strengthens the theme of abandonment and leads into the final segments of shine on you crazy diamond. part vi adds to the wind and ominous feel to the abandonment like fast approaching black clouds on an otherwise empty desert horizon. the bass line is similar to that of welcome to the machine in execution and atmosphere and gilmours jagged guitar stabs like a knife. as the song progresses the keys and gilmours rapid staccato picking work in the higher registers giving it a sense of frantic urgency. near the end wright plays the clavinet which gives it an awkward funky feel that is not entire out of place yet that does not entirely fit either. it is almost bizarre enough to seem right. the final minutes recall the elegiac opening but in a more celebratory fashion before fading meditatively to a close. as with all far-reaching concept albums all elements of the album contribute to the themes. music and lyrics should be obvious but an often overlooked aspect is that of the album art. the sticker on the album sleeve features two mechanical hands locked in a formal handshake. the robotic nature of the art points to the gesture as a routine and for that reason usually empty. similarly the cover itself examines the handshake. this time we have two businessmen shaking hands with one of them on fire read getting burned. the back cover extends the commentary on the impersonal greedy nature of business as a faceless empty-suit no wrists and ankles floyd salesman peddles his wares in the desert the ultimate irony being that the group themselves are a part of the machine. but let this reflective bit of music show that riding the gravy train is not all it is cracked up to be. as many who come into fame success or money find out paper is not the answer and it leaves people burnt out andor spiritually malnourished.

this album was all a bit too spacey and experimental for me. do not get me wrong i love experimental rock in all it is weird and wonderful forms its just that this album is extremely inconsistent apart from the absolutely outstanding wish you were here which is one of the best songs ever.

an overrated album not by far their best like is praised all the time . is so much great music to descover from the 70s that is hard for me to listen more than twice a year this album. is not a bad album that is no doubt but to me is almost boring. shine one crazy diamond part i is stunning very smooth and is clear that the members are very talented but have a cigar is a mediocre piece the other tracks are so so. this album has an istorical importance to many  no doubt pink floyd is one of the major influence in music but to me is an overrated band that does not mean i under appreciate thier talent and creativity throgh the years. so a 3 star album for me the next one animals is much better and is my favourite floyd album

sigue sonando muy bien quizs mejor de lo que en realidad es. suficiente para poder disfrutar de l porque esa ha sido siempre la ventaja de pink floyd ms all de sus ambiciones sus discos son siempre inmediatamente disfrutables y fciles de asimilar. el disco cae en clichs de todo tipo pero no tiene desperdicio shine on you crazy diamond es el mejor ejemplo pieza de 25 minutos que mezcla guitarras blues con pasajes csmicos y una cancin medio gospel sin ninguna explicacin. absurdo pero siempre entretenido y bien tocado. welcome to the machine parte de un tpico trillado pero lo conduce con un dramatismo vvido y creble. wish you were here es una balada que representa a la vez la falta de principios del grupo y su alta calidad compositiva. slamente fracasa have a cigar el equivalente inspido de money.
nada imposible que no le veo la puta gracia a pink floyd por ninguna parte.
shine on you is not a bad tune but soooo repetitive and morose. radically over rated 8th best album of all time? no way jose!
