so i have heard this is one album any fan of pink floyd needs to listen too? well i am a half and half fan i like the progressive rock era meddle etc. but i dislike parts of their back catalogue. oh well the proof is in the pudding as it were i best have a listen before i judge it. the album starts of with the song shine on you crazy diamond pts. 1-5 which i have heard is most famous pink floyd songs among with many others of course. the song itself is starts of with an almost atmospheric introduction before moving onto a bluesy solo. to be fair the whole song is bordering on progressive rock featuring blues mind you i do not really care it sounds great. the album then progresses onto welcome to the machine which is probably my least favourite on the album it is alright but as i see it it is a filler track. but with that it does contain some eerie synths on it maybe to play homage to the psychedelic era of floyds history? next is the song have a cigar is in pretty much the same vein as the rest of the album bluesy rock. after that it comes to one of the most famous pink floyd songs wish you were here. maybe it is just me but i like it but i do not think it defines the band as much as other songs. it is a ballad-sque song with soft humble notes threw out. well worth listening too but like i said i do not care for it much. the album closes on the rest of the parts to the song shine on you crazy diamond. a great closing song to a great album. on a whole the album contains some of pink floyds most memorable tracks and probably to many fans their favourite. in summary i thought i would dislike this album but on the positive side i do actually like it. the album features some classic pink floyd album. it shows more depth to pink floyd good song writing various different playing techniques. recommended.

oh gawd look what is landed on my lap as part of the go review that album game. well the easy bit ... how i came to own wish you were here ... it is my boyfriends so when i moved in and our collections merged the number of pf albums i owned doubled. i think i can also say with confidence that he has not listened to it once in the 27 months that i have been living here. i am really not a fan. when i was at school quite a few of the boys owned all the 70s pf albums and most of them who did were the ones with the biggest loudest hi-fi systems. i was at a boarding school and the walls were thin so you could guarantee to hear pf every single day. if you were really unlucky and your room was next door to a noisy masturbater you would get to hear that every day too. i had a cassette player with an ear-piece instead of headphones and was mainly listening to fleetwood mac bob dylan and lou reed and to be perfectly honest found pf really rather boring. my lack of pf albums had caught the attention of almost everyone who had ever perused my music collection. i would also had a previous and mercifully short-lived relationship with someone who pf were their favourite band and my lack of their stuff was viewed with a certain amount of snobby disdain. in order to prove that i was in fact open minded and willing to give anything a go i bought the latest pf album on the market - the division bell. funny thing was even this ardent they can do no wrong and are the best band in the universe fan soon to be ex-boyfriend of mine reluctantly admitted that this particular album was not quite on a par with their earlier stuff. i thought it had one good song on and the rest was cack. this is roughly what i think about wywh only i would add an extra word to the description ... i think it has one good song on it and the rest is proggy cack. the firstlast song just goes on and on forever the next two are unbelievably average and instantly forgettable 70s numbers and the title track has been so etched onto my brain over the past 35 years giving me no chance to dislike it because if i did i would have to go and live on the dark side of the moon ha bloody ha in order to not have to hear it ever again. so on the plus side? it has some groovy artwork. it is kind of hard to dis one of the most popular albums ever but i have done it before do people really honestly truely think forever changes is that good? give me a break it is a complete load of shit! and if asked i will probably do it again. a generous 1.

looking for your next investigation into boring uneventful music that you are supposed to love? if you have not heard this yet you are missing out! yadda yadda wish you were here is great yadda yadda blah welcome to the machine is pretty cool yep yep yadda oky doke. enjoy.

the eponymous track is one of my favourite songs from the band but i cannot really see what else can be loved on this album so much. there is hardly anything but endless epic synth solos sometimes supported by guitar virtuosity and as i am listening they just do not really go anywhere they do not have any intentions. maybe if i considered this as an ambient record it would make sense but it simply does not have the spirit for that either.
same problem as the dark side of the moon only more so. a it is rather slow and boring sometimes b i do not have the patience to appreciate its true brilliance. you choose which.

prog rock is in fashion now. how else could it be that an album that only consists of five songs most of them heavily overlengthy is currently rated 4.28 by 36841 people on rym edit updated 12 october 2019? the number would make sense if sgt. peppers lonely hearts club band was rated by even more numerous thousands of rymers but as we know it is not. and what about the average rating? do you really think it is absolutely that good? i consider it more like fashion  or a scientific paradigm as long as it is valid or reliable to hold wish you were here in a high position thousands of people do so. 1973 was to prog what 1967 was to psych. beside the dark side of the moon by pink floyd tubular bells by mike oldfield became a worldwide smash and as i have noted elsewhere that was when progressive  as a musical attribute  lost its connection to the socio-spiritual progress. a couple of years later pink floyd released wish you were here including almost 26 minutes divided into two tracks of a giant epic called shine on you crazy diamond. listening to the first part it takes over four minutes before the drums appear and again more than four minutes before vocals appear. i claim this was floyds own tubular bells. and of course this means  i am sorry mike o you did better with your pop songs!  that the 1975 incarnation of pink floyd had lost some of the progress within. this was not their first time ummagumma and atom heart mother in particular were slightly regressive rock records. lyrically crazy diamond is positive about the mental adventures of syd barrett but at the same time it seals the fact that after syds departure in the circle of pink floyd those adventures were going to be over. musically i think the latter part of crazy diamond may be even better than the former. none of it is bad anyway. welcome to the machine is overlengthy and actually a bit useless. then comes have a cigar possibly a link between time and the more rhythmic fragments on the wall. a nice track. the title song is a worthwhile classic of course. but that is all. except a few interesting pieces of cover art. so wish you were here is not a bad album. unlike the first two velvet underground albums it is real music. one two or even four of the five songs could be part of an excellent package like the dark side of the moon but hopefully not in a pompously overlengthy form. none of the tracks is plain bad in fact the album is quite good of course but come on is this really modern music at its most essential?

the two part title song is so relaxed that i feel as if i have to lay down to listen to it. makes me wonder what kind of drugs they were taking when they made this that caused them to be this relaxed. acid? prozac? wish you were here is a great song. this one sounds as if they taped two different concept albums to one and other. one about syd barrett and a second one about how they hate the recording industry. despite the fact that they joined it voluntarily became rich because of it and could have probably left it if they really wanted to. roger waters always loved complaining. the second album has have a cigar and welcome to the machine on it. is nice but just not as good as the first one. r

neck-and-neck with animals for the title of best floyd album post-barrett. make what you will of that as it is coming from someone who normally cannot stand waters-fronted pink floyd. have a cigar is fantastic. the same cannot by any means be said of the title track. i also dig the first five parts of shine on rule of thumb boys when you have already made a song with five parts that is plenty. stop there.
not nearly as good as dark side of the moon. shine on meanders on and on and on...on both sides of the record. sandwiched in between the middle tracks are all excellent.
uno tra i pi ispirati e godibili album dei pink floyd.
i heard a few and this master sound gold sbm cd release of wish you were here sounds best .
this is the best floyd album i have heard and it still is very very weak. i am not a fan.

as i make my way through the great classics list. i come to pink floyds. wish you were here. i was slightly underwhelmed. respectfully i do appreciate what they were doing for the time. and hear the influences over many of the acts i love today. but really i did not see the reason for waiting so long to get to the beautiful part of shine on you crazy diamond. actually the end half i enjoyed more. welcome to the machine is indeed innovative but not all that pleasant to listen to. have a cigar is good and of course wish you were here is so classic and has such great lyrics what is not to like. by the way which ones pink?

best pink floyd album!? come on! while i would never expect any pink floyd albums to sound energetic except the one when they had that syd cat wish you were here is just a lazy effort. shine on you crazy diamond part 1-5 is pretty but it becomes quite tiresome after a couple of listens because the first half sounds so uninspired yes i mean gilmours solo. shine on you crazy diamond parts 6-9 is much more interesting than the first part because of all the crazy styles they try cram into the twelve minutes however it is still aimless. wish you were here is a unique country ballad for the floyd but unfortunately pink floyd cannot really compose a great country ballad. i have heard much better. wind sounds so lame on a record. so three songs are dedicated to good old syd rip but my final verdict on these three songs if you have not figured out by now they are kind of a snooze fest. my favorite song is have a cigar. silly lyrics and groovy composition with a nice use of the synthesizer this song is fun fun fun! i actually like roy harpers voice in this song as well as what i consider some of gilmours best guitar work on the album too bad one of his solos is interrupted by a strange radio fade-out or something. and too bad the lyrics of the song only retread the music industry sucks lyrics of the previous and inferior song welcome to the machine. it is an amusing song with a cute gimmick but like most of the songs on this record it gets old after after a while. did we really need two songs about the music industry? this review probably makes the album sound worse than what it really is. i really really like have a cigar and most of the other songs have their gorgeous moments the acoustic portion in the middle of the machinery sounds in welcome to the machine. there is just too much boring fluff in between. smoke a bowl and you can add one star to this review.

after the sprawling epic concept album the dark side of the moon pink floyd released the more accessible wish you were here which was an affectionate biograph of ex-member syd barrett. whatever you might think about floyd - pompous over-indulgent pretentious complex all of which can be levelled to some degree at this album - there is no denying their talent as musicians. so whilst you may become frustrated at the prolonged length of the songs that ability is capable of making you sit up and take notice at any time. there are only four songs included - the massive shine on you crazy diamond bookending the album - but in truth that is more than enough. gilmour has never played guitar better and waters lyrical and musical restraint makes a welcome change. crazy diamond when it kicks in reminiscent of the alien welcome in close encounters is a genuine rock classic welcome to the machine with its fuzzy electronic keyboards is boring have a cigar is an amusing take on the music business and wish you were here is a touching tribute to barrett. there is no doubt that this is an accomplished album which won the group a great deal of plaudits but for me there is something missing - maybe it is soul.
good but overrated.

wish you were here went from the bottom of my pink floyd pile to the very top. it is the only recording i have by them i deep good enough to listen to a lot. shine on you crazy diamond has everything going for it and i was listening to it in a very atmospheric mood and i was blown away. a great album that does not lose momentum and is bolstered by the fact that it is 5 songs long. if shine on you crazy diamond was turned into one song at the end like was originally planned this album would be demoted. it works as a bookend to the album and fits nicely unlike echos which while being artistically a great pink floyd achievement i found myself already drained by the time it came on. i never get the feeling that i could be listening to something with more instant gratification when i listen to this album. it is great and should stand out over time as their greatest achievement. syd would be proud.

one reason i do not like floyd is because they took away fantasy from prog rock and choose to follow instead a dull  boring and pop-ish style that made them superstars.albums like this and dark side are good because they managed to write good songsbut most of their catalogue is wellboring. i really love prog rock but i never really liked floyd.this album makes the exception because it is actually very emotional.

i like shine on you crazy diamond wish you were here is a good fm standard welcome to the machine is not that bad and have a cigar does not really suck. but i will never consider this as their greatest album nor as a great album nor as a very good one. in my opinion this is one of the most overrated albums in the history of music. i have tried a lot of times but i do not get the great thing here.
wish you were here and that one guitar line in shine on you crazy diamond are pretty great but...i mean....come on!
let us have this thing where one guy... this one businessman is shaking another businessmans hand but then the other businessman is engulfed in flame

shine on you crazy diamond and have a cigar are good but the former has little business lasting over 25 minutes. welcome to the machine is outright boring. wish you were here of course is one of the best songs ever.
middle three tracks are all great but the bookending jams are all that was wrong with pink floyd at the time. i must say that have a cigar is my single favorite floyd song from the post-syd era.
shine on you crazy diamond and wish you were here are excellent. total masterpieces. the other two are ok but i find myself skipping past them every time i listen to this album.

not as engaging as dark side of the moon and a bit less proggy. still quite solid and entertaining in doses. again certain radio stations have pf hours so even shine on you crazy diamond gets air time preventing the need to take up precious storage.
as the 70s went on pink floyd seemed to lose that edge this is a classic album with the title track obviously about the founder sid barrett.

the title tracks are the end result of the process begun on atom heart mother and what a sorry progression it is. also there is a sort of hollogrammy j-m jarre feel to them much of the time this is nothing particularly new see the first track of meddle but at least it has a few balls there. the terrible thing about it is that in some way it sort of does work.

i do not get why this album gets such good ratings generally. the first and last songs although they have some really good parts go on waaaaaaay too long. the second song sucks. the synths on it are down right embarrassing on that song not that it was really salvagable and they even threaten to ruin the title track. the third song does not suck but it is pretty boring. the title track on the other hand is pretty great. but really this has to be one of the most over-rated albums i have ever heard. just woefully dated and self-indulgent as hell.

have a cigar - a very good song i like it its ni...ce. welcome to the machine - never had a whole lot of use for this song it sounds like something that was made for a short animated film of demented robots from a different world not much here musically in my opinion. wish you were here - a great song classic one of my favorite floyd songs. i will continue to listen to it much. the next long window blog will explain the 3.5 rating which i believe this album deserves since i prefer - the wall animals and dsotm too this album. which by the looks of things makes me the minority on this site. shine on you crazy diamond parts 1 - 1000000 i think parts of this song are great first 4 minutes - needless setup next 2 minutes - kind of boring end of 7th minute - great guitar solo end of 8th minute - vocals hooray!! 11th minute - very cool sax solo 14-19th minute - getting very dramatic i guess this is were the acid would start to kick in had i taken some at the start of the song. 20-22nd minute - physcadelic music kicks in. again not on drugs so not doing much for me. 22-25th minute - ok the word dragging is really starting to apply. 26th minute - hey wait i think the song is ending wow! i made it all the way through without the aid of acid. with that being said i do not see this song ever making any mix cd playlists or me just putting it on i guess the whole 26 minute thing is just a little bit too much for me. that is why i give it a 3.5

i really like the core of the songs on this album but sometimes it seems to go off on what i can best describe as a musical tangent. but then again i am not on drugs. perhaps that would change my opinion...
great album

i blame this on classic rock radio. i spent my formative years listening to classic rock radio until i finally just got fed up with it. here is a radio format that covers about 20 years roughly 1965-1985 with a focus on the 70s at least when i was listening and has a playlist of approximately 12 songs. classic rock is about as close as our current corporate run radio empires have to the free-form aor formats that i have only heard legends of. classic rock radio is not tied to singles or current chart positions and could play whatever they like really. but they continue to play the same songs from pink floyd led zeppelin tom petty acdc and queen. why not add more artists to that playlist? why not even add more songs from the handful of artists they do play? why such a limited playlist? i know that as much as people like me bitch about the limited playlists the more the corporate machine tells us it is because that is really just the way we like it. welcome to the machine. this album contains four of the approximately 12 songs that classic rock radio stations play. i heard this album too many times even before i ever tried to listen to the full album. i am older wiser and about 15 years away from my classic rock radio days now. i think i am finally getting to the point where i can hear wish you were here without thinking not again! i like this album it is good but it is not the pink floyd album that i am going to reach for those would be dark side or animals. maybe in another five years or so i will come to love it. but being able to finally like it is a good start.

at the time this was released i thought it was a bit of a letdown after dsotm. i like the album all the songs are good and it is interesting production. it is just not hugely dynamic. it makes good music in the car on a long trip. on the other hand after all the years i have had a copy of it i still find myself listening to it.
the title track is as terrific a song as they come and the rest of it shares the same spacy yet not totally indulgent sound of its predecessor

while the title track is my original favorite floyd song and certainly my favorite gilmour floyd song the album itself lacks a certain energy to sustain it all the way through. this can be attributed to the fact that 23 of the album are taken up by the two movements of shine on you crazy diamond. it is not a bad epic at all and it probably is a pretty good tribute to the erratic late syd barrett. it moves in fits and starts accelerates and then languishes. i could have done with just the first part myself. i saw a documentary of the album where the members said the album was supposed to be in part a tribute to syd. when they showed up at the studio one day to record they encountered a guy with his head completely shaven eyebrows and all jumping up and down brushing his teeth! according to rick wright they asked someone who that was and were told it was syd barrett. that was met with melancholy by the members each of whom cherish barretts contribution and impact on the band. how this affected the album cannot be known. the shine on tribute moves awkwardly into the somewhat upbeat anti-industry tracks welcome to machine and have a cigar sung by roy harper. from there it shifts again to the very warm and personal feel of wish you were before finishing out with the last remnants of shine on. they are all good songs in and of themselves but it just does not all meld together the way dark side or animals does. it does however have one of the greatest album covers of all-time. on a personal note in my midwestern atypical fraternity house in the late 80s and early 90s oddly about 4 of the 12 residents owned this album. of course in this environment things get lost misplaced stolen etc. at one point we were all inexplicably missing this disc! thankfully i found mine.

sandwhiched between dsotm and animals wywh although sonically gorgeous pales in comparison to both. i always wondered why roy harper sang have a cigar it sounds like something waters should have done strange.

what the hell did i use to hear in this album that made me give it 4.5 stars as a teenager? relistening to this for the first time in 6 years or so i just think this is one of the dullest albums that i have ever heard save the title track. each song is at least twice as long as it should be again save the title track. going through my old ratings has been pretty eye-opening so far for me both in terms of what i continue to consider great music and what i no longer think is notable. pink floyd has taken a notable hit in my eyes. half the band my 16 year old self thought they were. i used to think this was a 4.5 star album!
pink floyd is about dark side of the moon. and animals. and then i suppose about atom heart mother. and then maybe just maybe about wish you were here.
i remember liking it. but i bought it and played it again a couple of times and it is just so ponderous.
it is not a bad album however i like dark side of the moon better because i think it manages to be experimental without being drawn out... as wish you were here can get.

wish you were here cemented pink floyds stature as stars of the mainstream singing for the people despite not being part of the people anymore. it is centerpiece was shine on you crazy diamond which signaled the return of the progressive rock epic divided in ten parts and split in two sides. getting underway with parts 1-5 the intro bridged their former space-rock with their current soft-jazz-rock via the form of the lush soundscape. this was not music to freak out it was music to relax. it continued with a typical jam all in all a more convincing effort than the previous the dark side of the moon where the progressive element was limited to it being a concept album. the main waters-ian verse one the psychodramas which made his name was presented in a blues-gospel guise. truth be told this was a new form of easy listening one with an intellectual and existential pretense. softness could now be justified. parts 6-9 were practically cut from the same cloth just following a reverse structure whereas a more energetic jam led to a reprise of the main verse which in turn led to a wright-ian soft-jazz funk exercise before it concluded with a more lugubrious theme that eventually scattered in cosmic dust. essentially even though this was a classy composition it was little more than echoes and atom heart mother revisited and rearranged for mass consumption. it also shows just how much they have slumped from the glory days of interstellar overdrive and a saucerful of secrets. if the former was a schizophrenic acid casualty and the second an avant-rock watershed that bordered on cosmic enlightenment then shine on you crazy diamond limped along in the brave-new-world made out of upper-class cocktail parties depressant drugs and intellectual pretensions. the real highlight was welcome to the machine set on the rhythm of an industrial pump and featuring synthetic harmonies and mild mechanical dissonance thus giving musical credence to the drama-rock of roger waters who apparently felt alienated by the corporate record-industry that had made him rich in the first place. the other two tracks were have a cigar which was an ok blues-funk melodic-rock exercise and wish you were here which was a lame ballad.

the song wish you were here is amazing. there is a real soul bearing on this song. however the rest is a great big nag of shite. not a good bag either. like a steaming tramp shite. i have a cigar is so bad and shine on... is terrible. more melodious melodies have emitted from the back passage of a chimp. get out now.
shine on you crazy diamond  wow...

...and here we have the floyd post-commercial breakthrough attempting to follow up the audio masterpiece that got them there. it was not easy obviously and the band nearly split over the course of the sessions. and the results? 4 new songs spread out over 2 long lp sides. this is where synthesisers and saxophones go when they are feeling sick i mean slick. shine on you crazy diamond is a likable tribute to syd barrett though by lps end it has long outstayed its welcome and makes you wonder if something could have been done differently to prevent listening fatigue. the four note guitar riff that gilmour introduces the band with early on is absolutely brilliant hands down my favorite moment on the whole record. wish you were here is the other good song another barrett tribute. this song can be rather moving but i have heard it so many times in many different often utterly despicable reinterpretations that i have no real opinion of it anymore. please leave this song and across the universe alone those of you looking to cover an old not so well known tune. that leaves welcome to the machine and have a cigar the weaker cuts. the former reeks of then-state of the art tomfoolery mainly from rick wright mixing synths with gilmours acoustic guitar and dramatic vocalising. this song is about as useless as the floyd would get during their big decade the 70s. the only way to possibly tolerate it is by putting it in the background. have a cigar with lead vocals by pf pal roy harper is a little better but does not do much in making wish you were here a substantial album. it seems like their trying to have fun but there is no physical way that that can be accomplished in the constraints of 1975 pink floyd. listening to wish you were here i get the image of nick mason dressed leisurely hopping into a fast sporty car with drivers gloves on and throwing a cassette in the state-of-the-art stereo the car has and blasting the contents loudly. it is a yawn but wish you were here could indeed be a lot worse like say if they recorded a whole album using only homemade objects rather than instruments.

wish you were here fue uno de mis discos de cabecera cuando era adolescente pero ahora tengo la sensacin de haberlo dejado ya atrs. no cabe duda de que eran muy buenos msicos y de que la produccin es impecable pero las grandes pretensiones del lbum no ocultan el hecho de que ya haban perdido el espritu aventurero del que seguan haciendo gala fripp y sus chicos ni que las letras no son tan profundas como pretenden. es un lbum slido de una calidad indudable pero sin ninguna frescura todo est demasiado calculado.

while i love floyd this cd just does not do it for me like some of their other stuff. the purists will tell you that only posers like the wall more than this but i can honestly say that a concept album about going insane is far superior to a non-conceptual cd that has songs that drag on for 3-4 minutes longer than they need to. that being said this album is still worthy of owning and has it is beauties. welcome to the machine has a fitting title as it is almost mechanical in sound and structure while the title track wish you were here is one of the most heartfelt songs of the century. while it is definitely not floyds best and a little on the lengthy side this cd is a good one and should be considered an easy gateway for new fans.
roger waters continues his obsession with the ghost of syd barrett.he should get some help and quit sitting on his piles of pounds.

this has some nice moments the sung parts of shine on you crazy diamond part one the title track and even have a cigar. unfortunately there are only five songs here and many of them are prolonged with pointless unexciting guitar noodling. it seems as if the boys were out of ideas.

good album pink floyd in their prime but i do not pull it out very often. shine on you crazy diamond is in the floyd pantheon of songs and it is quality stuff but i have always felt it was a little long and tended toward the boring side. the whole part 2 of it as they call it - parts vi to ix is rather useless to me it basically just rehashes part one and that was enough for me. have a cigar is a cool song featuring the same funky vibe that floyd used in money and would later use in songs like pigs and young lust. killer synth line too. wish you were here is a classic of course. i personally have always enjoyed the live version on pulse the best it was the first i heard. the menacing welcome to the machine is a nice headphones song with lots of random shrieking keyboards sounds and a mournful-sounding gilmour vocal. overall while i think this album perhaps best captures the classic pink floyd sound it is not the album i pull out most often. animals which i rated 5-stars would hold that honor.

as a follow-up to a very well-received and charted and commercially successfull album such as dark side of the moon - wish you were here presents more of the same melodic bluesy space rock for the masses with immaculate crystal-clear production. shine on you crazy diamond 1-5 is a very famous and an alright song featuring simplistic soloing by gilmour sounding emotionally charged but also quite stiff and calculated and a cheesy main theme that would be great as a theme melody for the x-files. it is a great 4-note combination reminds me of black sabbaths 3-note doom dirge but plus one more note to sound more mysterious but after i have heard it for the 1000-th time it becomes quite ordinary. welcome to the machine is a fine and moody depressing ballad about alienation and the woes of the music business which according to roger waters destroyed syd barrett and brought him to madness. have a cigar sounds like an outtake from dark side... - nothing special but still kind of ok. it is pink floyd playing after all. the closing shine on you crazy diamond 6-9 starts with an irritating steel guitar solo i never liked the sound of steel guitar then goes into p-funk territory with some funky groove with synthesizer washes and bits and ends with a some more slower synthy melodies by wright. overall a prety good album which may amaze the more casual music fan. for the ones familiar with the krautrock scene and the developments of the space rock genre both of which to a certain extent derive from pink floyds initial barrett phase this album might seem a bit too safe shiny and pedestrian. the most interesting aspect is by far richard wrights keyboards and all the interesting and innovative sounds that they produce. and finally what is with all this stuff about the evil music business? if it is so bad why did not pink floyd become a rio rock band and why did not they sign to an underground label and make music with kitchenware instrumentation as was the initial plan for a dark side... follow-up?
at least they were off to a good start on this one. i want to shine on but i do not feel welcome in the machine i do not want a cigar. concept? maybe...
patchy self-indulgent record from a slightly overrated band. hey i like wish you were here as much as the next man but let us face it there some drivel on here too...
moving from nonsensical expressive acid-fried weirdness to heavy-handed allegorical space wank was the dumbest thing this band ever did. but it made them millionaires!

running over the same old tracks they were not kiddingat first the concept of despaired pessimism worked but by 1975 how many albums had they put out that constantly emphasized how much they hated life.what makes this album even worse was that these songs were mostly digitalif you are going to ask me to choose a concept album then i will take sgt.peppers lonely hearts club band any day over this!
this is where i stopped listening to pink floyd. insipid lyrics and boring music. even the album cover artwork is ridiculous.

an erratic performance by pink floyd on wish you were here. following on the breakthrough success of dark side of the moon considered by most as their masterpiece the band seemed to have rushed this together. it reminds me in a way of meddle in that the songs do not flow together well. as individual songs they are good but as a whole the album does not mesh as well as other releases. you could say the band has a chronic problem if you want to call it a problem with erratic music as piper... meddle and wish you were here all have it. anyway the album follows two main intermeshed themes. mostly it is a tribute album to former founding member syd barrett. the second or minor theme deals with what the band thinks of the record industry. this second theme can be intertwined with the first if you assume the band blames the industry for syds illicit drug use that drove him over the edge. in other words the fame and recognition syd receives as pink floyd becomes more and more known was the catalyst. add in the resulting stress from the pressure the industry would put on his creative processes with deadlines to fill and contracts to adhere to and you get the picture of what floyd would put on this album. i spoke earlier of the erratic nature of this album. like echoes is for meddle shine on you crazy diamond is the backbone and heart of wish you were here. the band broke it up into two parts with the first starting off the album and the second finishing it. after listening to the album repeatedly you realize they should have kept it together and placed at the end like on meddle with echoes. the reason can only be assumed that it was to distinguish it from meddle or to give the album a more cohesive whole as the 3 sandwiched songs could not drive the album on their own. the angst ridden insult toward the record industry that welcome to the machine is does not mesh well musically with shine on... even though it works from a theme based standpoint. the electronic sound of an industrial fan and overall feeling of machinery even with the acoustic guitar playing does not mix well with the sax by dick parry and other instrumentation and airy feeling of shine on.... in fact if you include wish you were here and have a cigar the former being another song about syd waters is having mixed feeling of the success of pink floyd as barrett who was instrumental in this success is not there to enjoy it with him and the latter is another insult to the record industry the 3 middle songs seem like additions to fill out the rest of the time that shine on... did not absorb. do not get me wrong have a cigar considered the worse of the songs on the record does have the theme embedded in it and of the three songs meshes the best with shine on... except that you hear guest vocals by british folk artist roy harper but it is not exactly there. neither is wish you were here although again it meshes with the theme. the reduction in the volume output at the end of have a cigar and at the beginning of wish... with the short conversation between a man and woman and commencement of of the acoustic guitar does not work well. it is not surprising that you hear these three songs on the radio more than any other songs by floyd with the exception of money and time from dark side... as i think the band or capital wanted to continue the success of dark side... with radio exposure. taken as singles each song is great and i enjoy all of them especially welcome to the machine one of my all time favourite floyd songs but as a whole they do not make wish you were here a coherent record musically. the output of pink floyd that commenced with meddle and ended with the wall is personally my favourite period from the band and wish you were here is an integral part of that era. it just is not my favourite floyd record.

this album shows the evolution of pink floyd from old guitar amplifiers to newer and crisper guitars and amplifiers recording equipment and a new recording label. it looks like they are set back a couple steps and try to learn how to render their instruments so they sound well with together which is not a bad thing but can make a listener bored like me. the whole synthesizer instrument for a keyboard was sharp and overriding and does not work well with their arrangements. shine on you crazy diamond obviously is roger reflecting on syd. in fact the album can be viewed in the light that roger is reflecting on syd. welcome to the machine have a cigar and wish you were here are good indications. too bad there is nothing here that even rivals their previous album dark side of the moon.

well this is my first pink floyd album. i do not know why it is taken me such a long time to finally hear one i guess i was just put off my a lot of their later overproduced pretentious stuff mostly from the wall- i will be sure to avoid that one. well this one is still slightly overproduced but only a wee bit pretentious and i do not mind a bit of pretension once in a while. i guess the title track was the only one that had any real effect on me but rest of it was fine- the two parts of shine on you crazy diamond just breezed by nicely welcome to the machine was a little overdone but still effective and even have a cigar which seems to be the weakest track by wide consensus was pretty good. altogether a strong if slightly overrated album it has not inspired me to check out everything pink floyd have done but i will give some of their other stuff a go.

4 songs that is not an album! its a lazy bunch of good musicians with no idea what to do next! perhaps if someone in the studio spoke-up and said...guys how about we chop crazy diamond into 6 minutes and write 4 more tunes then pink floyd would have had another masterpiece. but instead the guy in the editing room called in sick and they let self-absorbed demo-quality experimentation go on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on... perhaps my point is made by now?...mr. waters said no...and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on. what a bore. what a waste. such a lazy misfire at the peak of their talents. psychadelic my arse. the sound of water dripping is more creative than this. metaphorically i feel sorry for welcome to the machine cigar and whish you were here...these songs deserve better than to be sandwiched between obese boring shine on parts 1 and 2. should have been named shine on and on and on you lazy diamonds. cannot give more than 2.5 stars for half an album.

wish you were here was comparatively similar to the dark side of the moon but it was not as coherent. the overall feeling of the album is oddly disjointed but it is still good despite this. highlights include wish you were here  shine on you crazy diamond.

ahhh wish you were here is an average album. wish you were here have a cigar and welcome ot the machine are all good songs yet the other 2 shine on you crazy12 seriusly brought them down. floyd has definatly done better.

unfortunatly over rated. which is a shame because this is a fucking great album that i should give a 4. but in light of the popular cheese feel this album as i am forced to give it 3.5 sorry rodge. the track wish you were here probably houses my favourite song lyrics in the world ever p.

with the high esteem in the court of the crimson king is held it almost seems to be an obligatory listen. i have given it several listens just to be fair coz the first time around i thought it was shit. it is true that 21st century schizoid man was groundbreakingly heavy for 1969 and it drives along well for a couple of minutes before a really bad speed wobble and spin out. it finally gets back on track but the ride was ruined. next up i talk to the wind is the shortest track at a mere six minutes. it is a quiet affair dominated by flute and organ and for the most part is incredibly dull. epitaph brings welcome relief with a touch of variation and drama and greg lake actually portrays some emotion a true highlight. i am a little torn when it comes to moonchild. i am not sure whether it is the musical equivalent of taking five separate doodlings and attempting to construct a piece of fine art from them or the product of five musicians beating each other off. yes it is an absolute wankfest and i would rather listen to revolution 9 repeatedly or stick pins in my eyes than ever bear this again. if i ever see the words free and improvisation together again i will know when to run away. fortunately the court of the crimson king comes to a merciful rescue with some beautiful vocal harmonies to get lost in. it is a delightful piece. overall though i have difficulty reconciling the albums current lofty standing with its much more moderate success upon release. maybe i am missing something but i am not going to bother looking any more especially at that cover art. yuk!

like crash bandicoot warped 100 memory card save files of full relic completion are passed down from generation to generation the king crimson vinyl of thus debut has been passed down unto me via one generation of slaving to buy it at a car boot sale one day. i plug it into the glory hole of the back-end of a flouting disc jockey to be revealed a world of slam-dunk dairylea cheese triangles. 21st century derren brown bursts on like chocolate thunder ice cream and funks up in a saxophone doubled guitar sound that is both crunchy and polymerised for a smack of golden pangos. you hear the echo of some guy who forgot to pay for a lottery ticket as he exhales in anger in syncopated time to the instrumentation. then they make jam for a few hours with the jazz club. lightning fast stop-and-gos like the go-gos got no beat as they burn through the driveway at 22mph. only stopping to go into all out squeeadly deedly because they watched the newest episode of strong bad. i talk to the wind is the little gem in the spyro year of the dragon. heavily flute based and serenely hippy in calmness it brings about pictures of sitting in a medieval village discussing politics and if we truly find hairy legs smell attractive. the jam is melodious and sweet this time and i prefer it as the singer sounds like a door that needs to reverse itself outside of the closet into nostalgic spy air. perdodious. as the epitaph approaches we are lead into the morose cataclysms of mellotron that shoves us into zetsubou. the chorus shouting into a bass thump that manages to bump a goose into one and other but being awkwardly nihilistic in my head as i fear that tomorrow i will be crying. i forgot the leek. moonchild is when i left the jam outside and there was too much. the jam constantly fornicated with itself until breeding a super army of jam. this jam then continued to force itself onto the villagers. pillaging them all down one by one until i got the high score. that title track manages to get a perfect balance. the kingdom has been saved and we are a pe. the king screams because his face is red and he does not like having a red face!!! i guess it was too prog for him.

it is fucking ridiculous how much more i like i talk to the wind than anything else on this record. i talk to the wind makes me think of long sweet melancholic nights spent reading poetry under full moons and lost rolling hills over which i rollicked eternally with fairies before waking up alone again reaching laughingly for summer and what it should be for the streets when they are empty near campus for mornings when i can scarcely tell you about all the things i saw all the lost things streaked with syrupy pastel. the other four are like having a smelly uncle

so this is the legendary progressive album that the ratings and most critics have been so generous to. i have heard of kings crimson and looked into them to see what all the hype was about. my musical taste are always expanding and i always crave successfully pulled off cutting edge sounds that will knocked me off my feet. by successfully i mean it is still good music in that it has listen-ability you know the stuff that has you tapping your foot and whistle the tune later that day. you know what kind of music i cannot stand? music that wastes my time. there is a lot of good music out there and i want to hear it! i do not like feeling like i am listening to a film sound track without visual footage to accompaniment it. even worse are pretentious musicians who start out with solid sounding material then throw it all out with long slow dull and drawn out jams with little going on but subtle noises and minimalistic attempt at evoking atmosphere with spacy notes. i had a feeling that is exactly what this would be which is why i have avoided it so long. well i took a chance with it anyway come to find it was simply alright. the album starts off with a kick in the balls looked like it was going to be the album everyone said it was! from start to finish a progressive rock masterpiece! unfortunately it does not continue. the next song is not terrible it is just slow and soft which i do not particular care flutes tootin throughout the song without much more going on would not dismiss this song becuase i can see how some people could enjoy it for falling asleep or something. the is alright again slow and soft going for that classically induced atmospheric feel i see. makes me think of waves crashing on a beautiful beach with a light house but the mood indicates something bad just happened. great vocals here the instruments kind of take the back seat here and do not do anything tremendous even when greg lake is not singing. the next song does exactly what i do not like to hear in music as described above. starts off good then gets duller as the music does not seem to change until everything slows down and leaves you hung up listening to experimental noises beee booop... booop beee... xylophone riff.... .....bee boop .... get to the fucking point!! if you have got something worthwhile to record then only record what is worthwhile do not add all this extra fluff to drag the song out this is one of the biggest flaws i find in progressive rock and where my bias for long songs come from. if a song must be long have a purpose for it i.e. when the musics over by the doors or jazz music that features solos and well executed improvisation jams not this shit. finally in the court of the crimson king. this song is also rather good and i would place this as second best but still a long stretch from 21st century schizoid man. this is one of the few songs where the artist successfully demonstrates the imagery they want to evoke it really does sound like you are in the court of the crimson king whatever the fuck that is! full of expression and imagery. over the course of rating this album i have come to appreciate it more and see how some people with great patience can tolerate or enjoy most of this album. for the most part it is too slow and boring for me. maybe i will warm up to it some more though will keep listening to king crimson for i know their potential from the stellar track 21st century schizoid man.

i love crimson but it always aggravates me that this is always voted their best album when its plainly not. i put it down to peoples basic ignorance of their back catalogue. firstly the production even with the new re-master is pretty dull and stodgy even by 1969 standards. the album kicks off nicely with schizoid man but everything thereafter gets into a more pastoral vein. in the court of the crimson king is a nice track but the production let us it down and i am surprised that crimson never re-visited this track on further albums cos it could definately have done with an overhaul because of the lumpy sound. the definative version of schizoid man appears on 1974s live usa album and quite simply walks all over the original. this is a landmark album for sure - there was simply nothing else like schizoid man in 1969 though the remainder of the tracks are generally uninspired but there is much better stuff out there even though crimson have always been a very frustrating band being as all their albums suffer from hot and cold moments -the aforementioned usa album is generally pretty damn great though and you cannot go wrong with that. 2003s the power to believe has 3 tracks on it that are among the heaviest music ever created. the jewel in the crown though is 1974s red album. real mind-blowing stuff. start on any of those before going to this album.

i tried i swear i did. i do not get it. i know that this is one of those huge albums that everyone says is important. i would not dare say it is bad i just do not hear what everyone else is hearing. there were moments that i enjoyed but then it would break off into some other direction and it was very jarring. i appreciate that these noises were made on purpose and in a particular sequence but i only hear sounds rather than music.

would it be terrible to admit that while listening to 21st century schizoid man the first thought that popped in my mind was man this sounds like mars volta? haha i am so young. take away the mindless meandering of moonchild and this is a completely solid album. epitaph is just...fucking sweet lord. i am pretty sure listening to that and the moody blues nights in white satin back-to-back violates some clauses of the geneva convention. the one that says something about how combining the two songs in too short a time frame is equivalent to testing some sort of atomic bomb of absolutely fucking overwhelming sadness and melodrama.

i can appreciate why people like prog but beyond some of the krautrock stuff it is a genre that i just do not care for much. i dled this out of curiousity i mean it is regarded extremely highly but it reminds me of spinal tap circa stonehenge era in places especially moonchild and i talk to the wind! 21st century schizoid man has some interesting free-jazz freak-out moments but then there is some extremely wanky guitar playing that reminds me that the mars volta were probably inspired by this song....and tmv are just too busy. i like my rock without unicorns and fire witches. besides robert fripp went on to make much more interesting music with brian eno....
great fun and it was very thoughtful of them to give us time for a tea-break in the middle of moonchild.

somehow i managed to avoid hearing anything by king crimson throughout the whole of my school years which must be something of a record given they were the darlings of the student population. in fact it was not until the height of the punk revolution that i heard the seminal 21st century schizoid man and because it was new to me it sounded fresh and innovative and worth a punt. king crimson arrived on the scene when any idealistic notions of peace and love had been forever tainted by world events and bad publicity. their take on the dinosaur that psychedelia had become was to grab the drug-induced soundscapes of the music and drag them kicking and screaming into a more cynical world. except listening again they themselves wimped out. songs like i talk to the wind and moonchild already sounded as if they belong to a world of the dim and distant past. additionally pete sinfields lyrics - much beloved when first released - appear to have great depth and meaning but are probably nothing more than word necklaces strung together merely for effect. finally the preternaturally quiet doodling on moonchild are signs the band are having trouble wrapping it up rather than carrying any profound meaning. in the court of the crimson king is good value but it is not the messianic transcript that most see it as.

july 10 2008 i really do want to like this album. as a whole king crimson is a decent band and quite a few of their other songs i have heard are worth listening to. but in the court of the crimson king as a whole falls short. 21st century schizoid man is a great opener and a good song. it is nicely proggy and i like the sax section and jazzy bass. but after that the album completely falls flat. i talk to the wind is after a few minutes in which it has already said everything it can just flute wankery and gets really boring as the song goes absolutely nowhere. epitaph is alright a little more interesting but not much. it is also too long and only really gets going at about seven minutes in which is about five minutes after i have lost my patience for the song. and then... we have moonchild. oh god moonchild. it is twelve minutes of nothing at all. well it may as well be. i can appreciate improvisational stuff like this but here it just does not make any sense at all. and for free improv it is not even very good. finally we get to the the title track and the only other decent song on the whole album. you know this would have made a great ep. just the first and last tracks and you would be set. none of the wankery none of the improv none of the pointless songs just two decent prog tracks and it would have gotten at least a 3 from me. oh well.

parmi les grands mystres de l univers il y a les gens qui considrent que les improvisations jazz sont ennuyeuses et qui prennent trs au srieux le trs trs laborieux et carrment embarrassant moonchild avec ses vagues relents de fake moyen age sucr et cette impro hyper poussive qui meuble pniblement 9 minutes dans ce pensum. cette daube numro 1 de 1969 ? alors qu il y a trout mask replica uncle meat ou mme carrment ligeti si on veut un truc vraiment audacieux et progressif ? et la lourdeur des percus introduisant epitaph ce plonasme motionnel cheapo tragique ou au moins les paroles ne trahissent pas la musique. daube solennelle sotte et prtentieuse. misre.

i listened to this album without knowing anything about the history of the persons of this band. for the life of me i cannot fathom how this album is rated so highly and i generally agree with the other albums in these top lists.

i cannot deny their ambition and skill but this is not what i want to listen to. the improvisations are not interesting the lyrics piss me off. it all sounds cinematic in a way i do not like so this is a no for me.

it is an ambitious debut with new sounds and some good themes and melodies and some rooky mistakes. according to consensus it is a milestone the start of a musical tradition. i like to listen to it every now and then maybe once per decade. and i like the balads i talk to the wind and epitaph. i like them better then the two large prog tracks even if the schizoid man has good clarity and guts. the court is also good but it lingers for too long.

whether you have listened to this album or not you have no doubt seen the iconic cover art floating around the internet more than a few times i know i certainly have. the first track very aggressive cartoon music? did not like the second track peaceful forest music? lovely flute playing here. did like the third track boring pop rock with a random pointless crescendo? i suppose this one does have a bit of lite symphonic stuff going on but it really is not engaging or interesting to listen to. did not like the fourth track this one gets a bit of hate and i can see why. the very promising and pleasant track ends after about two and a half minutes and the almost ten minutes that remain consists of random soft improvisational instrumentation. did not like the fifth track now i understand why the fourth track is on this album- to make the other tracks seem much more interesting than they really are. but they are only comparatively more interesting. so this is another symphonic rock thing which is kind of a combination of tracks two and three. probably the second best track on the album. mildly liked overall this album is quite disappointing.

giving this a 3 because of 21st century schizoid man. would have been lower if not for the song. i enjoyed epitaph and the title track too. nonetheless the album is overrated according to me. there is no way its the 3rd best album ever for sure. it is amazing to create this in 1969 but it is too basic for my liking. love the flutes though.

21st century schizoid man is great the jazz-rock is fun to listen to. but the point of contention in most reviews is moonchild and to a much lesser extent i talk to the wind and i feel like not enough of them are interacting with it on its own terms i.e. as free improvisation so i am mostly going to talk about those and also i am breaking out the section headers so i do not have to write a transition between the two. i. i talk to the wind is it an interesting opinion to say that i talk to the wind is the misstep here? i guess i understand the juxtaposition effect that they are going for but also epitaph fulfills that same need without requiring everything to grind to a halt. and honestly my bigger issue is that it preemptively ruins the improvisation on moonchild but i could not figure out how to word that without it sounding unintelligibly clunky. but just because i do not like i talk to the wind on the meta level does not mean that i dislike the track itself the songwriting is stupid sure and i do mean that in the traditional sense but when have i been one to complain about that? and i find the twee-prog aesthetic kind of endearing you know? ii. moonchild i like my free improvisation to sound deliberatethat is i want to be fairly confident that it was a conscious choice on behalf of the songwriters and not a failed jam session. usually you will get some kind of fast section with lots of runs to give the instrumentalists a chance to prove their mettle or perhaps more commonly they will incorporate it into the main motif. i think the rest of the album is supposed to provide that here? only it does not really work because all that does is assure me that the band can play through-composed musicnot that they can improvise. so once we get past the power ballad section of the song there is some incredibly timid noodling and because i have not really been primed for free improvisation i hear groom asks to play with the band at the wedding or less cynically four musicians goofing around in a practice room instead and that is fine but it does not sound like free improvisation that has anything to say and i cannot tell if it was intended to.

this album is consistently hailed as one of the greatest of all time by pretty much everyone in the internet space. while i understand it is aesthetic significance because well it sounds like it was released about 20 years later than it actually was as someone hearing it for the first time in 2021 it is age and cheap tactics for seeming grandiose and epic are extremely obvious. while the album is still enjoyable and far from bad putting it anywhere near a top 10 of all time list is kind of ridiculous to me. my main issue with this album is the technicality for the sake of itself. the band themselves have even admitted that at times they would add more random stuff to the album for show to further show off their technicality. this flaw really gets in the way of a lot of the songwriting. there is random bells and whistles everywhere drum solos and just generally non-musical pieces that really take away from the songwriting. i can imagine a version of this album that focuses less on showing off the - admittedly very impressive - talents of the band members and i think i would enjoy that a lot more. all that being said i still have an overall positive review of the album. there is no denying the colossal nature of the soundscapes and songwriting choices here. to start we have 21st century schizoid man. this song is a full-blown auditory metaphor for mania for the great majority of it is runtime. the primary riff is strange and off-kilter though i am not a huge fan of the harsh sound of the higher-pitched saxophone passages. the large breakdown section in the middle has a lot of the over-technicality that i talked about earlier - the part with the snare drums and saxophones simultaneously starting and stopping at random is particularly guilty. the next track i talk to the wind is a dramatic change of mood from the previous track. this track is easily one of my favorites it let us the beautiful songwriting and playing take center stage in a non-indulgent way. the song is essentially a vocal section followed by an extended flute solo - and i do not think it needs anything else. great track. epitaph is perhaps the least memorable track here but still a cool ride - it is use of deeper-toned instruments in the instrumental sections adds a lot of power to the song. it also builds to a great outro but at the end simply fades out which is a bit of a bummer. moonchild is the worst track on the album as pretty much anyone could tell you. the brief part that is actually musical at the beginning of the song is fine but then comes an extremely pretentious instrumental section that consists of only the band playing random little licks for almost 10 minutes - 10 minutes!!!!! it is ridiculous boring and laughable. the album at least ends with a bang - the court of the crimson king is a really cool track for the most part. the vocals are epic the backing aids that feeling and the flute solo is especially cool. the only real downside is the ending that is trying wayyyy too hard to be epic. it stops at where it should actually end goes into a quieter section and then suddenly explodes again into an encore of the chorus before exploding into a noisier section and finally ending - all really eye-rolling attempts at extending the run time and showing off. although i have a lot of problems with this album the reasons that it is considered a classic are not hidden. it is a groundbreaking and impressive album truly ahead of its time and the underlying pretentiousness of it was probably a result of the pretentious nature of a group of people that would be able to push the boundary this far. i still enjoyed it greatly and can look past some of those issues when i am really getting sucked into the world that this album tries to create. strong 710
shit sounds like cavemen just discovered instruments and decided to make a shitty prog rock album

i think i have forgotten how to properly lay out a review by now but because this is an undisputed classic and the third best album oat according to the site i do not think people are looking for an extensively developed and probably unoriginal opinion or take on king crimsons game-changing 1969 record in the court of the crimson king anyway. thus i will press forward with this mess of a stream of consciousness. is this the album that holds both 21st century schizoid man and epitaph tight within its tracklist? why yes yes it is. damn me if that is not one perfect a-sideb-side combo. as i have grown out of 21st a bit and gotten more into the phenomenal melody lyricism and progression on epitaph as time went by i will give the latter all the praise i can give an old prog song the likes of this very tune. epitaph is brilliant. it is everything i expect from a progressive song of its nature it is not overly technical and off-putting which is something i could maybe critique 21st century schizoid man for its instrumentation is actually pretty its crescendos are grandiose its transition passagesmoments actually add to the songs power rather than making the whole song sound extremely long and boring its lyrics have some incredibly resonant and terrific lines it is topline makes the song what it is. for all i could compliment epitaph it is the brilliance of the melody just how fucking catchy and earworm-worthy it is just how much of a i will not leave your head for the next hour it amounts to be what actually makes this a perfect song. if greg lake had sung the song just the way he sings it with the same words but the melody had been anything but what it is the song would be torn to shambles. epitaph melody-wise is extremely one-note. there are not many variations other than perhaps lakes voice going an octave higher the second time he sings the melody and yet the song comes out anything but repetitive. the interlude halfway through is pretty as can be and when those bombarding cascading drum hits come back down on you you know you will be singing your lungs out to the waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaall on which the proooooophets wrote is crackiiiiiiing at the seaaaaaaams for the next few seconds. holy fuck. this is how you do timeless music. do not go the extra mile unless you have got a melody that can warrant repeated listens on its own that is not even counting the beautiful progression of the track itself. oh right. there is other songs on this thing as well. moonchild is incredibly pretty until it becomes incredibly awful and a song that makes you wonder what the fuck the people that think this album is perfect are on about. the second half is nothing! nothing happens! at all! thankfully i talk to the wind is albeit relatively simple quite pretty as well. one of the tracks that emphasizes that symphonic aspect of the album the most. the flute bits are really nice to listen to. the court of the crimson king i feel works as a closer maybe...? and it is one of my preferred tracks out of these 5 top 3 to be precise but i feel it falls a bit flat by the 4th time the in the court of the crimson kiiiiiiiiing comes around. i still enjoy it though. of course 21st century schizoid man although many might believe it to be the band throwing everything at you even if some of the fast playing whether it be the guitar the drums or others comes off as a show-off rather than anything of substance i just think is perfect. the middle section actually makes me enjoy the song even more rather than making me wish the band would just go back to the chorus. which is something weird for me to experience when it comes to prog-rock. perhaps the instant takeaway from the record i have now come to enjoy it just a bit less than i did before but by no means do i think it is lost its magic. it is a perfect song in my book well the 445 version is anyway. given the amount of space dedicated to the third song on the tracklist when compared to the other songs combined i guess i just wrote this review to churn out what i think about epitaph. and i think that is more than fine. this album should be renamed epitaph and other prog-rock songs that amount to just about an lps length. oh and the silent bit at the start of 21st century schizoid man is completely unnecessary. radio edit rules supreme. but anyways. stream epitaph.

been a long time probably like 7 or 8 years since i have listened to this. it was always an album that never had anything that brought me back. on the re-listen - 21st century schizoid man rocks especially in the context of music in 1969. - i talk to the wind is the best song on the record for me the woodwind and electric piano is total bliss to me. after these two songs though i really just do not care that much about the album. - the strings in epitaph are nice and the songwriting itself is not bad but it is not exciting enough for me to want to ever relisten although the last minute of the song is nice but not quite nice enough for me to want to sit through the meandering. - moonchild has a nice vocal melody but the instruments are just bleh and then it just goes into the most boring unnecessary dicking around i have ever heard. i hate the latter 34s of moonchild so much it brings the album down a whole point for me. awful contrast to the epic parts of the album. - the court of the crimson king is good but there was much more interesting things going on in music that it does not do much for me. a little too repetitive in a bit of an annoying way for me kind of like a fever-induced thought loop. despite my gripes it is significance cannot be ignored and i get why people cream their pants over it so to speak. it just personally is not as sexy to me though.

schizoid man is obviously brilliant and insane the rest sounds like the soundtrack to a monty python film. that old prog trick of putting a really cool track near the beginning and then letting your roger waters analog do his louis ck impression through the next 40 minutes conceptually speaking of course - no i will say no this time.

albums like this are more of a work of art than a collection of songs making it harder to rate than most records. what i can say is that the parts of this album that are good are pretty damn good. it peaks for me during epitaph although the court of the crimson king does not lag too far behind. and of course the classic 21st century schizoid man is great too. a good chunk of the album though is a bit too out there for my liking though works of art are not always completely palatable i guess. overall though in the court of the crimson king is a decent listen and a truly influential album. 3.5 pretty good

no doubt this album was revolutionary for 1969 and helped pave the way for the progressive rock take over however i feel it is very much a love hate relationship i have with this album for the most part it is enjoyable and unique but some of it is dull and boring.. its definitely a must too listen but i do not believe it deserves to be 3rd best of all time. highlights21st century schizoid man epitaph talk to the wind

this is a tough one but i have to say that this is on the lower end of king crimsons discography for me and i am still giving it 3.5 stars. not that it is a bad record by any means but as albums go the band only went up from here. with the love this album gets i think it has potential to be one of the most overrated albums of all time. this is a great starting point for the band however and shows people just how creative fripp can be. it was monumental for 1969 and is without a doubt one of the most influential records of all time. the drumming by michael giles is incredible greg lakes voice is just as good as any other work of his and the atmosphere in songs such as epitaph is astounding. this album would be much better if not for moonchild. i do not care what other people say the improv section absolutely ruins this album. not that it even is bad necessarily but it is just wayyyy too long. oddly the improv section is longer than most of the songs and unfortunately creates such an interference from the rest of the tracklist. while i think king crimson has better stuff and that this album does not flow the best the highs off of the title track epitaph and 21st century schizoid man will blow you away and at times make you forget about the atrocity of moonchild. any rock fan needs to listen to this record and just sink into that mellotron!

this album as a whole is cool but i do not enjoy it. i like the idea of everything that is going on here but something about the repeating saxophones or the extremely dragged out moments on this album are really not that enjoyable as cool as they are for it is time. take my favorite track moonchild. the song as a whole is amazing and the textured sounds that come afterwards are very fitting and enjoyable but they did not need to be nearly 6 minutes long. i have a lot of respect for this album but honestly it is not that replayable.
cover is the best part

the sound on this is quite bad but that seems to be a pretty consistent problem with early prog. other than the opener this merely reaches the realms of solid never really transcending into the mythical realm where so many put this. the opening section of moonchild comes close though.

king crimson were one of the first progressive rock bands. they took what was in the air from jazz-rock and baroque pop especially the key album days of future passed and transformed it into a new style. robert fripp and others wanted to establish rock music as a serious art something for which you could wear good suits. the collection is uneven but clearly shows the direction his artistry would take. 21st century schizoid man including mirrors of course is the big shot of the album it excells in guitar virtuosity memorable riffs and even was being sampled by kanye west. the lyrics by peter sinfield paint an apocalyptic world in typical late 60s-fashion but everything else was highly original for its time. the foundation of the track is jazz-rock but the scope musicality and tight composition was new. robert fripp one of the greatest rock musicians of all time presents his sustain-heavy virtuoso guitar style to the world. another key element is the saxophone and the jazzy drums. the lead riff is so disctinctive it essentially became a meme for big badass prog rock. i talk to the wind sounds like a standard baroque pop ballad and does not carry the momentum of the phenomenal opener. to this day i prefer my king crimson when it is ridiculously heavy and riff-tastic. fripp did not pen this but winds player and keyboardist ian mcdonald and the style is almost jarringly different. the next composition is much superior the majestic epitaph including march for no reason and tomorrow and tomorrow. the key instrument of the song is the mellotron an instrument so distinctive you will immediatly recognize its sound. it was brought in as necessity as a real orchestra was too expensive. it became a signature element of the band and the formula of the grandiose mellotron rock ballad would later be perfected by the bands own starless on red. moonchild including the dream and the illusion is a base breaker it begins with a beautiful minimal ballad. it is unusually melodic for king crimson and appears like a lullaby. after a little more than two minutes however it turns into a freely improvised piece that to this day will offend listeners. i personally found it failed and later improvisations like providence were much better. the court of the crimson king including the return of the fire witch and the dance of the puppets is another ian mcdonald-led baroque pop ballad. it is much better than i talk to the wind and the mellotron compensates for much of the lack of crazy fripp antics. when the album is over you really wished for more of those riff-heavy insanity of the opener and thankfully the wish will be granted on the mid-70s wettonbrufordfripp trilogy of albums which i vastly prefer. compared to later releases this album appears almost simple-minded as robert fripp would create the weirdest things in the future such as larks tongues in aspic and become a tier-a sideman in rock for the likes of david bowie. soon frippo would be in absolute control over the group and recruite even better musicians for his vision. of course i also have to mention the glorious cover art. it is the 21th century schizoid man according to fripp and it is based off a paining by barry godber a friend of peter sinfield. 7.510

in the court of the crimson king is a bona fide masterpiece. absolutely fucking genius. possibly the best album of the 1960s. has to be heard to be believed. the only thing holding this back is the improvisation on moonchild. other than that it is perfect. 9.410

in the court of the crimson king points out the dilemma underlying rock criticism. criticism should be founded on a bedrock of logic and reason but as an aggregated rating of 4.31  5 clearly shows a whole lot of people love this album and therefore cease to be objective. i am guilty of it myself of course. i have tried to get into prog. i just cannot. as psychedelia morphed into prog at the end of the sixties it lost the magic for me. i can listen to this album and objectively appreciate most of the tracks as daring and innovative but the album as a whole --and prog in general -- still strikes me as cold and bombastic. in the court of the crimson king is probably a better album from a technical standpoint than behold  see but it lacks the warmth and quiet resignation that has compelled me to listen to that album for decades before and for decades to come. my mind likes a lot of in the court of the crimson king my heart however is indifferent. and so as i bring down this albums impressive rating by just a hair know that i have tried to be as objective as possible. the poet robert browning once wrote mans reach should exceed his grasp. that sentiment seems true of both the albums contents and my attempt to adequately review them.
on dirait que des centaines de disques parus bons pour la plupart depuis ont piqu allgrement dans cet album hyper riche. cest drlement bien mais 35 seulement car je lcouterai une fois tous les...

clearly in the court of the crimson king is a historically important work. as a yes fan i recognize the unlikelihood that close to the edge would exist without the influence of in the court of the crimson king. along with van der graaf generators early work the use of syncopated reed-instrument parts on in the court of the crimson king would be emulated by bands for years. beyond that this album seems to have prefigured a whole strain of non-blues-based heavy prog and i have to believe it is a progenitor of many works by progressive metal bands. but while in the court of the crimson king has been one of the most influential progressive rock albums ever the album and the band is not without its own influences some of which to me seem fairly clear. for example the heavier songs owe a debt to in-a-gadda-da-vida and to groups like vanilla fudge. there are also echoes so to speak of pink floyd in these songs as well as in some of the experimental sections of the album. parts of i talk to the wind sounds a little like traffic and all of epitaph sounds a lot like the moody blues. nonetheless in the court of the crimson king is an original amalgam of a number of styles as a whole
