it is anything but derivative. in the court of the crimson king relies as much on production as on composition or musicianship and the production is superb. fripps use of effects on vocals and instruments is appropriately offbeat. the sound quality is also top-notch. in terms of sound the edition i am reviewing herethe fortieth anniversary cd with the 2009 steven wilson  robert fripp remixessounds like it was recorded yesterday. in terms of mixing it does not vary radically from versions of these songs on the 21st century guide to king crimsonvolume one 1969-1974 which contains nearly the entirety of in the court of the crimson king. the performances range from good to very good and rarely detract from the listening experience. the only exception is the vocal harmonizing on i talk to the wind which wavers off-key a bit too much for my taste. while michael giless drumming is good throughout it is occurred to me more than once that it made sense that king crimson bandleader robert fripp would eventually covet bill bruford for the band. the relative weakness of in the court of the crimson king is in its composition. the quality of the songwriting is within the normal range for artistic rock of the period. i acknowledge that peter sinfields lyrics are more sophisticated than were those of nearly any rock lyricist of the time but like neil pearts early works each clever turn of phrase is matched by an equally clumsy one elsewhere. repeated listens have illuminated aspects of the presentation of the songs on in the court of the crimson king but for me have not deepened my understanding of the composition. recognizing that i am in the minority here i am assigning this album two and a half stars. it is hard to say that an album as important as in the court of the crimson king is not essential which is how some people define a three-star rating. this album has been essential to the development of steven wilson andy tillison and many other great modern prog musicians. but as a part of a prog-rock record collection i would suggest first purchasing one of the bands 1980s albums with adrian belew or perhaps red king crimsons last 1970s album.

i am living in that 21st century doing something mean to it do it better than anybody you ever seen do it screams from the haters got a nice ring to it i guess every superhero need his theme music no one man should have all that power the clocks ticking i just count the hours stop tripping i am tripping off the power 21st century schizoid man inizia cos power di kanye west perla contenuta nellalbum - a mio avviso - pi grosso del decennio scorso. con il sample della canzone dei king crimson. i think it was really me him and the engineer and he was working on his asr-10 sampler going through samples while the song was playing over and over to see what would fit ricorda s1 producer di kanye in unintervista a rolling stone. i was right beside him while he was doing it and he came across this king crimson sample and as soon as he hit the key it triggered the sample and it came in right on the right spot of the song and we looked at each other like oh  that is crazy. so he started chopping it and getting the sample to fit exactly right aggiunge il producer. and every time he would hit it it was just this magic that was happening. leggenda narra che una volta scelta la base kanye lavor 5.000 ore sul testo e che lo stesso testo fu fortemente influenzato da quel sample. sempre s1 afferma once he put that in the song it became such a moment of the song that i am sure that had some type of influence on the lyrics. effettivamente al di l del verso i am living in the 21st century il testo di kanye con i suoi riferimenti al razzismo istituzionalizzato the system broken the school is closed the prisons open e il tempo che sta per scadere the clocks ticking i just count the hours  til then fuck that the worlds ours sembrano riflessi contemporanei della profezia oscura originale di peter sinfield. questo pippotto per dire che questo album ha unimportanza capitale non solo per leffetto che avr sulla generazione colta del post-punk ma anche per quello che avr sulla musica contemporanea. vedi kanye. detto questo io odio il prog rock non lo reggo. per se c un badate bene uno solo album prog che posso ascoltare  proprio questo. purtroppo per il resto sono proprio lontano anni luce da quellestetica fatta di folletti flauti maghi e foreste per qui - specialmente grazie al primo pezzo - lo posso sopportare.

this album is hard to describe. first off we start off with what is no doubt the best song on the album. this could be one of the best rock songs in the 60s. of course the song being talked about is 21st century schizoid man. the intro to the song is great and the verses are too. but it does not just stop there. we get into the fast solo section. the drums are packed and the drum solo is packed as well the horns just keep going and going and the expected guitar solo brings out the unexpected somehow. it is a very great song and i can listen to it any day of the year. however this should have been in like the middle of the album and maybe king crimson should have had taken a song out of the current album and create a song like this because... ...the rest of the album is... ...fine? epitaph is a pretty great song. the chorus brings out great emotion and feel. however i cannot really say the same for i talk to the wind. even while being the shortest song on the album i just do not see it being a high point on the album. it felt longer than epitaph to be honest. i talk to the wind is just alright. the song could be better if it was seasonal or something. honestly moonchild goes on for way too long. while the actual song is pretty good the intro kind of reminds me of shangri-la by the kinks moonchild and the court of the crimson king should have been equal length or maybe moonchild could take the extra minutes it had and just scrap it altogether. the court of the crimson king is an okay song though. it is a pretty good introduction to prog rock but i would not go to an extent that it is one of the best. 3.55

never been a huge fan of progressive rock. i see its merits but in my opinion the albums are often overly long and lacking in a lot of what i enjoy in music. i care little for virtuoso musical ability if the music said talent produces is not enjoyable for me to listen to. that is why i do not listen to much classical music. sure mozart is a musical genius with immense talent but his music is immensely boring to me. as the fathers of progressive rock one would assume then that i greatly dislike them but that really is not the case. more often than not i enjoy what i hear from this band but there are many instances where their songs get a bit lost in the sauce. the amazingly catchy melodies can disappear for minutes on end as the band members engage in performative wankery with their respective instruments. some people get into that kind of stuff and that is awesome but it just is not for me. the album starts out with an amazing song 21st century schizoid man. this is the type of stuff i love from king crimson. the melody is strong and dominant and the instrumentation is tight. each member is playing in perfect harmony and unison with the other and even at times when that harmony is disrupted it is a careful disruption that only adds to the song. i talk to the wind is another solid track. it is not as good as the opener but it is a nice little song that acts as a great transition from the hyperintensity of the opener and the slightly mellowed nature of the next track epitaph. moonchild just is not good. i like the first three minutes but those are followed by nearly 10 minutes of meandering nothingness. maybe i just do not get it but it is in no way enjoyable for me to listen to 10 minutes of near silence. the closer is pretty good. nothing amazing though. solid melody but it does not live up to the opener or epitaph. overall in the court of the crimson king is a solid album in king crimsons canon but it is far from their best in my opinion and i happen to find it a tad bit overrated. just my opinion though.

in the court of the crimson king 1969 by king crimson is a dark portrayal of the you.s. vietnam war from the perspective of the delta force. it is unashamedly darkadmittedly repressive but so is most rock and roll. after all do you really want the governmentor many others but that is a matter of speculationreading your rocknroll novels? king crimson is so stark in its realism that the viet cong might as well have had their own bandrocknroll without lyrics. the impact of this novel on the vietnam war years is both profound and surprising even by todays standards. in conclusion i came to the conclusion that luo hua city mistress was indeed different from his wife.

clearly influential and in many ways ahead of its time. i try to rate music with the era in mind though admittedly i listen to nearly nothing from the 60s and little from the 70s so my ability to compare and contrast is limited. what is clear though is on a 42 minute album that there is a good 8-9 minutes of pointless meandering improv wankery going on during moonchilds the dreamthe illusion sections. this renders about 20 of this album pointless if not irritating and a big mark against it. perhaps this is forgivable again given this came out in the late 60s. i am also not sold on track 2 i talk to the wind. it is okay but a bit too hippy-dippy without a meaningful build up crescendo or let down. i do not suspect this track was much different than much of the other rock music of the era. tracks 1 3 and 5 are clear winners though even forgiving the frustrating amount of repetition in title track the court of the crimson king. despite that numerically it is hard to justify giving a 4 for an album with 20 filler that is actively irritating. i am surprised that i actually liked this as much as i did however so a solid 3.5 will do.

i am astonished at the popularity of this album it feels very overrated to me and i cannot believe it is rated above so many classic albums on rym. also unlike some prog masterpieces it sounds so dated. i have never got the pure adulation for 21st century schizoid man including mirrors no less!. the song is decent enough with a strident urgent tempo but hardly earth shattering. moonchild is the sort of song that gives progressive rock a bad name. even if i grew a beard and downed 5 pints of real ale i still could not appreciate it. unfortunately that is over a 14 of the album wasted on one song! the title track is far more succesfull good use of mellotron and lakes vocals fit the mood well. but it does not seem to warrant it is near 9 minute length. the one thing i talkto the wind can say is its better than moonchild. it is ok if a tad dull. epitaph including ..actually just no..is the most successful song on the album where lake puts in a sterling vocal performance. very good. not a massive crimson fan but on the rare occasion i pull out one of their cds it is usually red not this. overrated in my opinion but it least it has a memorable album cover.

re-listened to this for its 50th anniversary. i cannot believe they would put some limp-dick bullshit like i talk to the wind after 21st century goddamn schizoid man. epitaph and the court of the crimson king are both prog-rock mellotron classics. moonchild sounds like a first-year contemporary improv class trust me i have done it.
this is where an entire genre essentially began that is a criticism not praise. robert christgau while brilliant is far from right about everything. he remains certainly right about in the court.

i would not say this is like the all-time best prog rock i came in 5 minutes click to play album of all time. i am personlly more favourable to that of close to the edge but i can respect this. 21st century schizoid man is one of the greatest song ever made even with the blatant stealing from kanye west  epitaph and court of the crimson king are also prog rock epics are are worth noting. moonchild is uh...yeah i do not like it. the first few minutes sound really cool but then it just sounds like they accidentally recorded the bands sound check and just kept it in the song. i are not sitting through 9 minuted of that lol but yeah good album. just some shortcomings and it is not even the best king crimson album

1 yes please! pow! prog rock that rocks? i will have three please. 2 enough twee to knit a cardigan no thanks i will use one of my three 21st century schizoids that i previously purchased instead of this snooze-fest. 3 mmm i am ready for lunch and it is a full-bodied and heartily good dish with a little bit of wool in it but it adds to the flavour. 4 i could not review this track because my record player started malfunctioning a couple of minutes into it and it sounded like a man failing to carry a lot of instruments at once up some stairs. i will just have a 21st century schizoid snack instead i am glad i bought all three of them. 5 all outta snacks going to have to settle on this for supper. it will do i am not exactly going to starve and i set myself up with a hearty breakfast and wholesome lunch.

21st century schizoid man is a real roller-coaster that i have never been fully able to make my mind up on. sometimes it is a blast of avant garde jazz and sometimes well sometimes well it is plain shite jazz. like a bunch of kids hammering the dj button in a music lesson except not as funny. do like the john lennon style vocals. truthfully though i think kanye did this track better. i talk to the wind is a pleasant little track. it does little to impress me though. its a reasonably nice thing. sounds a bit like that really shit song from a porno. not even like the fun porn groove sound but you know the boring bits when they drift off and give some really dull plot bit. yes you heard it from me king crimson sounds like the shit bit of a porno. not even the fun stocklibrary funky stuff when they get down and dirty. the boring stuff. epitah comes bodly in like it is ennio morricone and has some david bowie like vocals going on. this one fucking goes for it you know. i am a fan. moonchild has decent atmosphere but cannot quite match epitah. i cannot help but think the tracks are not as interesting as they seem to think to warrant the length of them. like i get to build such an atmosphere needs time but it is not good enough to hold me for it. that is why these tracks which do start off quite nicely can really bore me my the end and just annoy me. what a snoozer of a track. finally things pick up again with the court of the crimson king. some fucking flutes and shit come in. vocals are pretty cool. solid closer. this and epitah i can get behind. these are alright. had the album been a but shorter and had less of the silly stuff i could see myself saying yes it is really good. i am still trying to figure out the full appeal of this album. comes in with some crazy nonsense that is not terrible but really falters against something like what miles davis would have been putting out around the same time. in a silent way wipes the floor with this shit. afterwards the album goes in a slower direction that is completely different. all i can think of is if i wanted this kind of sound i would go to ashra or brian eno. fripps later work is definitely better than this. you can definitely see though some of what made him so excellent later on in this though in all fairness. perhaps this just gets credit for coming out so early and being influential. is that the obsession with it? if that is the case then respect where its due but it does not do a lot for me. in the past i have been very resentful to this kind of music. at this point i do not think it is terrible i just think there is stuff that does the same and sounds better.

21st century schizoid man is a masterpiece. first time i heard it i was absolutely blown away. i talk to the wind sounds more grandiose than it should and fairly boring. epitaph suffers from the same thing but it is marginally less boring. moonchild is pretty good if you are about to sleep. the last track is supposed to be the best one on here but i guess i will grant it the silver medal losing to the opener. it seems like a rock opera of sorts. i will give it a weak 810.

the thing i do not hear many people talk about in respect to crimson king - and i feel like that is weird because of how transparent it is - is that the music sounds awful. not awful in the sense that it is bad music but more in the sense that this might be one of the worst production jobs in any album that has ever been canonized. the mixing very often just plain sucks being the worst offender greg lakes voice being always really fucking low in the mix what many listeners have awkwardly assumed was an intentional artistic decision with deep implications related to the albums supposedly innovative qualities and let us be honest this is not that innovative despite a few fresh ideas here and there. mcdonald spent hours and hours overdubbing mellotron and wind layers in order to get an ok-ish job at developing enveloping atmospheres probably ignoring that reed and the velvets had already achieved such thing with better results two years ago with sunday morning. the organ on epitaph sounds scratchy as fuck and it always turns me off when trying to give the album a listen. this is not a cheap singersongwriter album this is a prog-rock epic. imagine if selling england by the pound sounded as shitty as this nobody would be giving a cent away for it. wikipedia tells me the stereo master recorder used during the mixdown stage of the album had incorrectly aligned recording heads and that such misalignment resulted in a loss of high frequencies and introduced some unwanted distortion. yeah that might have a bit to do with it... but it cannot be all. cmon. sounds like a crappy excuse more than anything. and i do not think every single copy has the same problem. if it sounds shitty it is because it sounds shitty so let us discuss that. do you guys know fragile came out only two years later? and foxtrot just three? those sound much better. besides let us not pretend there is not some of the most annoying fantastic poetry ever on the album. torinn has already covered this peter sinfield often gets so devoted to the development of his lyrical theme that he forgot people were actually going to hear it being sung. i cannot blame him he had no reason in 1969 to think this band would have any listeners. the first section of moonchild is i think particularly problematic. but all the songs at some point or another get a bit too drowned in their own self-indulgences. if i could go back in time and cancel somehow the release of this album i would do it in order to stop the legion of idiots that would come after. not like i would have destroyed music or anything i am pretty sure 70s kids would have found some other way to suffice their need for classical-pop crossovers. this is just some more stuff that adds to the big list of pretentious andor annoying things about this record. fortunately good songs -or at least interesting ones- can make up for things like shitty sound and there is some of that stuff in here. 21st century schizoid man which is probably the most emblematic track of the album is a furious piece of jazz-rock and listening to it feels like walking barefoot through a path of burning ashes. the song does seem to go on for a bit longer than it should but most of the band plays throughout it without getting any exhausted. and it is a lot of fun there is a jam of chaotic brass playing noisy guitar solos and it is all sandwiched in between the apocalyptic classic set of verses that greg lake sings sings? with a megaphonic voice that resembles that of a radio host announcing that the end is near. and there is michael giles always playing like a badass and not missing a single note. i appreciate all those things very much. if every song was like this the status of this record would be perfectly understandable. but then the rest of the album happens. i talk to the wind is just a plain boring composition. with boring flutes there are even two flute solos but i never remember any of them are there with the inane vocal performances of lake and mcdonald and some nonsensical lyrics that probably helped settle the aforementioned standard for overly self-important lyrics in progressive rock. it is six minutes long and not much happens. figure it out for yourself. and in epitaph things do not get much better lake manages to make the thing sound a bit more convincingly epic but the song itself is still a very basic piece of atmospheric rock that goes on forever and never quite displays the melodic greatness that it should be developing given the important classical influence. besides it sounds like shit. there is some good stuff that i like the organ crescendo at the 345 minute mark the always-present low notes on the piano that help build a very eerie atmosphere and last climax of the song with that bizarre instrument that comes in during the seventh minute. i actually like moonchild a bit even though it often gets dismissed as the weakest track. it seems to be only one moment on the record where the band just compromises to the silly search of instrumental color instead of creating dated and pompous soundscapes. the way the song comes to an end with the gentle melody of the vibraphone is very sweet and that is something you would not expect to hear on an album like this. the title track is epitaph all over again only that a bit more dynamic - in particular i like the drumming here - and with a long false ending. on one hand the song was already long enough but on the other hand the reprise gives room for some pretty counterpoints and the display of some impeccable guitar noise so it really does not really fuck the song up. quite the opposite actually. i do not like the way the album ends though. they just stop the recording in the middle of chaos. laaaaazy. so yeah flawed flawed flawed songs. still i have to give props to this record because even though it does not always hit right on the mark it always every fucking time manages to sound iconic. this is music that sets an image that can be remembered. maybe it is how grandiose the music tries to be maybe it is the uncomprehensible pretentiousness of the band but you always know what the songs are doing and what is that you will remember about them. there is a reason why kanye sampled 21st century schizoid man of all things that moment when lake sings screams? the title words tower themselves above anything else like giving the clear impression that you are in front of the only thing standing gloriously in the post-apocalyptic 21st century world that we did not exactly get although with all the cold war paranoia the imagery seems justified. lake lamenting the words confusion will be my epitaph  as i crawl a cracked and broken path in the last set of choruses of epitaph sounds like one of the most self-assured things anyone has ever sung and it makes you wonder why anyone would sing those words. the songs do not die in their weaker moments but try to resurrect and reaffirm themselves as important fragments of folk tales that will have to be confronted and understood - to put some thought to it - even if there is really not much to understand. i look at the charts for 1969 and i find many greater albums though everything from 5 to 11 is better. i would not put this record on my top 10 for that year. would be lucky to enter the top 20. same for the prog-rock charts there are many many better progressive rock albums where to pick from. albums that sound better are way less corny and have actual songs that deserve to be remembered. in the court of the crimson king might be an interesting listen from time to time if only because of the musics iconic component which i have already discussed. but it is not a record as preciously atmospheric as the dark side of the moon or rock bottom nor as rewardingly tuneful as selling england by the pound or foxtrot nor as fierceful and forward-heading as thick as a brick red or fragile. if crimson king is the quintessential progressive rock album it is because of the particular place in time and space of its conception. which you know i can admire. but not in the form of a rave review. and not today of all days. is in the court of the crimson king the most overrated album of all times? well... i would probably say so if i were suddenly asked the question but i suspect that if i tried to put more effort into the search i would quickly find other more overrated albums. at least i can understand why people praise this one. and i actually think it is pretty justified getting a vinyl copy even if it is just to have the artwork around. i mean... it looks awesome and the screaming guy does make you feel anxious for a second. i would not have it in my bedroom watching me while i sleep though. 7.5

my overarching theory on king crimson is that they have managed to masterfully release near-identical records with just minor variations over the years and that is not even meant as a mockery or even a critique of them. sometimes the most interesting music is one which only differs slightly from another and in king crimsons case the differences are sometimes quite meta in that it feels their songs are rearranged before being put on wax. even internally the band has at least two occasions wherein they rehashed the same basic musical concept and applied it in a new way. this did not happen quite as overtly on this album as those that followed but it nonetheless is something to consider as well. now frankly this is also a bit of a reduction on what i mean to state about their music but really it seems they have something of a checklist with which to compose their works. that checklist is  two hard-rocking hitters one noticeably lighter than the other the court and schizoid man larks tongues parts 1 and 2 red and one more  the crooning song i talk to the wind exiles starless  a midway between the previous two epitaph book of saturday fallen angel  the prog song moonchild providence the talking drum granted i have not listened to the rest of the bands material in quite some time but the notion that this neatly applies to their three most celebrated works is telling to me be it that the bands most accessible when there is this spread specifically or if there is a shadow of some larger thematic decision. one need only look at my ratings to see that i am not altogether bothered by this and in fact i find it extremely interesting to question why there is such a variance in my personal reception of these albums. red undoubtedly rocks the hardest and larks tongues is almost definitely the most adventurous. this one? i think this album is most in line with what would become the typical progressive rock album and i cannot help but feel this is a major consideration upon the great number of folks that rate this so highly. its legacy is certainly enormous but the effect its had in tandem with the music presented is a bit less exciting than i would like it to be. i will be content to listen to larks tongues another dozen times before i come back to this one.

one of the pioneering examples of english prog pomposity and one of the most egregious offenders. the musicians are excellent the album cover a classic and the opening track is vicious and damned good but after that it becomes unbearably pretentious. greg lake would later make this seem like a masterpiece as 13 of the 70s bad taste machine elp robert fripp would make better king crimson records and would do his best work adding his puzzling dazzling guitar to records by other artists. ian mcdonald would be a founding member of fucking foreigner of all things. the drummer later played for leo sayer not kidding. a strung-out jimmy page ascending a mountain top dressed as a sort of wizard druid in the song remains the same was subtle and earthy compared to this long-winded nonsense. how on earth it is so highly rated on here is anybodys guess. must be a strong contingent of medieval knights with accounts.

i love rym to death but the overall charts are undeniably dominated by the vestiges of dad rock - that distinct genre of 70s guitar heroism instantly recognizable by its middling tempos grandiloquent solos badass moustaches and impresive sideburns. now king crimson is far from the worst offender of this era. in fact the opening track here is genuinely exciting and worth every second of its 7 minute runtime. the title track is majestic in the best sense of the word and i suppose i talk to the wind is good for lighting a candle and staring into the distance if you are into that sort of thing. problem is this leaves us with barely 20 minutes of good music. because the other 45 of this supposedly genius album is - frankly - throwaway garbage. i cannot imagine how anybody could objectively listen to moonchild and take it seriously let alone consider it as part of a masterpiece. are we thinking independently here or just following the cult? overall the emperor has some clothes but misses a few vital garments. this lp is a mixed bag only half worthy of the fawning it routinely receives.

i am a huge fan of progressive rock and i think this album is greatly overrated. while the compositions are often inventive and the band was far ahead of its time much of the album is bland and boring. it is very vocal-heavy. it seems to be more influenced by soul than by jazz which is great if that is your cup of tea. i appreciate these guys for what they contributed and for making very listenable music but i have heard much better progressive rock. that said this is one of those albums that every rock fan should familiarize themselves with if not because it is a solid rock album then at least because it is so highly acclaimed by music critics in general and so influential on subsequent rock bands.

ok... this is the best king crimson album. naturally some may think i am saying something self-evident but i was not at all sure because there are many highly appreciated albums or songs within the catalogue of king crimson which i do not like at all. originally in the court of the crimson king was the first crimso album that i heard but it was on the background in my friends flat about 15 years ago and i may have been slightly drunk. so when i started exploring the crimso albums 196974 i decided that i would listen to other albums first and end up my exploration at the court of this crimson king. i guessed it was going to be more interesting that way the original magnum opus did not have a massive effect on my further listening experiences. i started from larks tongues in aspic which i did not like much. i also considered the amazingly appreciated red even substandard. up to this my favourite crimso album was lizard. but anyway in the court... sounds better. i am not at all fond of the disharmonic features that are present on all at least 196974 king crimson albums. here those are virtually dumped into one song 21st century schizoid man and even that one is not bad though honestly speaking i cannot say that i like it. moonchild is massively overlengthy but it is somehow intelligible this obviously is the way it was meant to be while in most similar cases in the crimso catalogue that may not feel very obvious through listening  you just believe that mr. fripp certainly wanted it that way. i talk to the wind epitaph and and the court of the crimson king are honestly good numbers. thus coming to know this album still did not make me a king crimson fan not even close and while i remembered some beautiful fragments from my earlier first listen i similarly recalled some uglier ones so i may be positively surprised especially while i have always hated the album cover. in the court of the crimson king is ok.

uhmmm... there is only one song that is worth your time and that is the 3rd track on this 5-song lp epitaph. this album opens up with a horrible pathetic attempt at black sabbaths metal rock. the lead singer seems to think that the voice distortion sounds pretty cool when in fact i cannot make out a single word he is saying. but worst of all is this drumguitar solo that just screams pretentious. next we have ourselves a 6 minute tune that is calming and oozing. i like the flutes on it. i think it would have been better if it were cut a little shorter in my opinion. third track is the standout track. this song is definitely worthy of being on red the bands best record. i really love this song. fourth track is pretentious garbage. quite possibly the epitome of boring. fifth track is yet another overrated pretentious song. honestly i think the chord progression and the chorus are amazing but the length of this track and all the babbling about middle age mystic-epic-wizardy make this song laughable. they could have broken the mold a little by stepping in a guitar solo or something just saying. they could have done something to make this a little less repetitive and more interesting. so there it is in the court of the crimson king rating d

more than enoughs already been written about the original album so i will just comment on the bonus features in this edition. aside from the wonders of hearing a 2009 mix of this classic album in surround audio some of the bonus tracks are superb additions. in particular the alternate album which is all-instrumental and in some cases quite stripped-down studio out-takes. my favourite thing is the power-trio instrumental version of 21st century schizoid man i.e. played in the 1969 studio solely by fripp giles and lake. at the moment i am liking it better than the main version! especially hearing michael giles fantastic drums move to the foreground with extra reverb and really thundering from 5 speakers  and his kick drum is incredibly fast and powerful. many of the guitar and bass elements that are rather buried in the main version are revealed with astonishing clarity in this plainer take. it is good to finally hear precisely what is going on in this normally very dense piece. fuzzed vocals? shrill saxes? if you have heard them a thousand times over 40 years they are not missed here at all. there are numerous takes of i talk to the wind some only instrumental others with different solos. each version is excellent and worth hearing it must have been very hard to choose only one for the original album. i found it very cool to hear instruments like piano acoustic guitar and clarinet moved to the forefront on epitaph and itcotck  not to mention the mellotron overdubs being separated out to distinguish each one  though truth be told this causes the pieces to sound even more moody blues than the main versions do. still enjoyable especially the starring role giles fancy kick-drumming commands in the latter. oh and it is nice to hear a very abridged version of the normally tedious moonchild it made me somewhat appreciate the song for the first time. while i still vehemently disagree with the legions who feel that itcotck is king crimsons best or most important album at least this edition has me raise its rating by half a star.
decent but highly overated. 21st century schizoid man isnt bad and the court of the crimson king is good but stuff inbetween is mostly mediocre.

i really enjoyed this. i do not know much about progressive rock or this time period at all but i can say that there were parts of this album that really spoke to me. i loved the beginning of moonchild i loved all of the opening track and i really liked i talk to the wind. i am not sure how i felt about tracks three and five but i will definitely be giving this more listens and i fully expect my rating to increase.

lt1 although the album allegedly has five tracks it could just as easily have been divided into seven. that means two tracks would have been cut into two those being 21st century schizoid man the instrumental and the verses at the beginning are pretty much entirely mutually exclusive although the main riff from the instrumental capitalizes well on the main riff of the verse admittedly and moonchild which could be cut into the song per se and the pointless directionless uninspired and altogether unnecessary improv section that follows it. and now we are left with two templates with the instrumental and the improv section on one side representing the more experimental side the album boasts and the remaining five tracks on the other which makes up the bulk of the release. if we eliminate the former side the remainder becomes entirely transparent and altogether unimpressive. essentially in the court of the crimson king is a pop album with unnecessarily long tracks talking about politics and fantasy shit. influential and historically relevant as it may be the album is just a bit dishonest really. the intimidating track lengths are not obtained by progressing the songs in some meaningful way towards magnificent conclusions or important segues no what king crimson actually do is to just repeat the same old verse and chorus dance interspersing some little interludes usually solos in between so as to break the monotony a bit until they reach whatever their understanding of the song being done is. that is literally all they do on i talk to the wind on moonchild and on in the court of the crimson king with varying success. on the non-instrumental parts of the other two tracks they manage to do even less than that. and no matter the song we are talking about the riffs and melodies of the songs their actual themes just do not hold the weight of the length they are supposed to carry. it is hard to imagine melodies that could accomplish such a task for a whole albums length. the only one that pulls through in the end relatively unharmed is i talk to the wind but that one gets to use the opener for second-hand momentum for a while as once that fizzles out the problem is just as apparent as in the tracks that follow. nevertheless with the tune it has it could have easily been an absolute classic were it not for how little reason it has for extending for the length it does. now one good thing does come from this insistence on length it allows king crimson to do some neat work on the atmospheres of the songs and they do a considerable bit of that on epitaph but all in all it just is not enough. at the end of the day in the court of the crimson king consists entirely of half baked song ideas extended way beyond what is reasonable with a few jabs at the jazz scene plus i talk to the wind. once the novelty fades away there is not much left.

if you claim to be a progressive rock fan as i do you have to give this album its due amount of respect. 21st century schizoid man is the perfect blend of aggression and control while the rest of the album demonstrates that there was a reason that these guys were considered the first masters of prog. the most valuable part of this album is that if it did not exist then neither would many of my favorite bands. for that i do tip my hat.

talk about an epic opening track. the first time the riff kicks in -- with fripp on guitar and mcdonald on saxaphone - is breathtaking every time. nothing else on the album matches it but the slow burn on epitaph comes close. the first third of moonchild is good but the improv meanders too long. the quieter moments as a whole can stand up to the more obviously impressive ones thanks to innovative arrangements on the mellotron but there are a few things that keep me from rating it higher. why does the improv on moonchild need to go on for 9 minutes instead of 6 or even 3? why is the coda on the closing track even there? nevertheless i cannot imagine what it would have been like to hear this way back when it was released. even if you do not like prog rock -- like i generally do not -- it is worthy of several listens.

this is one the most influential albums of the so-called dad rock genre. too bad it did not age that well - of course it must have been a shock to hear this album in 1969 but let us be honest the mellotron and choirs sound really cheesy at times. the album itself starts with 21st century schizoid man which is the highlight of the whole recording and probably the reason we still talk about this album after over 40 years. it is just ridiculously unique and ahead of its time. then the album gets pretentious and well boring. i talk to the wind is fine. epitaph is kind of overdramatic. moonchild lingers for way too long. and then it ends with the court of the crimson king which is pretentous too but at least it a really good song. forgot to mention it has its iconic gorgeous cover art.
moonchild is actually my favourite song. i guess i just have not given the album enough listens.

definitiv pionier des prog rock eine mischung aus schnellem frickeligem jazz-rock und leicht psychedelischem pop mit geigen und flten. alles gar nicht mal so schlecht aber mein ding ist diese art von musik nicht das ist mir alles viel zu nett und eingngig und berechenbar zu melodisch und melancholisch -- gar nicht so weit vom pop-mainstream entfernt wie man glaubt! als junger kerl htte ich das sicher groartig gefunden so wie marillion etwa heute gibt mir diese musik nicht viel. trotz einiger netten ideen fehlt hier letztendlich die substanz das ganze wirkt auf micht immer auch ein bisschen posig. das cover ist definitiv wesentlich dsterer und beeindruckender als die musik.
i like it but not up there with others on it. it is a classic but last few times have not really killed me.

je moet er voor zijn voor die typische jaren 70 progressive rock of art rock. niet alle groepen uit die periode zijn nog steeds even boeiend om te beluisteren. king crimson is gelukkig wel nog een groep die nog steeds relevant is. in the court of the crimson king is hun debuut en nog steeds hun beste album. het album biedt een donkerder kant van wat we gewoon waren van de muziek eind jaren 60. muzikanten mochten hun muzikale veelzijdigheid en intelligentie meer en meer gebruiken om moeilijker structuren toe te passen op hun muziek. het contrast tussen stille en luidere passages wordt onderzocht en is al een beetje de voorloper van de hele alternatieve scne van twintig jaar later. ook bombastische momenten worden niet geschuwd iets wat later groepen als pink floyd volledig zouden perfectioneren. de groep neemt rustig zijn tijd om de ideen volledig uit te werken in hun lange songs varirend van 6 tot 12 minuten. meer dan veertig jaar na datum is dit album nog steeds even verrijkend en verscheiden als toen het werd uitgebracht hoewel het toen helemaal geen commercieel succes was. zelfs kanye west gebruikt tegenwoordig samples uit dit album.
beh  fico. non posso metterlo in dubbio. pure io ascoltandolo in un primo momento mi galvanizzo.. e il progressive non mi  mai dispiaciuto. dopo un po per..... emicrania assurda.
some really great stuff here as well as some really great musicianship. but it is the definition of overlong.

21st century schizoid man i love chaos and this song has a strong dose of chaos in a fairly original prog-rock format. lyrics are unintelligible apart from the title of the track. i talk to the wind absolutely nothing wrong with this song. all the jazz sensibility in the flute or mellotron? and keyboard parts may be lost on me and the dreary vocals do not do much for me but the song is pleasant. epitaph has a false sense of grandiosity which unnerves me. uninteresting. moonchild two minutes of substance. i cannot thing of a more unamusing way to spend 12 minutes than listening intently to this song. and given that some of the sounds in outro are annoying or startling they outweigh anything positive in the first two minutes. the court of the crimson king comparable in quality to the opening number but its slower speed loses most of the chaos. the flutey solo halfway through is actually fairly enjoyable i must confess. lyrics are among the best on the album some albums just give me the burning desire to knock them down a peg. but to review them i have to listen to every song and give it a fair chance again which sometimes leads to me having a better appreciation for the album even if i still do not love it. this is not the case with itcotck. however influential it may be it is simply not enjoyable to listen to.

sorry but this really is not my kind of music. everything is nice and beautiful and harmonic there is flutes and violins all over the place. there were a few nice parts but in the end i do not see much difference to mainstream pop music except that the songs are twice as long as they should be so that it can be called progressive and art and thus is hip enough for hip people. i give half a star for the cover which is the only memorable thing about this album.
moonchild  21st century schizoid man  i talk to the wind  in the court of the crimson king epitaph
why would human bean do this what is this i do not even made me laugh then sleep v. soundly until last track that was v. noisy. bad idea

in the court of the crimson king pode muito bem ser considerado o bastio o baluarte do rock progressivo clssico. no s isso a faixa de abertura 21st century schizoid man  o que de mais moderno tinha sido gravado at ento desafiando e dizimando qualquer tentativa anterior de qualquer outro grupo de soar moderno e de outro mundo. o disco alm de dar ao mundo a banda mais enigmtica da histria do prog tambm registrou uma lenda futura them disco greg lake.
dazzling debut. the kings court is glacial mystical and spiritual. favourite tracks i talk to the wind  the court of the crimson king

in the time it took me to eventually summon the motivation to write a review for this i initially thought my rating would be higher than the one i have decided to give. after getting a better idea of the album content however i now feel 3.5 is justified. 21st...man is a unique fiery jazz prog work and i think it is brilliant. love the tempo change midway with greg lakes walking bass and the jazz band inclusion works really really well. i talk to the wind is not terrible but i mainly enjoy it for the repeated suspension at the end of each verse phrase bit of music nerdery i am slightly ashamed to say. epitaph is fantastically haunting and i love the bass instruments bass clarinet? about midway through with their really brooding drones that have on a couple of occasions given me chills. now i will explain the main reason this album lost my appreciation somewhat fucking moonchild. it starts off like all of the other songs with promise of something exciting and unexpected. the excitement however never comes and it disappears after barely two and half minutes note the length of the actual song!. when i notice how long there is left of the song to go i am thinking wow there is so much left of the song what interesting ideas are going to come in to fruition. little did i realise that i was going to hear tiresome uninteresting somewhat pretentious experimental wank interspersed with sweet fuck all. now if it had been one of those songs that is long for the sake of being long with just silence and is leaving a little present at the end as a reward for your patience - one example is  dead girl off of acid baths paegan terrorism tactics - then i am familiar with the concept and can just fast forward to a couple of minutes before the end when something starts happening albeit weird shite when referring to dead girl admittedly. king crimson however unintentionally or not provoke the listener in to think something is going to happen in the next 9 minutes by having something playing in it constantly whether that be an organ or random flute or drum spells implying that perhaps there will be a build up leading to a climax. fans of the album would say the title track is the much expected climax but for fuck sake. did it have to be 9 minutes of utter tripe that adds nothing to the listeners experience whatsoever? a theory i had was that they did that as a way of making the song more progressive and going with a sort of post modern theme. in my opinion it was an experiment that failed quite stupendously. the title track is an interesting tale that let us your imagination concoct interesting mental images of what the hell is actually going on. i do like the song as a whole but am quite happy when it finishes with a satisfying tonic major chord at around 640. then again even the somewhat cheeky repetition of the main fragment following that is a nice touch. instead however there is a drum fill with a few more reiterations of the chorus this time in a different key before building to a discordant mess that just cuts off at the end. disappointing end to a rather good album i feel. just a few words before i finish this for those who have not heard the album before i suggest if you decide to stick with listening to moonchild try your best to stay patient and you might be best just skipping to the title track after two and a half minutes. good effort to do something original and creative crimson but was not without its flaws. thanks though.
great album that just does not move me anymore like it used to do once in the past.

i see this as a missed opportunity for me. i listened to 20th century.... to gauge whether i would like the album and hated it. 3 years later listened to more of it and loved it and the rest of most of kc back catalogue. still hate 20th century.... still cannot stand the jazz stuff but love the other stuff

talvez de lo primero q haya escuchado de ellos hace ya un tiempo despues de leer que era el mejor lo cual nunca me parecio. si bien me quedo con lo mas chiflado de ellos red por ejemplo y esto sea muy diferente es uno de esos discos q crecen mucho en uno con los aos.
ya know the long ending of moonchild might actually be my favorite part of the album. so nocturnal mystic and dreamy. i also love the freakout parts in 21st century schizoid man obviously.
this album is mesmerizing. quite possibly the greatest early prog-rock album ever. every track is great. the only downfall is the bare instrument improv at the end of moonchild.

la cara a me sigue pareciendo excelsadesde la brutalidad metalica del comienzopasando por la delicadeza de i talk to the windmi favoritao la grandeza de epitaph.musica panoramica del maximo nivel. mi problema estriba en la cara b.moonchild siempre me ha resultado largaespesaderivativa...y el tema final redunda en la grandiosidad de epitaph pero no le llega a la suela del zapato.aqui la voz de lake me resulta pomposa y cargante al mismo tiempo.una segunda mitad grandilocuente y bastante hinchada. aprobado suficientepero podia haber sido mejormucho mejor.

gli anni 60 sono un covo di falsi miti che il tempo ha contribuito a cementare. il debutto dei king crimson ha tutta laria dessere uno di questi. la loro colonna sonora da operetta televisiva suona quasi imbarazzante di fronte ai picchi conquistati dal progressive rock. la furia creativa che altri artisti seppero manifestare mette in ridicolo questo modesto album che non pu nemmeno vantare unoriginalit fuori dal comune. i king crimson avrebbero potuto impressionare il loro pubblico giusto per la pretesa di trasformare il format rock in unorchestra moderna in cui la musica accompagna unipotetica scena. nella fattispecie la scena  assente viene sottintesa. ma questo tentativo suona estremamente vacuo e superficiale. c pochissimo dellepocale tentativo di sintesi stilistica che invece caratterizz il genere negli anni a venire. anzi le contaminazioni jazz sembrano uno scimmiottamento da show domenicale. in questo album sopravvive unicamente un blando tentativo di scrivere una magniloquente favoletta medievale. lopening  la parte pi interessante. la chitarra ed il sassofono salternano ad una voce estremamente distorta costruendo un motivetto immediato ed appariscente. il vortice strumentale che copre la pi ampia parte della canzone ammicca concretamente al jazz e ricorda i successivi soft machine di third. se lintero album avesse seguito le orme di 21st century schizoid man in the court sarebbe stato un lavoro impeccabile ma subito dopo i 7 minuti dapertura le attese vengono miserabilmente tradite da un sonnolento idillo bucolico. i talk to the wind suona effettivamente come una ballata annacquata che non riesce a proporre davvero nulla di interessante. la voce annoiata nuota nelle torride linee del flauto. lassolo finale insegue il free jazz ma con carenti risultati. pare un clich andato a male. epitaph forse presagendo le difficolt del pezzo precedente propone immediatamente di voltare pagina con un attacco estremamente enfatico. qua i king crimson recuperano la loro caratteristica pomposit. il progredire lento e tragico della voce guidato dal mellotron conduce lentamente ad un assolo ristagnante e remoto che sembra preludere ai pink floyd dei concept esistenziali ma con un tocco teatrale in pi. la canzone altro non fosse pu vantare una composizione impeccabile con una serie di pause e riprese curate magistralmente per favorire il pathos ma i difetti sono gli stessi dellintero album. moonchild  il brano pi lungo con 12 minuti di registrazione. la prima parte  una narrazione dai toni fantasiosi accompagnata dallarpeggio di fripp e dalle percussioni mirando a suggestionare lascoltatore con queste tinte fosche e vagamente malinconiche. ma ancora prima di attecchire la canzone sprofonda in una stasi vibrante che tenta di rafforzare latmosfera notturna da noir psicotico. da qui in poi si articola una sessione improvvisata. in realt la canzone di per s era limitata alla povera ballata che riempie i primi minuti ma si decise di allungarla con questa tenue jam che d un tono astratto ed onirico al brano. la struttura non  lineare e passa per momenti di incomprensibilit caotica a semplici sessioni minimaliste conservando per il tono povero ed inconcludente del resto della canzone. in chiusura la mini-suite che dona il titolo al disco ripropone la faccia pi nota dellalbum quella della teatralit kitsch con un duetto di grandiosi voli di fantasia e romantici stralci di narrazione iperbolica. nulla di fondamentale per la nostra sopravvivenza.

i think this would probably be my favorite prog rock record if it only had 3 songs on it those being of course 21st century shizoid man epitah and in the court of the crimson king. the first song is a pretty psychadelic piece with lots of strange things in it but great none the less. epitah is one of the most epic ballads that i know of simply great lyrics and mind blowing music. the court of the crimson king is a pretty epic song on its own right as well with a great build up and amazing hook. the rest 2 songs though are pretty much the reason why i tend to dislike so much prog. they all sound far too pretencious and redundant boring rock and if i looked up the album looking for boirng pretencious prog rock i had enough already with jethro tull. overal though pretty great listen.

i like prog as much as anyone and i find this album good but extremely overrated. every song is at least twice as long as it needs to be with moonchild six times as long as it needs to be. so many groups did the same kind of thing much better including later incarnations of kc but this group did it first so they get all the love.

es un mal disco? dios me libre de afirmarlo de manera categrica. in the court of the crimson king irrumpe en mis odos de manera atronadora y luego se desinfla con el paso de los minutos interminables minutos de experimentacin y vanguardia. mi eterno conflicto con el rock progresivo slo se soluciona ocasionalmente cuando encuentro en sus ampulosas estructuras y pretenciosas aspiraciones reductos de emocin. pese a su incuestionable leyenda y legado todava no he vislumbrado en la msica de king crimson muelles a los que agarrarme. quiz algn da halle en ellos la chispa que me ayude a comprender tan magna reputacin pero creo que ese da an se encuentra lejos.

virgins late-1990s run of album-replica cd reissues of the king crimson catalogue are quite attractive. for example included along with the great-sounding re-master of their debut in the court of the crimson king was a small booklet full of old crimson-pertinent photos and news clippings from that heady time period of the very late 1960s. it can make for a rather fascinating read if you have a few minutes. the album might have the greatest opening track in rock music history! 21st century schizoid man has been performed and covered countless times but this original version is still essential and the stuff of progressive rock legend. i talk to the wind is simply beautiful and it makes one wonder what avenues king crimson might have explored had ian mcdonald had a bit more say in the bands direction. despite its deservedly exalted status for me personally this album is a bit dull and it just has not held its luster over the years. fortunately king crimson has!

the psych influences may be limited but this is a classic among prog albums and it is influence on the underground rock scene at the time cannot be overestimated. somber and morose flavored matl mixed with some mildly annoying avant-gard cuts. grades - 2 bs 1 b- and a c.
a whole lot of riffing and an awful lots of pointless fucking noodling. makes it hard for it to stick for me.

not as good as i expected. the famous schizoid man is a belter of a track followed by two very mellow very english tracks before the noodle fest read that as yawn fest moonchild. court ends the album with a superior feel and the track itself encapsulates the styles throughtout the preceding tracks. fans of the moody blues will find much to enjoy here. id probably loved this album moe when i went through my prog rocks phase in my younger years now i find it a little bit whimsical and yawnsome in periods. no doubt the musicianship is top dollar and i am sue the improvisational peices will appear to some but id say those on red were better and more focused.

at the time of it is release this album was a stark contrast to the boy-loves-girl 3 minute pop songs of the early beatles et al. much as the sex pistols would rail against the prog dinosaurs in the next decade this was part of a turning point. we nerdy college boys loved the artwork and the concepts and the whole mind-expansion of classical and mythological allusions. having said that - 30 odd years later it does not stand up and it now sounds dated and pretty dull.

i own a nice original heavytextured gatefold copy but annoyingly this canadian wea issue also has the band name  the atlantic logo printed right on the front. i wonder if this feature see photo appeared in any other countries? this album has been more than sufficiently reviewed so that i need not add another one. i will simply say that this is not at all crimsons best album nor was greg lake its best singer.

the mirrors section of schizoid is excellent no question. the mellotron use on this album is staggering. no other album uses it to such good effect. ian macdonald shows himself to be one of the best horn players in the scene. but the lyrics are largely drivel. greg lake is a much better bassist than singer. michael giles is an indifferent drummer. primogeniture in the prog world has led this album to be more highly rated than it quite deserves and the next three are also buoyed unnecessarily. the wettonbruford years are far superior.
the tedious noodling on moonchild somewhat wrecks an otherwise enjoyable prog experience.

often considered an inspiration for much of the progressive rock that blossomed in the early 70s king crimsons debut album embodies the serious though not necessarily humourless approach that grew from the most recent developments in jazz and rock namely fusion and psychedelia. in fact the opening number 21st century schizoid man including more importantly mirrors might have been the sort of thing miles davis and jimi hendrix would have cooked up had they collaborated together instead it was left up to a bunch of white kids from england. it is a stunning opener sporting a guitar riff bordering on heavy metal and a snarling distorted vocal it must have scared a few of the more sensitive long-hairs fresh from the beatles white album. within progressive rock its song within a song format soon became standard practice immediately alienating the true rockers as rock had alienated the rock n rollers before them. the inner section mirrors is the real revelation sounding unlike anything else with its tight unison playing between the guitar and drums like musical bursts on a machine gun not lost on yes. the way the next song - i talk to the wind - contrasts with the opener is also part of the emerging formula of progressive rock. its sweet harmonies delicate guitar jazzy flutes tinkling percussion and whimsical nostalgia are some of the ingredients that fed into the contemporaneous canterbury scene. above all though its the big mellotron wash that one identifies most with this album. it is there on the intro to epitaph a stark yet bombastic anthem that impresses sonically even if it is a bit simplistic musically the moody blues had their ears open to this one i suspect. greg lake delivers its morbid lyric operatic-like as straight as he can probably under strict instructions from mr. fripp not to laugh. it is hard to clearly identify the other pieces incorporated into this song but i will take their word for it. moonchild brings some welcome relief on cd at least and is another lilting lullabye similar to i talk to the wind. what follows though is controversial and troubles some listeners who otherwise greatly admire this album. the dream and the illusion who knows where one ends and the other begins are in fact beautiful little arrangements between guitar vibes and percussion. yes quite abstract and somewhat under-recorded but also highly imaginative and quite enchanting even funny if you can appreciate the subtle humour. they certainly add another layer of texture to an already fascinating album. anyway those who fell asleep are rudely awakened by the drum figure that ushers in the final epic and title track the court of the crimson king oh yes and its inner segments the return of the fire witch and dance of the puppets. the mellotron features large once again and the music as with epitaph relies on arrangements rather than composition. more eerie somber lyrics help to consolidate the medieval terror that qualifies this as a concept album. towards the end some of the mellotron goes out of tune - it always was a temperamental beast - but what it was capable of is admirably demonstrated here and subsequently found its way onto countless other albums of the genre and beyond. not bad for a debut.

this just seems like a highly pretentious and self-indulgent album...and i am usually a fan of pretension. 21st centurty schizoid man and moonchild are great songs. i talk to the wind and epitaph are well written but seem like songs that would prefer to hear performed by another band. the moody blues type vocals do not intrigue me at all. the ciourt of the crimson king is a horrible song. it reminds me of a renaissance fair and i do not enjoy renaissance fairs.

this is interesting and for some important. i think for shear presence of musicians and their intentions this is far better than a 1.5 star review. give me a break! then again i give things a .5 and folks love it!
60s music does not really enthrall me. well not in the way it seems to do with everyone else. i think it is down to production techniques but i am not sure. a solid album though.
i really like the opener but none of the other songs appeal me. maybe someday in another listen i will find why people praise this album so much.

some beutiful moments here are ruined by some very very boring moments. i really belive this album is good but i cannot give it higher rating because its too exhausting and tiring. the keepers here are i talk to the wind epitaph and the court of the crimson kingthe best song here
it is pretty good and all but sometimes i do not get the big deal about prog. whatever.

vastly overrated. i do not get it. this is my second kc record and i am sadly once again disappointed. being an avid pink floyd fan i hoped king crimson had that same prog beauty. unfortunately crimsons holy grail of album does not compare to the watersgilmore machine. in comparison court sounds more like ummagumma and atom heart mother - two of the floyd duds.
definitely an awesome album. nice and mellow with a great flow.

when the worst song on an album is also the longest it is never a good combination. disregarding the wankery on moonchild this is 44.5 star material. -- song-by-song - 3.9 album cohesiveness x2 - 3.9 overall - 3.9

i like the lizard album with it is jazzy noodling better than this one. i really really like epitaph and i think greg lake has the most beautiful singing voice. i do not really hate in the court of the crimson king it is just that the song has it is moments both musically and lyrically. i really do not like when the flute comes in on that tune and the chorus is kind of boring.

a great album but i do not understand all the hype surrounding this. how anyone can give an album with tracks like moonchild five stars is beyond me. sure this might be one of the first beginnings of progressive rock and so on but it does not have anything to do with the actual quality of the music. i mean 21st century schizoid man starts the album with a blast and is definitely the best track here but the rest of the material just does not equal its high standard. along with the total waste of 10 freakin minutes with moonchild the two minutes of the beginning are good by the way until it turns into a yawnfest the last track is also kind of a bore and way too long for its own good. oh the good side is that we get to hear lots and lots of mellotron here and there and epitaph is a beautiful song that would inspire many prog rock songs of the same styling. actually the songs themselves - if you do not count the schizoid man - are not all that complex or progressive in the true sense of the word they are more of psychedelic mood pieces. and i do not hear anything so mind-blowingly revolutionary here most of this mellow psychedelic stuff could have been made by i do not know the moody blues a year before the release of this album only the songs here are longer. what more can i say this is a nice first effort and they truly have a vision but if the material ranges from awesome to mediocre to dumb the result is that the album is not exactly excellent. sometimes i feel like it is only the schizoid man that keeps this ship from sinking into the sea of semi-good potential.
about as pretentious and overblown as prog rock can get. at least tracks 2 and 3 are decent. the rest of this album is laughable classic status be damned.

great calm spacey seventies music. the title track is amazing in it is simplicity and i talk to the wind is relaxing in it is quitness. it is just the songs could have been twice shorter but then it would not be called progrock i guess...good but not top 100 album with only 5 tracks!.

good and ambitious album creating very specific atmosphere. also the musicians are very skilled and tasteful at the same time. so why only 3.5? because in many cases king crimson did not know where to stop and a great song turned into some senseless noodlingmoonchild or just a snooze-festepitaph the title song. highlights 21st century schizoid man- so powerful and captivating i talk to the wind- this time mellow and captivating

alright time for me to controversial again. 4.43 from my friends rankings? seriously? i understand the influential-ness of the whole thing but a lot of the artists this influenced are making me sick here in 2008. epitaph is a great song and 21st century schizoid man is decent too. but moonchild? really? this album is just over 42 minutes long and contains 5 tracks. 12 minutes 29 and 1 track 20 of this are moonchild. this creates a barrier to me giving this a good rating.

i enjoy most the other albums 1970-1984 better than this one.. it just sort of dies out on moonchild.. even i talk to the wind.. snore city.. hippy bla blas.. fripp takes it to better places in the years to come.

influential revolutionary and a classic. this one just does not impress me as much as others. first off all i do not get what the deal is with 21st century schizoid man. i just do not get it. it is mediocre song at best as far as i am concerned. moonchild is pointless. it goes nowhere. not only that it does not sound interesting in the least. ok the other songs are brilliant. 3 out of 5 songs just does not cut it for me no matter how great the other songs are. the court of the crimson king blows my mind every time i listen to it.

the first and last songs on this are pretty top notch but the middle 3 songs are very cheesy and difficult to listen to. i would have rated this a lot worse if the opening song was not so damn good. wish the rest of the album would have been similarly good.

i am a real prog rock fan and i was turned on to this band by a friend and i have got to say that it is not without it is charm. however i just cannot seem to get into it. prog rock is something that you should get lost in but this just has some good tunes in between really boring and cheesy moments

this ended up in my collection thanks to my boyfriend. i looked up what the three best kc albums were in terms of ownership and ratings bought them and then he never listened to them or at least he is never mentioned listening to them. i had played this one simply as it was thee first in terms of chronological order decided that my thoughts about late 60searly 70s prog rock had been right all the time and that this just was not for me. i have given it a few spins over the last couple of days so that i can try and do it justice as i am reviewing it for the go review game love it and i have to say things are not improving on repeated listens. i do not mind the beginning of moonchild i suppose but most of the album just sounds aged and cloying to me and bugger me it has the most awful cover - if i ever have yet another day to waste sitting at the pc rather than having a life out there in the real world and feel the need to do a my least favourite album covers list then this will be vying for the number one spot. as you can see i am already digressing from the music in this review and that is another problem. it just sounds kind of boring to me. five minutes into moonchild and all i can hear is the sort of plinkyplonky noise that my boyfriends 2 year old godson makes. i would much rather listen to drone at least that makes sense to me.

not the masterpiece that so many people hear in it. but that is personal. i love tracks 1 4 and 5. i heard this album when i was about 8. i was digging through dads collection and the cover struck me immediately. i played and flipped! so old and yet so loud and dark. 21st century schizoid man has not aged a bit but the 4 other tracks have not aged that well. it is still good but very 60s. schizoid could have been made last week. track 5 scared the shit out of me then and it still sends shivers down my spine.

gregs lakes vocals especially schizoid man are a real highlight on this album. the wonderful chaotic instrumental passages are a real blast and that iconic cover is one of the most memorable in rock. some parts tend to drag though hence 3.5 stars
5 stelle il primo brano 2 tutto il resto.
the noodling on moonchild gets old but it is not enough to bring down this album. a masterpiece.
moments of unnecessary pomposity and insincerity are covered up by some stunningly powerful explosions of greatness. just listen to the opening riff of 21st century schizoid man fucking epic.

i probably fessed up to this before but greg lakes vocals are to me like that little spoonful of sugar which helps the medicine of progressive rock go down smooth. so it has been with anything by elp and so it is with this king crimson debut. you have to wait out the first track before lake begins to sugarcoat anything but no worries 21st century schizoid man is a worthy hurricane of an opener. i have yet to finalize any kind of definitive list of tracks that blew my doors clean off the hinges but schizoid man is on the rough draft for sure. the real big moments come on epitaph a grandiose and of course! lengthy tale of woe in which lake matches the musical mood note for note. he grieves he worries he rages against the dying of the light. as he repeats the central phrase but i fear tomorrow i will be crying a wave of hopelessness washes over the world. the title track concludes the pageantry taking epitaphs air of grand despair for a nine minute stroll through the world of macabre. the dance of the puppets sounds exactly like i would have pictured it in my mind. if i ever pictured such things.

this ones clearly a landmark in the world of art rock or whatever you want to call it. parts of it have not worn especially well though some of the extended gentle passages hit modern ears as a bit twee some of the lyrics possess too much bug-eyed fairy-world wonder. still there is much that holds up and it is unquestionably important. 21st century schizoid man kicks plenty of ass to this day and in fact one wishes the boys had taken that aggressive approach more often. moonchild and i talk to the wind sure are pretty and epitaph has its moments. and hey that distinctive to say the least album art still rules.

album que dio forma definitiva al rock progresivo aqui no se me hace un gran disco completo pero por el hombre ezquizoide del s xxiepitafio y en la corte del rey carmesi resulta ser un muy buen disco 75100

honestly this album gets three stars alone just for the title trakk. brilliant brilliant song. unfortunately for king crimson one song cannot carry a whole album to the victory line. the songs got to work together as a team you see! 21st century schizoid man is a decent opener a distorted rock song with saxophone parts. the album then falls into a ditch that takes about 26 minutes to get out of. the three middle tracks are mostly just boring boring acoustic pieces not that there is anything wrong with acoustic pieces...my father was an acoustic piece! in the court of the crimson king closes with the song  not in the court of the violet queen which is 10 minutes of pure musical bliss that just steamrollz the rest of de album. but that is not very cooperative is it. if they could have just workkd together they cud hav won this dammiot damndit iu betg my housrn an my car and my wife onb yiouj baastard dbabfh i talk tob tyhe winf you wsuick and yiu too epitpah amnd inm noit forgettjing you moon child you are bringin sthe team down dam agh you ruiknd it for xda teame and that is what a review looks like from the point of view of a person who has no conception of how a review is supposed to be written thank you for joining me
ok i just bought this because of all the high ratings here. i do not get it? not very appealing for me. i will tuck it away for later review.
moments of prettiness that are ultimately consumed by the all-encompassing fluff of it all
robert fripp is a great guitarist and the drummer is pretty good here but i just do not get what the big deal is about this band.
21st century schizoid man moon child and i talk to the wind are amazing. the rest range from forgettable to horribly overblown.
thus far the only kc album i have heard but man does this ever have a feeling about it. disturbing peaceful hopeless epic in every sense of the word.

king crimsons debut effort in the court of the crimson king should get an award for the album cover which is very cool. beyond that the album is fairly up and down. the title track the court of the crimson king is nice but not great. 21st century schizoid man has some very unique and interesting vocal work but i talk to the wind is a mellow bordering on dull track. overall i can tell these are well written songs even if they are not my thing so to speak. a good album and for prog rock aficionados i can see why it is regarded so highly.
the greatest progressive rock album there is.
if i am honest i have only listened to this once. i found it to be half brilliant and half wanky rubbish hence the middling score.
not into it that much but 21st century schizoid man is brilliant and crimson king is pretty good too. i need to digest it more i guess.

great stuff mixed in with some real crap that everyone feels that they have to accept because otherwise this shit is brilliant. but listen let us not dress this album up because it has some real blemishes. now as an album this is not a 4 out of 5 it is fucking less than that just for i talk to the wind which wish washy tripe and a 6 min waste of vinyl. and let us not even mention moonchild. which is like listening to the moody blues gang rape donovan. which is also a problem for this album. it seems a little too much inspired by days of future passed. but i am sure when your really stoned and reading lotr for the umteenth time it hardly matters. love that fuckin opener though and the album cover... fuck yeah.

21st century schizoid man seems like a combination of early heavy metal and weird jazz fusion. after that comes the pretty folk song i talk to the wind. the rest of the album stays in this folk prog realm not counting the ending of moonchild which i refuse to recognize the existence of.

i guess i am just not a prog-rock fan because this album does little to nothing for me. it is all just too damn pretentious and over-blown for me to take. i mean i do not think that i could ever bring myself to trot this shambling mound out in front of any other self-respecting music fan without being completely embarassed. i guess if it was 1969 i was hearing this for the first time and was stoned out of my brain i might be more impressed and get it. today however it alternates between making me feel embarassed that i am listening to it and making me fall asleep. the musical virtuosity is obviously not in question. the emotion and impact is though. the only situation in which i find this music appropriate is perhaps a rainy sunday afternoon when you are sitting quietly reading the newpaper or a serious novel of some sort. even then i would rather turn some good jazz on or even classical.
i like 21st century schizoid man and i talk to the wind but the rest just seems overly done and very late 70s yes

i have had it with this album. i am moving on to their later material i cannot understand what is so damned interesting about it. i am dead certain the heavy amount of praise for this record is because of the year it was put out and the amount of non-jazz heads who have been inspired by it. the actual music is great throughout but beyond the first track i am at a loss for why i would come back and re-listen. i suppose the recurring synth lines of the last track are incredibly iconic epic and angsty but the song teases a little too much for my liking.
