solid creative and very colorful this album indeed deserves its hype. 21st century schizoid man is some jazz-prog thing with that guitar theme which is often called the first stoner riff of rock music history. it is a tune you once heard and will stay with you for a lifetime. the other 4 tracks represent a different balladistic style though all of them are epic melancholic and kind of dark and romantic that i truly like - only the title track sounds too melodramatic to me. i talk to the wind is smooth and lounge still offering something sinister epitaph includes a fantastic symphonic orchestration and moonchild is a short lullaby with a 10 minute-long minimal improvisation-outro - and still i do not feel it pointless nor pretentious it totally has its place. so each song has an own character the production is rich and wonderful - if only the vocals were more in focus. the voices are pretty cool but it feels like they are a bit repressed. probably that is the only factor that keeps this album from being a favourite.
overrated. thoroughly groundbreaking but ultimately not very compelling.

i used to be a huge fan of progressive rock and i still enjoy a fair number of albums and bands grouped into the genre but i am not as keen on this album as some of my fellow fans are. this album has quite the reputation and on three tracks i think it lives up to it. epitaph and the court of the crimson king are great tracks and highly worth listening to and 21st century schizoid man is a prog masterpiece a definitive song of the movement that took my breath away when i first heard it and still amazes me to this day. definitely a song for the ages. unfortunately the other two songs really let the album down. i talk to the wind meanders with little to stimulate the ears but the album still could have made 4 or 4.5 stars if it were not for the tragedy that is moonchild. to call it simply boring would be an insult to all truly boring songs out there. it is so beyond boring and bland that i simply can only describe it as nothing. a complete waste of time. how king crimson could go from the excellence of 21st century schizoid man to the nothingness of moonchild is simply beyond me. despite this fact the album is still highly worth owning both for its place in history and the excellent material it does contain.
i bought a lot of highly recommended records such as this one in the 80s when people were getting rid of vinyl. some were great finds but this just does not work for me.

this is not a classic album in my book - moonchild is a complete waste of 12 minutes and has cost this album 1 point. unfortunately this trend would carry on until robert fripp teamed up with bill bruford and john wetton.
i like the title track but i am pretty bored by most of the rest of it although i have only listened to the full album twice so maybe after a few more listens...

there is a scene in the film buffalo 66 where christina riccis character tap dances in a bowling ally to king crimsons moonchild. it is a poignant scene in the film where vincent gallos character sees only her not the other distractions of the bowling ally and realizes the girl that he kidnapped is the girl for him. having been a fan of king crimson for nearly 20 years i did not recognize and had to look up the beautiful song when i re-watched the movie recently. out of the context of the album moonchild seemed completely foreign and that is kind of indicative of my opinion of in the court of the crimson king. moonchild begins as a pretty quiet pastoral ballad for about two minutes before shifting to a 10 minute improvisation which is not always entirely successful or interesting. there are four elements that i think make this album great though - elements 1  2 are the songs that bookend the beginning and end of the album. 21st century schizoid man is great heavy proto-metal while the title track that closes the album is grandiose. - element 3 the mellotron. what a cool instrument! it used short tape loops of strings flutes etc and was sort of the original sampler. i only really learned what a mellotron was in the past few years i thought there were string arrangements on the album for years. not a bad-ass keyboard. - element 4 that cover. that is absolute terror. how shocking this must have looked in 1969. legend has it the artist died only weeks after the album was released. like moonchild this album is not a total success. it has moments where it is great and moments when it is not so great. and there is a middle part that always makes me space out and forget what album i am playing.

i guess i have never been in the right mood or frame of mind for this album. yes i appreciate it but no i do not exactly salivate over it like other people. reputations aside in the court of the crimson king may have a kind of substance but for whatever reason it just washes right on through me. opener 21st century schizoid man has some great musical phrases that are wound around and around. but then comes i talk to the wind which is kind of just there just blah ballooned up and all fluffy and sweet with that flute like some prog rock serving of cotton candy and that is when i start to nod off. zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz... yes it may be nice but so what? the first few minutes of epitaph could use a few more herbs too all i am tasting from the pot there is a few bland boiled spuds barely seasoned with the salty dry drone of the vocalist and moving on up to around the four or five minute mark there is thankfully a few tidbits swimming around but it is otherwise keeping me hungry. moonchild is so spartan and so benign that while it probably has its niche as background music for falling asleep in being so subtle and random it almost becomes irrelevant. particularly when this goes on for twelve minutes. i do not know about all you but i have a life with other things to do rather than sit listless to this for so long. thankfully the court of the crimson king brings the album back to some semblance of listenability. so alright it is okay. i would not say it lives up to the hype though. yes yes maybe i just do not get it and i am fine with that.

i was told this was progressive type stuff. that it is. pretty bearable though. points off for that moonchild bland epic though. pretty decent the rest of it. you like this sort of thing a lot you are likely to give it 2 more stars.

yet another record i lost during a massive vinyl kidnapping. i think the thing i liked best about this album was the cover not only was it massively cool but it was fuzzy and fun to look at. okay so the music was quite decent although i am not a progressive music fan it still appealed in many ways. 21st century schizoid man was a really great tune in fact it seemed heavy in an entirely different way than i am used to but that is what made it neat. the music is rather epic it is got plenty of drive and the various instrumentation rarely seems overdone which is a rarity for this style of thing. this may only have five rather long songs on it but it is got a nice flow to it and every song included is at least decent. aside from the biggie in the court of the crimson king was my favorite but there is definitely plenty to like on here the sort of dark layer to everything makes it worthwhile. this may not be my kind of music but it is my kind of album one of the few in the genre that everyone should be able to like!

this album has great songs on it but they are too long -- even aside from moonchild two minutes of song ten minutes of tinkly noises. i say this as a big fan of prog rock including lots of long songs. this album actually sees about as much play from me now as red which was the first kc album i bought this was second -- that is to say not much. i liked both of them quite a good deal after getting them but they have sort of seeped into my brain to the point that actually listening to these albums does not really excite me anymore. fripp is quite tasteful here not that i mind most of his freakouts lakes pretty good whichever giles mike? it is who drums does so well and pete sinfeld is pete sinfeld. ian mcdonald was probably the true driving force here -- certainly his keyboards have a higher prominence than such things usually do especially on a king crimson album. it is just that those little textures that help make an album great seem here to have been confined to a caged death match for control of moonchild. there is some good playing but really this is closer to something like cream than a lot of people realize... there is just a jazz spin on it.
some extraordinary bits the first two songs and some pretentious bits on this debut by prog-art-rock kings.
fripp-a-dip.good but kind of snurly.that might not be a real word but snurly just about covers it.

when i was a tot my dad kept his records in an old antique oak chest in the sitting room. i used to be fascinated by this chest and would often nose through all the dusty vinyls studying the myriad of colourful and psychedelic images that adorned his mostly sixites based collection. this was probably before i could even read properly. to me all those gatefold albums were like giant picture books. then one day i came across this. the front cover freaked me out a little. that guy looks kind of distressed. but that was nothing compared with when i opened up the gate and holy fuck this moonfaced acid fried freak of an image was staring out at me with a doped out glare of such evil malice i might possibly have wet myself there and then. for whatever reason that image stayed with me and for a month i had nightmares about moonface. he would be stalking in my room late at night possessed by some strange intoxicating madness ready to steal me from my bed and drag me underground with all the other moonface folk. to this day that image makes me feel so fucking... uneasy. ahem. this is quite a good album by the way.
on paper it should be a brilliant album but it just comes off too childish to work. the first song 21st century schizoid man with mirrors is the best.

i do not know if it is mostly for nostalgic reasons but i really enjoy this album. it has a certain dreamy feel to it and luckily frippco. did not drown the compositions or theme of the album in their usually boring proggy guitar riffs and bombastic solos.

this is a very historically important album. it is not my favourite king crimson release though. here is how i feel when i listen to it track 1 right on! track 2 nyah. not bad. track 3 zzzzzzzz. track 4 huh!? oh yah zzzzz. track 5 sweet! in the end you are left wonder just how good the album was because you did not really absorb half of it. i would rather listen to bill bruford era king crimson. larks tongues in aspic red and discipline are just the beginning of the amazing output he was part of.

i have tried god knows i have tried to love king crimson. i am so tired of people telling me that if i like yes i should adore king crimson down to robert fripps rockin guitar stool. and yes there are two -- two! -- brilliant tracks here 21st century schizoid man and the court of the crimson king. yet i also hear a flacid jam titled moonchild an overwrought epitaph and a limp ballad i talk to the wind. there is just something chilly and misanthropic about most of the music here that leaves me cold. let us face it it are not no ummagumma. and i think i prefer yes to crimson because yes is always at bottom no matter how pretentious a pop group. but i would give fripps exposure album a handy five stars. go figure.

it might be over-produced it sounds very constructed. but overall it is a very impressive and creative album. the first hip-hop album i actually enjoyed and that gave me hope i might maybe one day appreciate the genre. only 3.5 stars because i really have a problem appreciating hiphop this album included. it is a genre i always found very non musical and uninteresting. the whole talking and posing thing the bombastic lyrics i could never suffer them. but it might grow on me more hopefully. musically it is nothing incredible but definitely it is interesting and well produced. lots of interesting sound effects and rhythms it is definitely more diverse and catchy than most hiphop albums.

tm levy sattumalta osui minulle tubesa ja sen kuuntelin lpi nyt tn pivn niin tytyy sanoa ett osittain pidn ja osittain en mutta kun vlill se kaupallisuus menee sinne huonolle puolelle eli painotan kuuntelijan aliarviointia kun mennn vlill sielt miss aita matalalla ja setelinkuvat silmiss mentaliteetilla kosiskellen isoja massoja ns huonolla kaupallisella tavalla ja ei sellaisia kohtia jaksa oikein kuunnella mutta vlill musajutut on parempia joten albunmi jtt vhn neutraalin fiilikset minulle mutta 35 on hyv arvosana johon ei aina kaikki yll. musiikillisesti bndi kyll on lahjakas tytyy kehua siit. rauhoittaa mys mielen aika ajoin. kotona bndi parhaimmillaan hitaissa ja puolihitaissaja yksi biisi jonkun verran leijuvan tuntuinen jotenki se on tosi hyv eli viittaan biisiin institutionalized joka on minusta levyn jopa kirkkaasti paras teos.
used to like this more until i learned of better rappers draingang and sadboys.

i have given this album so many chances over the years as i do with a lot of massively popular and highly rated albums just to make sure i am really not missing anything or that it will one day click with me. sadly that click rarely happens and i got to chalk it up to just different taste. sellmeagods review puts it best when they said to pimp a butterfly is an intriguing album and cultural event that reveals less with more listening when people talk about this album it always feels like they are talking about the idea of it rather than the actual music. i cannot deny the ambition of kendrick on this album but it really comes across as him doing a whole lot to say very little. his flows are on point he occasionally has a poignant lyric but half the time it feels like he is just filling space. brevity is a virtue for me and this album seems to have everything except that. almost every song could have been at least 1 minute shorter. luckily this is a problem he fixed on his followup damn. - which makes it a much better album in my opinion i think the overarching theme of the album was kind of interesting but its not a pleasant experience hearing i remember you was conflicted after every single song. i get it you do not need to spoonfeed me the concept line by line because it just kills any momentum that the few great songs on here have. its a decent album with a mixed bag of songs ranging from amazing to just plain sleepy. the album cover tricks you into believing this is a rebellious or transgressive work of art but the majority of the content is just plain inoffensive which should be evident by the obama cosign. feels like this is massively overrated by white people who want to prove how much they think black lives matter or how woke they are when i could name at least 30 rap albums more deserving of a 3 overall ranking but are not as politically correct

...i truly do not get how this has the status it does this album is always seen as some grandiose political statement that it simply is not. the music itself is great and we all know kendrick does the raps the singles own in particular. i just think it is hollow. it never goes beyond losing obama almost a verbatim bar and such. for me kendrick was always better on the smaller scale. i love gkmc to bits because it is a small-scale hood documentary that truly is one of the best ever at what it does. this is trying to be massive. it is not massive and at severe risk of targeting the rym userbase not at all as politically profound as many many of the older acclaimed albums you know the ones. this review is garbage i am drunk and feel ill edit it is genuinely a bit upsetting that this is considered the best political album on here. its his flashiest i get it but has almost nothing to say that literally all his other records do not do better and kendrick has never had that much to say in the first place the reason good kid m.a.a.d city is so good is because it is humble and does what it does really well. this tries to do it all and achieves little i just realized i said the same thing before but whatever. god that fucking poem bit at the end of every song is obnoxious and the conclusion is even more so unrewarding as fuck. dude 2pac lmao. i am sure that was epic to someone the first time they heard it so fantastic for them but are people still really getting mindblown by that? treads the line between being zoomer music and oldhead i.e reactionary music so hard that i guess it makes sense but fuck me this would be such a shit 1.

i remember playing this for the first time when it dropped. i was shocked by how many songs i did not care for minus alright. i tried to get into it that year but just could not. i ended up shelving it until 2021 and gave it another more in depth listen. good kid mad city and damn are definitely better than this release. the production just is not as good. i do not think most of these beats were that great when it was released and especially now. the album just never reached the highpoints his other releases did. too many beats that are just generic sounding or average. the rhyming is there but the production falters. these beats sound like watered down version of the music groups like blackalicious was making in the early 2000s. some of these hooks are irritating as well. i am surprised how much hype this got then and still. lyrically at times it feels like i am being preached too or it is almost a diary at times for himself. the insight is nice but it harms replay value. i love public enemy but you got to be in the right mood to play certain kinds of music and after you hear this release a few times the concept is very apparent.
beautiful album beautiful beat i love life and myself

i have talked about how the wall by pink floyd is one of the most over rated albums of all time. it is a good album but i am beginning to hate it because people ignore it is obvious flaws. to pimp a butterfly is in the same category as the wall. it is great jazzy conscious hip hop. but to say it is perfect is a stretch. it is a slog. the repeating poem wears thin and the pay off is not interesting in my opinion. institutionalized hood politics and momma are not enjoyable. the interludes are also not great. b-b-b-b-but the lyrical content is important. yeah i agree. does not make it good though. maybe i have just become worn out when it comes to this album. every hip hop circle is just 16 year old white kids telling you how perfect this album is and that it is the best album of all time.

continue with the third act........... reviewing every single fantano 1010 albums that he gave 3 to pimp a butterfly. my goal is to review every single fantano 1010 albums that he gave since he started his youtube channel. not even a full year later fantano dropped another untimely 1010 bomb on the internet. this time the bomb incredible huge. fantano review of tpab is by far his most watched video on his video on his channel. so now to the review. this album is means a lot to me. hip hop is the first music genre i listen to and surprisingly to pimp a butterfly was the first album i have ever listen to. i started listening to albums early march of 2021 back then i did not know much about music. the only music i heard was the most popular songs on radio and meme songs. it did not spark my interest in music at all. everything changed one day in march i heard to pimp a butterfly for the first time. before that i was listening to spotify keep repeating wesley theory and humble on repeat. at the time i never knew that to pimp a butterfly was so highly praise. i just enjoy a couple of kendricks songs. unexpectedly i had another level of enjoyment in music that i never had. the music was so catchy that keep me intrigued the whole time without knowing any lyrics that kendrick was actually rapping about. i just love his voice love what music i heard. in my opinion to pimp a butterfly is like a diary. as 16 tracks is about kendrick lamar life living as a colored person in the united states. as kendrick lamar explains topics about love family things he faced in life as a kid. this album blends everything black music culture such as jazz soul and funk. as jazz samples are all over the album. with incredible very chopped jazz samples and kendrick smooth flow fits perfectly. as kendrick lamar writes his diary every single day. he gone through the brightest and darkest moments in life. to pimp a butterfly is very relatable to me. kendrick lamar on this album is just a normal person as kendrick lamar used songs to shows his progression in life. with the first track of wesley theory explains about kendrick meeting love for the first time explaining his raw deep feelings about it. the track king kunta showing how he is so proud living in compton. the following track institutionalized with bilal and snoop dogg protrays as his grandparents their impression about kendrick lamar. the track these walls with kendrick lamar expressing about love and sex like a normal person. he is very sincere about everything he said. but noticing that the girl he just fucked is a bitch and actually does not care about him which is quite heartbroken if you ask me. the track you fixed perfectly on the next track with kendrick lamar expressing his anger after suffering some problems in life. as the track alright is more than a protest song. this track is an encouragement song with kendricks parents encourage him not to give up with its heartwarming after knowing the previous kendrick lamar at his lowest and darkest point. after the track momma we reached teenage kendrick. as kendrick started knowing about politics as he realise his life was not actually that good as he thought. the track hood politics with kendrick lamar just mocking and do not give a fuck up about politics. but the track the black the berry is oppositing as he express his issues about the police killing innocent black people and expressing his honest thoughts about it. this track is where the emotion got to and all time high. as the lyrics in the black the berry goes i am the biggest hypocritic of 2015. some tracks such as how much a dollar cost and complexion are things that kendricks experience that he encounter in his life. as the track how much a dollar cost as he met a homeless person chasing him just to get money to live explaining how unfair the world is to everyone. the track complexion as talking about complex things in life with forgiveness is given as it determine by your skin color. as he express he is proud being a black person. as the track i kendrick lamar goes on stage and give a confident speech and a performance. as his diary is complete 15 tracks in. as the last track mortal person talking about forgiveness and accountability about peoples mistakes such as michael jackson doing shitty stuff and still be forgiven as innocent and power justice that nelson mandela brought independence to south africa. it is just sad. the music slows down and kendrick lamar reads his diary to tupac shakur. a person that kendrick lamar admired a lot. tupac and kendrick lamar are talking casually as tupac mentioned about black people has 5 years to live otherwise they would be trap in controlled by rich white people. kendrick lamar ended the album with a poem of explaining the title of the album to pimp a butterfly. the album is an entire full circle. this album truly means a lot me. i get emotional when listening to this and had appreciation listening to music. to pimp a butterfly changed my way i listen to music music has a true meaning. its not just fun music and also could impact peoples life and i am of those people who got impacted by this album. i have no words of this album i love this album in my heart after listening to the entire album three different times yet every track feels special and unique. he used previous ideas pioneer by the roots and a tribe called quest yet made their ideas into perfection with this album. kendrick lamar is one of my favourite musician of all time. kendrick lamar is the best rapper to ever touch the mic. he impacted how music could be used. i will always love this album forever. fav tracks wesleys theory for free? king kunta insitutionalized these walls you alright for sale? interlude momma hood politics how much a dollar cost complexion a zulu love the blacker the berry you are not got to lie momma said i mortal man least fav tracks na 1010 perfect album

i think it goes without saying that a huge portion of this albums critical success is due to stupid american politics. to no ones surprise i suppose hip hop has always thrived as political commentary. i think this album is incredibly overrated but i do not think it is bad. i will say the lyrical themes i do appreciate on this album are the ones concerning mental health. from a pure sonic perspective this album succeeds in incorporating a vast array of musical influences and is often just really satisfying to listen to. of course it needs to be said this album is 1h18m long and at least half of that is filler. this is a common issue i find with hip hop albums. to name a few favourites the intense and emotional you the aggressive the blacker the berry and the unique and interesting king kunta.

this is a good album it is about kendrick lamar screaming at white people in a funny voice. of course being the masochists that they are white people grew to love this album especially the ones that look like this  however i already heard this done better before it is this little album called black on both sides you might have heard of it it is the album that is this but better in every way and made 20 years earlier but this has a poem about 2pac in it that unfolds throughout the record. because of that this is deeper than other albums that came out in 2015 according to critics. you know the year that tetsuo  youth and days with dr yen lo came out. good job tourists you were wrong again. this album is funky and jazzy which is rare in rap nowadays so it gets a 710 by default.

i love kendrick i even love this album but it just is one that can be super hard to digest. i have to work to listen to it and that is not bad but it does mean that i find myself coming back to this album less than others in his discog. the album as a whole is super important and i get why it is so loved i just find it hard to listen to in full at times where as gkmc and damn are more relistenable
most overrated album on the rym charts just insanely overhyped and overshadowed by gkmc.

this is that kind of rap for intellectuals praise of which i do not understand. that kind of rap rich and educated 25-30yos play at the parties convinced it is banger but actually forcing half of the less unique people to leave or at least to change the room. to be honest i could not find anything interesting about this album except its political message. it is drastically overproduced and hi-budget but at the same time it is not catchy at all. also it is full of useless jazziness in some tracks. lamars rapping is good but these songs are completely uninteresting. still it is not that bad that i would be the person who is leaving the party or complain about music. i just do not get it.

you cannot talk about this album without the term album of the decade being thrown about. finally i have listened to the album that seems to be the most unanimous decision for the best album of the 2010s and unfortunately i think it is a 7.5 out of 10. unforunately? yes unfortunately. if there is been one artist that is been a pain to listen to in recent discography runs it would have to be kendrick. this man is hailed as some kind of god when it comes to his craft and there is something about his music that is understandably different perhaps the increased jazz influences that are present are a big enough differentiating factor or the mans idiosyncratic voice. something is missing for me. i think it sounds undoubtedly good but i wanted great amazing superb to be the descriptors i would use here. this album feels to me at least like perfect background music. maybe that is sacrilege but i just could not fully connect with it and i find that to be a real shame. or maybe my expectations were way too high because of everything i had heard about this album. regardless this album is basically essential at this point so go listen to it. i mean it is an average rating of 4.24 at the time of writing this so i am in the minority. go enjoy this. rating - 7.5

obama rap in which k-dot points out the pertinent political issues facing the black american and subsequently retreats into personal ennui - weaponising bourgeois identity politics to mask the clear lack of ideas and structural criticism that define great conscious rap albums. the beats still sound fresh though

no highlights like there on gkmc.. wesleys theory got a 4.6 rating ?!! this rating should be given to absolute classics.. not a song with zombie noises and sexed up burps.. moreover kendricks vocal here is little annoying and less diverse than that on gkmc.. it sounds pretentiously harsh all over the record and misses his softfun characteristic vocal that can be found on his earlier releases.. the production and delivery in total are not that interesting and can get boring oftentimes.. 510

1  5 in the mid 2010s hip hop became a mainstream sensation and kendrick lamar lead that expedition. everyone was hyping up his steps. this record transformed his image he quickly fell from man of the future to man of the hour literally the one who tied the present and the past. the very concept of the record making an ode to all black music up until that point weighted so much promotionally that suffocated his idea of self in innovation. the record is structurally confusing ultra pretentious and well produced at the same time a weird and rare combination. it is an undeniable epic that forced mainstream enthusiasts into an actual experience if anything it could be praised for that. definitely a faux masterpiece.

kendrix we love you but cmon dude. what the heck is this? brother we been in the shit. i dislike the ratatap tap of the drums i hate the voice of kendrix but i had to listen. i loved the second track most holy crap it was mediocre but everything else made me get hurt in the head. i cannot listen to music i need pills this is thanks to kendrix.

lots of tracks on here help to paint a picture of an individual trapped in a violent society who sees their only way out as lsd. the production here directs a specific image and meaning akin to ok computer dark sid eof the moon and a night at the opera. thus the production is on point but takes away a lot of the fun from music as i see it it is interpretive nature. this is an album hell bent on making a point. the only song that gets above this is the masterpiece the blacker the berry. it is a step above all other songs here in both concept and meaning. overall this album is packed with top-down songs and vulnerable expressions. tightly wrapped in a well developed concept with humility brings the whole album to 4.5.

kendrick sure improved with this album because good kid maad city was boring and here the music is better. the beats are more diverse and creative and the rapping sure improved his voice is a little less squeaky in this album and the jazz influence is cool but this album certainly is far from being a masterpiece. decent album but not even close to a masterpiece.

to pimp a butterfly 2015 by kendrick lamar is not unlike a basketball game. according to mr. lamar the nba finals are now contested between the sixers and the warriors. mr. lamar is about to enter that tense moment. he has written an op-ed piece for the local media. it does not go well. that is the world that he has created for himself. now he finds himself in the path of a fast-moving ocean. his younger sister jessie is pregnant with his son who will become a future member of the nba. now he must choose between his basketball and his family. to pimp a butterfly is a devastatingly compassionate piece of work. but for someone who is continually hidden under a gown which makes her almost invisible to the public the drag queens true name remains one of the most intimate secrets of her public life. kendricks personal journey to on fleek as well as the evolution from child stars to rock star. listen in as kendrick takes listeners through the most epic moments of his amazing career including his acclaimed songwriting career his battles with depression and addiction his rise to the top of the rap game and now the pivotal moment of his marriage. he has come a long way since then to be on this list but he has only gotten better over the years. much like cookie monster brian has seemed to grow a lot over the years. in conclusion kendrick lamar or anyone else has shown that the relevance of hebrew and its use and meaning is the number one selling point to a lot of music fans. with his considerable fame and influence a lot of his music has gone through a much longer process of translation and meanings than other work. with his western fanbase for them the work comes from the heart and they admire his impeccable line skill and professional execution. but the german rapper still has a lot of work to do in terms of giving back to the world with his upcoming album revival which is expected to be released in january.

mostly noise. i do not understand how people this to this shit? kendricks also used far too many samples making this album very unoriginal. i really have no interest in hearing a small portion of a classic 60s song in the middle of a hip-hop song just sounds fucking awful to me and whenever i hear these samples it ruins the song for me. i enjoyed king kunta and the blacker the berry when i first listened to them but that was when i was 16 and those songs have not aged well at all king kunta is boring and has no replay value. fuck you kendrick.

i believe what makes to pimp a butterfly so revered is the fact that it is simply a really flexible rich concept album with a clear steady and extensive narrative that goes great with the music and the lyrics. what is more impressive is the way kendrick mixes personal struggles with identity various life shifts ideal changes and match them to near perfection against the struggles of his people which gives depth to each and every song. the use of jazz in the fore and background in this record also helps emphasize strong senses of ethnicality imbued through and through implying thoughts of roots and foundations. as exhaustive and terrifyingly ambitious as this record seems at first it is however entirely encased in a very grounded accent as if made and written by someone who is spent the last 25 years in a prison cage alone with various contemplations jaded yet sneakily hopeful. it is both sincere and boastful it is maddening and sweet at the same time. these constant malleable overtones of duality can be seen most clearly in the very lucid egocentric verses and poetic insanities that dominate the closing track. to pimp a butterfly might not be the exact cup of tea for lovers of good kid m.a.a.d city as it might be too serious too sombre or whatever have you but as a work of art it has surpassed its prequel per se. it is genius creative insightful vivid wonderful and absolutely shocking in a good way. i strongly recommend you give this gem more than one replay. highlights king kunta mortal man alright the blacker the berry how much a dollar cost wesleys theory i lowlights for free? interlude for sale? interlude complexion a zulu love you are not got to lie momma said

packed with commanding performances ambitious sonics and a who is-who of contributors from anna wise to clinton to thundercat butterfly is a massive presentation. lamar is superlative pulling an arsenal of choice samples and jazzy interludes to accent his trademark variable-flow delivery musicians and guests applying themselves passionately to an album that screams out the plight of 21st century african american life. creating backdrops to diverse themes like the seduction of fame depression hypocrisy black-on-black violence and multi-angle views of racism butterfly is a surreal experience of cleverly connected songs. it is a clich but the effect of the spoken-word interludes intros outros and complex arrangements are truly cinematic like a movie of the mind. it is preachy and full of shifting moods but despite all of the expressions of discontent he packs in some next-level jams. king kunta transforms the darkest subject matter into the sickest beat pure west coast groove  funky as all getout. these walls is more of the same smooth and scintillating with mellow jazzy flourishes splashing against an irresistible tempo and complexion is absolutely gorgeous languid soul-drenched loops against layered vocals that resolve in rhapsodys crescendo-like rap finale. it is an album that requires a certain mood to digest. there is a lot to unpack but like most top-tier concept records it reveals its true gold time and time again over multiple listens. undoubtedly one of the most daring hip hop records of the last ten years.

listen kendrick let us make things clear here. i appreciate your intentions. seriously. on paper an ambitious convoluted and lush concept rap album on the struggles of modern america seems like a really orgasmic idea concluding it with an interview to 2pac filling it with tons of little self-referencing details building an entire world and imaginary in it all can be really intelligent ideas. you are very good at writing lyrics i admit that. i have not read much but for what i have read  purely regarding your verses  i have liked that. but we are not there. we are not there at all. the songs often seem to be completely directionless feel like totally devoid of purpose. let us say it loud and clear you can stay on beat and maybe you have even got poetry inside of you but musically you suck. the beat is almost always basic and without elements of interest not to say usually constructed on a heinous usage of tacky synths. the construction of the song is always fragmented interrupted by every kind of bullshit ugly soul-ish choirs useless samples several scene tricks without any logical sense to them like that sort of mini-recitation at the start of for sale?? what even was that? that leave you absolutely nothing. nothing at all. you cannot maintain pathos for more than what thirty seconds? and how many refrains can i remember after this listen? the one from king kunta the one from wesleys theory the one from alright maybe the one from these walls? and the rest? zero. and let us not talk about the delivery for gods sake. do you know why i stopped reading your lyrics more or less at the 6th or 7th song? because your timbre and the way you interpret flow make me puke. consequently i could not care less about what exactly you are saying since the base level of emotional engagement the immediate one is irreparably lost already. for gods sake not a time where you let energy rise not a time where you come close to a visceral mood not a time where you take some courage in your hands. the main noble exception is the blacker the berry which in fact is by a wide margin one of the most spot on songs in the whole album. on there you look like someone who has something to say. the rest of the time you just sit there and babble some gibberish with your tone that feels almost mocking always annoying and let me say that to you buddy you come in one ear and you come out the other. without leaving a trace. not one time the arrangements pull out some magic trick some wildcard. if all your songs were arranged with the same creativity of i or for free this would be a good album. but it is not. it is a collection of songs perfectly designed to leave you nothing. you get exceptions sure but they feel like oases in the desert. a desert that much like a real one leaves you with a nasty dry feeling in your mouth. i am sure that if i were black  or paradoxically even just had english as my main tongue  i would have sensed more on my skin your very struggle maybe i would have forgiven the countless imprecisions that make to pimp a butterfly a mediocre record or maybe they would have had less importance maybe i could have closed an eye on some stuff. sadly this is not the case and for me you are  and apparently will always be since not even when i put myself into it i can bring myself to like you  an embarrassingly mediocre musician. i swear on god that if one day you make a record where beats song constructions arrangements etc. are made by someone else and you only take care of the rapping i swear that i will give you another chance. until then get out of my sight. italian version spoiler click to read

the way he juxtaposes jazz with hip hop makes for a cool sound on a number of tracks although the album overall is clearly in the hip hop genre - there is not much of what i would call genre bending or fusion going on here. these walls is a pretty good straight pop track. many of the lyrics are political which is a turn off to me even if i agree with the politics. there are plenty of niggas and bitches referenced on this too - par for the course for this genre. if that does not bother you or you find it liberating it is not an issue. some of the tracks are funny. overall really cool sounds decent variety in the musical approach the singingrapping is ok but nothing special. i need to get to know this better but it does not stand out as anything special after a few listens.

make no mistake no other album from this decade will be remembered as fondly as this album by the public at large. it represents the focus on mainstream hip-hop as well as a greater focus on large-scale social consciousness and political activism. this album presents itself as a personal reflection of african-american culture and its place in culture at large in america. however after reading into the album one inch below the surface you can see that it is anything but the grand presentation it puts on. to pimp a butterfly is the epitome of woke capitalism and an effort to manufacture politics like another product. the main strength of the album that is referenced in many reviews is the lyrical contents of the album. outside of any evaluation of the content of these lyrics it must be affirmed that there is a difference between lyrics and music. lyrical contents will never replace musical expression. poetry is not music and when expressing a means to make art it is the duty of the artist to determines the greatest medium to express their artistic desires. if this albums only redeeming quality is lyrical content no matter how good that lyrical content is is not fit to be music. the transformation of the poetry created into song must be seen as the commercialization of creativity it is. of course there is more to this album than the lyrical contents which will be explored in more depth later in the review. the production is praised on this album for the use of funk rb jazz and soul samples with live instrumentation from artists like kamasi washington. this is where the first failure of many critics emerges in evaluating tpab. this is not to say the production overall is negative on the album. in fact the first third of the album has some great cuts on it. the first three tracks are representative of what i think many people think of when reflecting on the album. however this production only declines as the album continues. the second half of the album is riddled with generic rb elements. with all of the different influences from african-american culture trying to get their moment in the spotlight the album fails to form a melodic identity. tpab is to an overview of black music as it is a small world after all is to a college seminar on history. on a single sitting these elements of genre tourism become irksome to say the least. with every track in the album clocking in at an average 4-5 minutes tpab is an endurance marathon with a final 12-minute ego jerk as kendrick has a make-believe interview with the legendary deceased rapper 2-pac. the double album has the material to make one 1010 single lp but that is not what is presented. the real focus of the album the lyrics come off as artificial at best. any real insight in this album is a repeat of what kendrick already stated more eloquently in his previous album. the newer lyrical parts of the album come off as a milquetoast version of fear of a black planet by public enemy. the themes of african empowerment are so much stronger from public enemy that is a wonder that it has not received as positively as this album. it could be perhaps that kendricks lyrics are political but hip enough not to draw heavy critique. in this sense this album presents what is already safe to say and accepted by a large portion of the public. it is an expression of the mainstream and the establishment. this album presents a revolution. this revolution has been televised and whored to the masses brought to you by the same label as imagine dragons maroon 5 and carly rae jepsen.

si bowie cohen o coltrane resucitasen y viesen que en los mejores discos de la historia est este disco hecho por un sucedneo de msico que no sabe tocar el tringulo y que est por encima de cualquier disco de ellos probablemente volveran a morirse de un soponcio. y es que....la ignorancia es gratis y votar en rateyourmusic tambin-

this album is not bad but it is a bit overrated. the lyrics are not that great and the instruments are decent but not more than any rock or jazz record. it is not 1010. it is more like 6.5 - 710. in mortal man i think the album misses a chance to have a great finish kendrick yelling pac at finish. it is a 10 minute length songpoem decided to 2pac. and other songs are actually about gold diggers and how obama is not care about black people at all. it has plenty of good songs but it is not 1010. come on people...

published through the same label as maroon 5 imagine dragons tokio hotel or selena gomez -- and it is showing. calculated and trite pop-oriented sound without an ounce of the freshness and urgency golden age hip hop had. after the very good opener and decent follow-ups the album sinks into indistinct hibernation and never awakens again. monotone politically aware rapping over equally sleepy jazz instrumentals inbetween some run-of-the-mill rb and party songs. is this supposed to be the best music had in store in 2015 one of the best albums of all time?
i completely understand the praise it gets but some of the music just is not for me. lyricism is definitely at a top tier level though. deserves the reputation it has.

this album is full of juvenile lyrics that i cannot get into and the music if you can call it that was repetitive and obnoxious. a few synthesized chords on a repetitive cycle how did this guy get a record contract? i know because there is enough people out there that think this is cool.

i know this is viewed as kendricks best work but i am not big on this album. i can see why it is so well-liked though. the production is very good and the album feels cohesive. however the musical style throughout much of this album jazz rap soul is just not something i enjoy very much. the highlights on this album are very strong though. 6.210

butterfly is objectively engaging - it is a long and varied record. the blacker the berry is staggeringly furious and i found myself listening to it again and again before sitting down with the whole album. when i did i was thrown by the endless backing vocals the densely poppy vocoder shite and lamars odd propensity for changing his own voice which is irritating. as a confection it is overwhelming it is massive sprawling there is about a billion collaborators on like every song and by the end of the rambling mortal man and the rich hip hop kaleidoscope that this album is i found myself longing for the sober focus that so caught me on berry. hell of an achievement though and i am not at all denying it deserves its lofty critical perch.

admito sem nenhuma vergonha que quando o disco do kendrick lamar foi sugerido eu j torci o nariz. detesto hype them cima de qualquer tipo de msica o tipo de coisa que acontece o tempo todo alguma revista ou site nos dias de hoje grande e descolada elogia logo os hipsters comeam a gostar e de repente todo mundo  entendido da msica do sujeito e them pouco tempo o disco se torna a melhor coisa que j foi desovada nesse mundo. pra mim isso  exatamente o que eu sinto quando o nome kendrick lamar aparece them qualquer lugar. de certa forma eu no estou errado to pimp a butterfly est longe de ser a abominao que eu estava esperando mas tambm est h anos de luz de ser a obra-prima que todos clamam ser. eu no sou o mais entendido them hip hop ento obviamente minha base para comparao  pequena. mas no geral eu ouo msica ouvindo a msica e no tentando fazer comparao com o prximo grande nome e tentando ser o entendido no assunto. no ouo o tipo de msica que kendrick lamar faz e no pretendo comear a ouvir aps este disco. nada mudou. o disco  longo demais diversos momentos poderiam ter sido limados para criar um disco com maior unidade. as letras? o pouco que eu realmente prestei ateno no me diz nada. resumindo ok. no mudou a minha vida e o hype no foi sustentado.

it is a damn good album with a lot of good tracks including wesleys theory king kunta institutionalized alright the blacker the berry and hood politics. that being said it is clearly not perfect and a lot of you are either a. praising it because you feel like you have to for some reason or b. have not listened to a lot of music especially hip hop. maybe it is both but this album has clear shortcomings and is inferior to a whole lot of other hip hop albums. much of it sounds overbearing and this is coming from a jazz fan. sometimes the music flat out does not serve the song even if it is well crafted. for instance in wesleys theory which i do like to reiterate kendrick raps like he is trying to cram as much as possible. also the music is an odd choice paired with the intended subject matter. yeah it is funk with a george clinton feature and all but why? i am confused with what i am suppose to feel with the track? just energetic? it is like ideas were considered before actual effective use of the medium. he incorporated funk and i get it is a black genre i get funk is basically a genre that warps and bends which kendrick is trying to do clearly given the title of the album and wesleys theorys lyrics cover how things are going to change with a black perspective but it flat out feels and sounds out of place. alot of this album works better in theory than execution. you want to make an angry song you get some anger in that sound like in blacker the berry. some tracks just do not nail down the feeling. also the lyrics are not that dope folks. there are a lot of contrived annoying stuff going on booboo? how he raps on you? mortal man?. flows are fine i have heard better from a lot of other releases check the extinction agenda nocturnal hell even atrocity exhibition. finally the general idea of this album is not that hard to get to. i do not know how this is perceived as genius. digable planets did this in a more clever and better way with blowout comb in the last millennium. still though kendrick is dope and even though there are clear flaws even in songs i like a lot it is still cool when it works and though it is not a transcendent unbelievably perfect release it is still dope. now shut up and just bob your heads and stop being so overly dramatic

considering all the praise this album gets i was expecting a masterpiece however this is not the case. the album certainly starts off strong with wesleys theory and for free being the best tracks on the album. unfortunately for the most part it only goes downhill from here. this album has the same problem every kendrick lamar album has it is way too long. a lot of the tracks are much longer than they need to be and this is only more apparent with the amount of repetition on this album. a poem is read several times throughout the album and it did not need to be. absolutely nothing was gained from doing it that way. many songs on this album have several verse that are either entirely identical or have 1 or 2 different lines. there is 1 track i want to go in depth on because it showcases every problem i have with this album. the track i am referring to is the last track on the album mortal man. mortal man is my least favourite song of all time no exaggeration. it is such a perfect storm of shit that it is the main reason i dislike this album. but i will get into that later. mortal man can roughly be divided into 3 sections song poem and interview. the track as a whole but primarily the song and interview portions of the track is unnecessarily long and repetitive. if you look at the lyrics for mortal man you will notice that it is extremely long. however upon closer inspection you will see that a bunch of it is just repeating what was said before. it is followed by kendrick reading the poem we have heard so many times before. if this was the first or second time we heard it i would be okay with it but by now it is lost all meaning. it is then revealed that he was reading this poem to tupac which then begins the part of the track that i have heard the most praise about the interview section. kendrick takes an interview with tupac and attempts to make it seem like a regular conversation. this while good in concept is poorly executed in my opinion. it still feels like an interview kendrick does not respond much to tupacs responses like you would in a regular conversation and instead asks other questions so that it will fit with what tupac said in the interview that is being sampled. the conversation just feels disjointed and unnatural. i have a few minor complaints about some of the stuff he says in this section but as that does not affect the quality of this album i will refrain from saying anything. even though i have been mostly negative there are things this album does well. the instrumentals are great and the concept of jazz rap seems very appealing to me i feel like it could be better executed.

re-assessment of hip-hop 6 kendrick lamar as of 2017 has overtaken kanye west as the most artistically acclaimed rapper. indeed the first tracks on this album show signs of at least matching the creativeartistic prowess of kanyes my beautiful dark twisted fantasy. the eccentric electronic composition surrounding wesley theory and the creative jazz incorporated into for free? signal that the album might be one of the more creative hip-hop albums ever produced. however the tracks king kunta institutionalized and these walls destroy this hope by returning to the fatal and needless formula that plagues the rest of hip-hop lounge music consisting of a drum beat with minimalist accompaniment. in fact these walls gets rid of the beat and simply transforms into outright lounge music. some semblance of atmosphere is recovered in you with it is sleepy jazz instrumentals and a somewhat manic vocal delivery. this glimmer of atmosphere is crushed again by alright. the following six tracks are a trial of pure suffering to listen through being languid rb tracks with sleepy vocals. the blacker the berry is an extremely run-of-the-mill attempt at hardcore hip-hop. the album then finishes with another borecore rb piece an extremely run-of-the-mill party song and finally a 12 minute long piece of lounge music interspersed with mediocre beat poetry. final verdict 310 terrible

i quite like the beats and kendricks vocal style but i could do without the childish lyrics. also this record seems to have been resposible for a load of similar cash-in political albums in 2016. as much as i feel for black people in the us at times this sort of protest record leaves me cold.

this album has a great sample to start it off and then people try to rap and it loses all legitimacy. most ordinary vanilla ass average hip hop album of all time. any critic who rates this album as good should be embarrassed. it sounds more like rb than hip hop. no one rapping on this album should be ever be considered a descent rapper. their flows are boring and fail to bring out their lyrical content. i cannot say i hate this album because whenever i listen to it i am stuck in a sort of daze where i do not hate it but i feel as though i am constantly waiting for it to do something. it is the epitome of popular hip hop i cannot understand why people think this is some transcendent album to be remembered as one of the greatest of all time.
kendrick lamar has taste in music but it sounds little more than a poor mans fear of a black planet to me.

i have always tried so hard to really really love kendrick lamar like everyone else does... but to me it is all a bunch of humble bragging. i believe he is trying to send a message but i keep on hearing me me me me me. it is nothing new for hip-hop. and he talks about his dick size in at least one song here. what a great role model for young people! same old same old. i do not care how experimental the approach is. the subject matter is nothing i have not heard before. and sheesh the album never ends!

the best out of kls 3 albums. the production of course is batshit crazy as always but kl here actually brings some more technical skill to his rapping. yeah it is still fucken weird but at least it does not sound lazy anymore. still i am never going to be able to get over the sound being so deeply rooted in rnb which i cannot stand so i am fooling myself to think i will ever be able to enjoy this album as much more than a curiosity.

this album belongs to the list of rare cases when i acknowledge how important and influential it is for so many people or the music in general but my own subjective taste does not let me recognize it as a masterpiece. it gets even weirder when i think how much i love the work of a few contributors and certain elements they bring in the record like for example the bass lines of thundercat or the production of flying lotus. anyway these distinct elements form the unique atmosphere and decorate appropriately kendrick lamars varied style and rhymes throughout the record and critically contribute to its deservedly characterization as an one-of-a-kind record. to pimp a butterfly will probably dominate most music fans or magazines lists at the end of the year but i am still not convinced and resisting to surrender to an although very powerful at the same time heavily influenced by politics and social matters album which usually is not part of my favorite music even though i highly respect. maybe it is just my impression that there is much potential in kendricks music to further expand his audience outside of hip hop. i have read that except collaborators they are good friends as well so i would love to hear a thundercat flying lotus and kendrick lamar avant-garde jazz rap record one day.

to pimp a butterfly has been lauded across the board as a gamechanger for the genre. i am unconvinced. undoubtedly it is got its moments - king kunta institutionalised you are not got to lie and mortal man are all standouts. musically it has more going on than most hip hop albums and is excellently produced. lyrically it does have a lot to say even if it cannot help itself with vulgarity. it is a solid effort deserving of a 7 or 8 out of 10. that is what i am giving it. i prefer east coast stuff.

appreciate the production which pulls from a number of genres old-school samples smooth beats jazz and funk. there is a really good flow between tracks and the guests do not detract from the album as they often tend to. despite all that it comes off as kind of dry in that not one song grabbed me. i appreciate conscious hip hop but the message was kind of lost here for me. good for a listen like a podcast but i do not see why i would want to revisit.

nothing like his other albums kendrick lamar got too many ideas in his head. cannot figure out if he wants to be a expirimental version of common. or a more political version of dre. boring as hell. some of these songs go on seemingly for forever. i do not agree with this whole thing bout this production being game changing or whatever. they are sleep inducing. kendrick is not too far from going full on pop star after making a song like alright and collabing with taylor swift.
it has some good sounds and some ideas... but i think he would have better forced them in 4-5 songs. sixteen are too much.

i quite enjoyed aspects of this the p-funkjazz and neo soul backing tracks he used in places especially. he is a goodstrong rapper and at times things get pretty intense. their is a strong political flavour to the record but it takes in other subjects like black on black crimedepression and sex. on the downside - a lot of spoken word sections that are boringthe album is way overlong and repetitive and some of the raps are downright irritating. i do accept i am probably not the target audience for this though. lol
an earnest album rather than a profound one. there is some okay beats here but too often it wears the gimmick of hip-hop with wacky sound effects. still endearingly strange and emotionally naked.

unimpressed by this as much as every reviewer everywhere in the universe seems to be impressed ... am i so out of the hip hop groove that it says nothing to me about my life? i will stick with chuck d circa 1988.

i was not all too convinced of this album. yes it is smooth and dynamic but lyrically i feel it is not as conscious as before. the tracks mixing jazz funk and soul to them were the ones i did like here but otherwise i felt rather oh whatever of the material. so there are some pearls here but the rest is rather bigtime boredom.

in all sincerity this one is a solid 3-3.5 but my vote reflects how overrated this record is in my opinion. nothing stands out immediately like his prior lp which is not a necessity but its coherence is also kind of a drag as well.

ok. people are waaay overreacting to what is a great record but not a classic nor the artists best. i will try to explain... shout out the yale herald in to pimp a butterfly the follow-up to 2012s good kid m.a.a.d city kendrick lamar takes an audacious step forward but also gets a little stuck in the past. his decision to tackle uncomfortable issues of social justice and self-doubt in this anticipated release is bold and new. his lyricism does not disappoint. but in crafting the sound of the album he shunned mainstream production in favor of throwback sounds. while this is smart in theory it does not completely work the project lacks sonic cohesion so it cannot be called a bona fide instant classic. i respect kendricks decision to draw in jazz and soul influences but some of the beats just are not fitting this coming from someone who counts something else and a love supreme among his all-time favorites. you is the emotional climax of the album and would be one of its best songs but for the vibe-killing instrumentation after the beat switches. the man is contemplating suicide and the best you can give him is a sad jazz sax? the lyrics are terrifying they deserve a terrifying instrumental. king kunta is fun but it offers little that suga free and dj quik did not do years ago. in general the album sounds too derivative. i am confused by critics who call joey bada anachronistic and kendrick a game-changing visionary in the same breath. it is revealing that the best song on the album both lyrically and sonically also boasts the most modern production. the menacing synths and thumping percussion of the blacker the berry plus the yeezus-citing dancehall bridge make an appropriate framework for the most memorable verses of the year i am african-american i am african  i am black as the heart of a fucking aryan. the title track is another clear highlight but begs the question why make a jazz-hop album in 2015 and only put flylo on one beat? last years never catch me displays an energy that this lp craves. i would have liked to see more of the fela kuti influence present on the closing track that afrobeat pioneer being one of kendricks more novel references. speaking of mortal man i love the audacity of the tupac sample but editing yourself into one of his interviews feels sacrilegious. it also adds length to an album that already seems bloated 79 minutes is a long runtime and there are a few tracks momma institutionalized that you could excise without compromising the albums message. the message is complex but compelling. he is mad and he lays into all he sees white america the music industry himself. the fact remains that kendricks lyrics are brilliantly devastating critics want to mention they miss when hip-hop was rappin motherfucker if you did killer miked be platinum. but i hear a deep disconnect between that message and the sounds that surround it. the day after to pimp a butterfly came out i was listening in the car with a friend. he remarked that the settingsun out windows downwas perfect for the smooth sound of the record and i had to agree. but later that night really digging into the lyrics i realized kendrick may have intended this to be a claustrophobic suffocating listen. this disconnect means to pimp a butterfly is not as instantly iconic as good kid m.a.a.d city but it is nevertheless a captivating story of racial tension and religious salvation and a worthy follow-up. 7.210 the blacker the berry wesleys theory hood politics

as letras so majoritariamente speras e them tom bem confessional e raivoso mesmo que por vezes estejam envoltas numa atmosfera bem soft. quanto ao instrumental com exceo de poucas faixas a eventual tentativa de ser simples me soa preguiosa. de resto a voz do cara no me desce mas a proposta dele  mais que aceitvel. the blacker the berry i e mortal man fogem absurdamente do padro das outras faixas ganhando destaque incontestvel. impressionante como isso deixa o lbum inconstante e desproporcional! e  a que sinto que o cara no vale todo esse oba oba. se ele  o maluco mais gabaritado pra representar o gnero no sculo xxi prefiro ficar com a galerinha de uns 25 anos atrs ou at mesmo com os modernosos aesop rock e criolo que no vivem tanto de lampejos.

i will willingly throw out there that i am not a particular fan of hip-hop and yet or perhaps because of i am already tired of these same old stories of misunderstood cult heroes of the relentlessly bleak hood life. call me some synonym of white but i have heard all of good kid maad city or whatever the hell the stylization is before in greater or no more a commanding voice. that ones success was as unsurprising as the album itself sounding every bit like a revival of late 90s conscious rap. predictably to pimp a butterfly follows the same direction as its inspirers. lamar digs doubly backwards to incorporate the same jazzfunksoul sounds as others have done before with the original shock impression having long faded by now. or maybe not considering tpabs reception. that or we all love a decent take on our old favorites. but this is not anything revolutionary and as such it will never start a revolution as much as it wants to. hell this album is literally black messiah with the genre chemical makeup rebalanced somewhat. remember that one? not many seem to and dangelo undeservedly did not even have as much hype. as implied earlier kendrick lacks a distinct forceful personality and that character influences the limits of his music. shoot did anyone really care about the struggle? maybe it is now left best bitching at idiotic rednecks on facebook who try and justicy the latest racial transgressions. do not collect 500 4.5 ratings. go directly to tetsuo  youth.

to pimp a butterfly is an intriguing album and cultural event that reveals less with more listening. its problems are best displayed on its best song king kunta which slams so hard with dj quik drumblams and a disco-rap bassline to recreate james brown for 2k15 but all building up to little more than a homage to funk heroes with a sick hook catchier than holden on some crazy cliff and underdeveloped verses. basically this track is how i feel about kendrick at his best  he does throw a thousand great influences together with talented musicians who can make it smooth a mosaic of beautiful sounds that adds up to no coherence. and he should rap more since he does have flow when he needs to on these verse fragments that we rarely get. one of his most important and exciting nuances is his narratorrapper split where you can never be sure how honest his rapping is  might he just be playing a character or an earlier version of himself as was often his method on his previous rekkerd? and sometimes this irony can work well. but more often it just creates unsolved confusion for us while we give him an undeserved pass for saying stuff that could end up meaning almost anything just cos meaning almost anything is a virtue no matter how unintentional. the yams are the powers that be but he also has got the yams so who knows how may rapgeniuses it is going to take to explain that bit of lyrical contradicting thoughtlessness? oh but it is ironic and dealing with dual-meanings...or something. i find it to be just lazy connections and it takes me out of that deep groove. and why is lifescreaming annie are you ok? other than to drop in a reference to an inspiration? it sounds cool but it is purposeless and inane. he gets into battle rap mode too infrequently on this album i guess in an effort to push rap forward or whatever common has been doing for a decade plus but when he does again i am divided. his strongest diss is aimed at biting rappers yall share bars like you got the bottom bunk in a two-man cell while he concurrently plunders lines and deliveries from the payback among others which his fanbase will either ignore or celebrate as being meta-cool is he another voice here calling out himself? but i think he is just confusedly throwing everything around and hoping for a vague hip hopfunk song that hits it all at once. also how can dre not feel a bit hurt? i get much of the support for this album comes from it being introspective and still big-society condemning which is great except when it feels like his lines could mean anything or nothing. is he conscious of how wildly exaggerated it is to compare himself to mandela or haley? it seems that sometimes he is and sometimes he revels in that extreme ego  and again i want to applaud honesty but it is too loose and flying everywhere. we are supposed to praise its craft and attention to detail while also recognizing that some of its details are egotistical and underthought so that other than when he is bleating-screaming his hypocrite exorcism of himself as on the blacker the berry i am not sure how seriously he takes individual lines he is saying. obviously it is easier when goofy voices are putting on characters but these parts are even more problematic in being badly-rapped-for-sake-of-making-irony-apparent etc. essentially i am supposed to think it is good when it is not good because that shows his contradictory nature. intrigued at this albums task of trying to decode its puzzle i end up finding less and less meaning as i put it all together and find it is really not that deep. often it is just a display of a guys sometimes half-baked thoughts like any rap album great or not. will we still love him when his dirty secrets get out? is perhaps crossing a line uncomfortably while still seeming under-analyzed like any message board can i still like burzum? post. snippets of a poem that is so vague and underwritten flow throughout and for everyone who says there is a butterfly-symbology motifing in-n-out there is just as much randomness rap normalness love lyrics vague spiritualism etc. and then if it is throwing rap forward to year 3000 why do we still get long talking interludeskits with diminishing replay value saxophone careless-whispering outerludes and rap clichs galore? it is just not doing that much. cracked-open song structures this i can certainly get behind and wild genre bending is cool but none of it seems to match even lesser acclaimed albums that have been doing this thing in hip hop from 90s onward. spiral those walls into divine light instead! for how conceptual this album gets credit for being i see almost no coherence other than loose topics that many hip hop albums deal with anyhow with a particular focus on race. i also get that it is got mass appeal and high school kids will be blown away and that is great  it sounds radical for a mainstream rap album since kendrick so rarely does rap while still touching on enough elements to be understood by that audience and he is legions more self-aware than most rap videos will ever be. his referenced literature is likewise stuck in a high-school bookroom which helps. kids can easily pick up on those mockingbird parallels and achebe. but it is not getting near the coup in its politics and mouthful references or freestyle fellowship in its jazz-splunk spray or even some mainstream stuff that did get kendrick level support like outkast in its funk synthing spirituality. yes i am glad a new generation of 10th graders is hearing something out of their regular mold since it can get massive mainstream appeal and promotion but it is not changing anything for me.
i think this is better than his previous album. i like the way he uses jazz here. the theme here is somewhat less offensive.

while i will not try to argue my case on the message behind this work the music itself is not entirely great. jazzfunk production comes off as the flavor of the month in hip hop right now. 3-4 of the songs could also be cut as they sound like filler. i do not understand the high ratings this album is getting as its a 6.5 at its best and sounds like early black-eyed peas b-sides at worst. overall an exhausting overly preachy mess that many will find amusing because kendrick tells a tale of race that comes off as amazing in a hip hop environment riddled with catchy one liners and generic subject matter. 5.3-5.7.

am i the only person who thinks section 80 is his best album? the storytelling was more captivating the lyrics more fluid the politics less prevalent. he is trying hard to me a sociopolitical force and kudos to him for trying to leverage his importance. but this is music and he is no chuck d not yet

edit overall this grew on me and i would like to believe i am less of a prick now than i was when i wrote this. i will leave it be though it is kind of funny to me. i tried pretty hard to love this and i still feel a bit dumb for not getting it you know. but truth is i think i get it and still do not care too much for it. first of all let us give credit where credit is due the production on this thing is awesome. all over the place that is a recurring theme but awesome. i am a sucker for funk and there is a lot of it jazz influenced beats all over the place straight up jazz sometimes. overall i am really happy that kendrick went for a more instrumental kind of sound that is a pretty big gamble for someone in his position. now i will have to admit something i do not give a fuck about political messages and how deep the lyrics are. i would go as far as saying that i do not really care about what the lyrics mean as long as they sound good probably because english is not my language or maybe because i am an idiot. anyway this brings me to the fact that i find kendricks rapping pretty underwhelming i do not like his voice to much and his delivery is not really dynamic. also all those fakeweird voices he uses all along the album i do find rather grating for sale is the most obvious one but it is all over the record. in the end my main problem is how hit and miss it is not even from track to track but inside the tracks themselves. one second i feel like there is something really cool brewing up and the next one there is an annoying weird voice bit or a bitch talking about bald ass niggers or that song ruining featuring in the blacker the berry. oh and that fucking poem cut it off already. it is fun how negative this review sounds when i actually enjoyed the album a fair bit. king kunta and i are wonderful. but there is so much that keeps me from calling it a masterpiece or a classic. and then there will be people saying that i do not get it because i am a middle class white twenty something and i am pretty sure they would be right.

i think i can now say this with confidence. kendrick is just not the mc for me. if you collaborate with flying lotusthundercat two of my favorite musicians currently working and i only kind of like your new album i am not sure what else you can do to impress me. i suppose i should explain what i did like about this. first off flylo and thunder are all. over. this. it is really cool to hear them working with an mc extensively over this project. the three of them along with some sessions musicians work as a really cohesive unit. and that is the type of cohesion i thought good kid maad city sorely lacked. this project also contributes to a change in sound for kendrick which is a major improvement for him. i enjoyed that this does not sound like a straight forward hip-hop album but is rather reminiscent to the soulful funkadelic experimental albums that were seemingly all the rage in the early 00s. there is also a lack of radio singles aside from the two that were released prior to this album. it is a pretty bold move from one of the most popular rappers in the game. in fact the sound on this album flies in the face of pretty much the rest of hip-hop. these walls and how much a dollar cost sets an incredibly high watermark for others to achieve. but ultimately it is this very sound that forces kendrick to take a backseat on his very own album. my mind pretty much zoned out during those poetic interludes and do not get me started on that gimmicky 2pac interview. i was so impressed by the production here that at the end of the day it does not matter which rapper jumps on this. as much as i would like to hear more tracks in this vein ironically he is not the selling point. so despite the ambition and scope shown here kendrick still does not do anything for me.

perhaps i gravitate toward the axiom the simpler the better in my rejection of this highly regarded album. a celebration of jazz its offshoot synth funk thru the oral cinematography made popular by prince paul. ke ndrick uses a very highly stylized vocal rap reminiscent of rammellzee later popularized by flavor flav. throw in a quasimoto reference if you want as well this is fine. a jamboree of sound often unconcerned with melody. too busy for nuance. sweet syrup draped in coarse pointed hydraulics for a statement that is not abundantly clear. perhaps a riddle hidden amongst its theatrical complexity with clues lying in its historical references. it is certainly easy to miss amongst the abstract outbursts of emotion and syncopated energy. maybe this is the greatest showman of rap. polish pizzazz and rotating cast of characters who quickly disseminate behind the curtains. dsemnshn kendrick knowing damn well that we the people want to see what is forbidden. the fringe. a world beyond our own. an unapologetic statment of blackness. there is plenty to enjoy and become fixated on. the layers of sound contain lovely musicianship. harmonies. juxtaposed transfusions of sounds
